Incorrect: Patients with overt disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) have abnormal coagulation profiles (elevated PT, aPTT, and INR) together with systemic signs (tachycardia, possible hypotension) and active bleeding. In pregnancy, it is usually associated with placental abruption, severe preeclampsia, or postpartum hemorrhage, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic for evaluation of easy bruising. The patient states that for the past few months, she has noticed frequent bruising on many different parts of her body without preceding trauma. This week, she noticed bruising on her right thigh and left arm without recent trauma to the areas. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. The patient has no other medical problems and takes no medication. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use other recreational drugs, over-the-counter medications, or herbal supplements. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows two small ecchymoses on the right thigh and one small ecchymosis on the left upper arm. There is no evidence of petechiae, lymphadenopathy, or hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies are shown below. Peripheral blood smears are unremarkable. Which of the following tests should be performed next?  

 Laboratory Test  Result
 Hemoglobin   13.9 g/dL 
 Leukocyte count  5,000/μL 
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)  89 fL 
 Platelet count  41,000/μL 
 Reticulocyte count  1.0% of erythrocytes 
 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  175 U/L 
 Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL 
 Prothrombin time (PT)  12 s 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)  22 s 
 International normalized ratio (INR)  1.0 
 Urinalysis  Normal

choices.text: HIV and hepatitis C virus testing

questions.solution:
This patient presented with multiple unexplained ecchymoses in the setting of isolated thrombocytopenia and a normal coagulation profile; she likely has immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Patients with presumed ITP should undergo an initial assessment that includes testing for HIV and hepatitis C virus, as thrombocytopenia can be the initial presenting sign of these infections.  

Defects in primary hemostasis, or platelet disorders (such as ITP), usually cause bleeding of skin and mucous membranes, as well as immediate bleeding after surgery. Diagnostic evaluation involves obtaining a complete blood count with peripheral smear, coagulation profile (PT, aPTT, INR), fibrinogen, and d-dimer. Patients with ITP exhibit a platelet count of <100,000/uL and a reduced number of platelets or giant platelets on peripheral smear. Since there is only platelet destruction without blood clot formation, PT, aPTT, fibrinogen, and D-dimer will be normal.    

ITP can be primary or secondary. Initially, secondary causes should be ruled out, including infections such as HIV and hepatitis C; autoimmune disorders such as systemic lupus erythematosus, medications (e.g., antibiotics, anticonvulsants, quinine, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors, NSAIDs), and immunodeficiency syndromes. Once secondary causes are ruled out, the diagnosis of primary ITP can be made. Bone marrow biopsy is not required for diagnosis but can be considered when an alternative diagnosis is suspected, like myelodysplastic syndromes, or if the diagnosis is unclear.  

Option Analysis

❌ Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) antibody testing:
Incorrect: Thrombocytopenia is the most common manifestation of HIT. However, this patient was not exposed to heparin, which is a required criterion to make the diagnosis of HIT.
✅ HIV and hepatitis C virus testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antiplatelet antibodies testing:
Incorrect: The existing approach to testing for antiplatelet antibodies lacks the necessary sensitivity and specificity to help diagnose immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Therefore, it is not useful for making the diagnosis of ITP.
❌ Direct and indirect Coombs test:
Incorrect: Direct and indirect Coombs tests are performed to diagnose autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Patients with AIHA have laboratory features of ongoing hemolysis (declining hemoglobin, increased reticulocyte count, elevated LDH), which this patient lacks.
❌ Vitamin B12 and folate levels:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 and folic acid are required for hematopoiesis. Deficiency of these vitamins typically causes megaloblastic anemia or macrocytosis without anemia in mild cases. Isolated thrombocytopenia is rare. This patient has a normal MCV and hemoglobin, making deficiency of these vitamins unlikely.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of severe left ear pain and discharge. The symptoms started three days ago and have progressively worsened. The pain is worse during the night time. The patient also reports discomfort and pain while chewing from the left side of the jaw. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus, as the patient is noncompliant with medication and follow-up visits. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 99/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg. Physical examination reproduced severe pain on moving or touching the pinna. Otoscopic examination shows granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal at the bone-cartilage junction. Initial cultures show a motile, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative rod. Which of the following antibiotics have activity against the organism responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has severe ear pain, discharge, and granulation tissue in the ear canal. This, in combination with uncontrolled diabetes and initial culture findings (motile, oxidase-positive, Gram-negative rod), is consistent with malignant otitis externa, secondary to infection by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This patient should be treated with systemic piperacillin, an extended-spectrum penicillin.  

Extended-spectrum penicillins, also known as antipseudomonal penicillins (e.g., piperacillin, ticarcillin) have activity against several Gram-negative rods, including Pseudomonas, Enterobacter, and in some cases Klebsiella species. Most drugs in this subgroup have synergistic actions with aminoglycosides against such organisms. Piperacillin and ticarcillin are susceptible to penicillinases and are nearly exclusively used in combination with penicillinase inhibitors (e.g., tazobactam, clavulanic acid) to enhance their activity.

Option Analysis

❌ Nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin is a penicillinase-resistant penicillin that is effective against Staphylococcus aureus (except MRSA). It has no activity against Gram-negative rods.
✅ Piperacillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Cephalexin is a first-generation cephalosporin and is effective against Gram-positive cocci, Proteus mirabilis, E. coli, and Klebsiella pneumoniae and can be used for surgical prophylaxis and treatment of urinary tract infections and minor skin and soft tissue infections. It is, however, not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is usually used in the management of Borrelia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia, or Chlamydia infections. It is, however, not effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol is a bacterial protein synthesis inhibitor, effective in the management of meningitis and/or rickettsial diseases. It is, however, not effective in the management of malignant otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with one month of nausea, vomiting, and early satiety. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, type II diabetes mellitus, schizophrenia, and a prior episode of tardive dyskinesia. Current medications include aripiprazole, carvedilol, lisinopril, metformin, and pioglitazone. On physical examination there are hypoactive bowel sounds and an abdominal succussion splash is present. There is no significant tenderness to abdominal palpation. Laboratory values include a prolactin of 120 ng/mL and hemoglobin A1c of 12%. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Domperidone is an anti-dopaminergic agent used for treating gastroparesis. These days, it has largely been replaced by metoclopramide. Domperidone can help symptoms related to gastroparesis by inhibiting dopaminergic pathways in the brain and promoting muscarinic receptor-mediated gastric emptying.      

Domperidone increases the risk for tardive dyskinesia, which is a movement disorder thought to arise from an imbalance of dopamine blockade and overactivation of D1 receptors. Concomitant use of antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol, aripiprazole) is a relative contraindication to domperidone therapy. A prior history of tardive dyskinesia is an absolute contraindication.      

Additional relative contraindications include hyperprolactinemia and prolonged QT intervals whereas mechanical bowel obstruction is another absolute contraindication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Erythromycin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of gastroparesis. Erythromycin has promotility properties that can be used to manage the symptoms of gastroparesis. There are no contraindications to the use of erythromycin in this patient. 
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine reduces nausea by antagonizing H1-receptors in the vestibular apparatus and is not helpful in managing the symptoms of gastroparesis. While they are not contraindicated in this patient, first-generation antihistamines should be used sparingly as they have many side effects.
❌ Empagliflozin:
Incorrect: This patient has no contraindication to SGLT-2 inhibitors and would probably benefit from one given his history of congestive heart failure and hypertension. Contraindications include frequent urinary tract infections as well as a history of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis or Fournier gangrene.
❌ Granisetron:
Incorrect: Granisetron, like ondansetron, is a 5-HT3 antagonist that works in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. While it does not help gastroparesis-related nausea very much, it is not contraindicated in this patient.
✅ Domperidone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man presents to the clinic with two weeks of severe nausea and vomiting. Two weeks ago, he started treatment for small cell lung cancer with cisplatin and etoposide. Other medical history includes chronic urinary retention, glaucoma, and mild cognitive impairment. Other medications include dexamethasone, granisetron, and timolol eye drops. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination there is no abdominal tenderness to palpation. Which of the following medication types should be added to improve this patient’s nausea?
questions.solution:
Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant, fosaprepitant) are used frequently for patients with chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. They can be used for prevention or treatment, and are frequently combined with dexamethasone and a 5-HT3 antagonist. Anticholinergics and antihistamines can also treat nausea from chemotherapy, but have more side effects and are often less effective than neurokinin-1 antagonists. This patient’s chemotherapy regimen includes cisplatin, which is highly emetogenic.     

Aprepitant works by inhibiting the binding of substance P to neurokinin-1 receptors. Neurokinin-1 receptors are found in many areas of the central (including the area postrema) and peripheral nervous systems.      

Side effects of aprepitant include fatigue, constipation, and hiccups. It can cause inhibition of the CYP3A4 pathway and should be used cautiously in patients taking medications metabolized via this pathway.  

Option Analysis

❌ 5-HT3 antagonist:
Incorrect: This patient is already on a 5-HT3 antagonist (granisetron), so addition of another agent in this class (e.g. ondansetron) is unlikely to provide further benefit.
✅ Neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ First generation histamine-1 receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: In general, first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) should be avoided in elderly patients. These medications are more likely to cause confusion and anticholinergic side effects (e.g., urinary retention, constipation) in elderly patients.
❌ Muscarinic receptor antagonist:
Incorrect: Antimuscarinics (also known as anticholinergics) should be used very cautiously in patients with glaucoma and in older patients as they can cause confusion. In addition, this patient’s chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting will likely respond better to a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist such as aprepitant.
❌ Motilin agonist:
Incorrect: Motilin agonists (e.g., erythromycin) are unlikely to reduce this patient’s nausea. These agents work by promoting gastric emptying, but his symptoms are chemotherapy-induced rather than gastroparesis-related.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the emergency department with five hours of nausea and hematemesis. He has no past medical history and takes no medications. He is admitted to the hospital overnight and transfused with two units of packed red blood cells. He has a history of transfusion reactions and is given intravenous medication before transfusion. The next morning, the patient is disoriented and has blurry vision. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 141/73 mmHg. On physical examination, there is disorientation, dry mucous membranes, normal extraocular movements, and suprapubic fullness with tenderness to palpation. A urinary catheter is placed and 950 ml of yellow urine is removed. Which of the following medications is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from the anticholinergic side effects of diphenhydramine, which was likely given as a premedication prior to his blood transfusion. The medication crosses the blood-brain barrier and blocks H1 receptors in multiple areas of the brain, including the vestibular apparatus.    

First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) should be avoided in elderly patients as they are much more prone to its side effects. Side effects include sedation, confusion, and anticholinergic effects (e.g., dry mouth and eyes, tachycardia, urinary retention, blurry vision). If an antihistamine is required, a newer generation medication is preferred (e.g. cetirizine, fexofenadine, loratadine). 

Option Analysis

❌ Bethanechol:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinergic medication that is used to treat urinary retention and would not cause this constellation of symptoms. If the patient’s urinary retention is chronic, then bethanechol could be a potential treatment.
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: While high-dose steroids can cause mental status changes, his acute urinary retention, blurry vision, dry mouth, and tachycardia are better explained by anticholinergic side effects.     
✅ Diphenhydramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Domperidone:
Incorrect: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist that is frequently used for nausea. It can cause a prolonged QT interval, tardive dyskinesia, and rarely confusion. However, this patient is presenting with confusion, dry mucosal membranes, and urinary retention, which is more concerning for anticholinergic side effects.
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Domperidone is a dopamine receptor antagonist that is frequently used for gastroparesis-related nausea. It can cause a prolonged QT interval, tardive dyskinesia, and rarely confusion. However, this patient is presenting with confusion, dry mucosal membranes, and urinary retention, which is more concerning for anticholinergic side effects.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the clinic with two months of nausea and vomiting. The symptoms began after her most recent cycle of chemotherapy, which was started for pancreatic cancer. Over the past two months she has lost 14 pounds and has no appetite. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Current medications include dexamethasone, palonosetron, and pancreatic enzyme supplements. Allergies include aprepitant and sulfonamide antibiotics. Which of the following medication classes should be added to improve this patient’s anorexia and nausea?
questions.solution:
This patient has anorexia, nausea, and vomiting associated with chemotherapy. Cannabinoid agonists such as dronabinol can help treat both anorexia and nausea. Dronabinol’s antiemetic effect is mediated via stimulation of cannabinoid receptors (CB1 and CB2) in the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the brain.      

Of note, an antimuscarinic agent (e.g., scopolamine) could also be an appropriate antiemetic for this patient but does not have as much appetite stimulation as dronabinol.    

Abrupt withdrawal from dronabinol can cause a myriad of side effects including tachycardia, irritability, and insomnia. Some patients experience fatigue or vertigo with this medication.    

Dronabinol is mostly used as a long-term medication for anorexia and nausea, or as a prophylactic medicine for patients receiving chemotherapy. It is also used frequently in patients with AIDS or cachexia to stimulate appetite. In contrast, dronabinol is not as effective for short term relief or for managing acute nausea.

Option Analysis

❌ 5-HT3 antagonist:
Incorrect: This patient is already on a 5-HT3 antagonist (palonosetron). The addition of another agent in this class (e.g. ondansetron) is unlikely to provide further benefit.
✅ Cannabinoid agonist:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Histamine antagonist:
Incorrect: First-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) can be effective at treating nausea. However, they have numerous side effects including sedation and confusion in older patients. As a result, other medications with fewer side effects should be tried first.
❌ Motilin agonist:
Incorrect: Motilin agonists (e.g., erythromycin) are unlikely to reduce nausea. These work by promoting gastric emptying, so this could be used if the patient’s nausea were from gastroparesis rather than chemotherapy.
❌ Neurokinin-1 antagonist:
Incorrect: Aprepitant would be an excellent choice for this patient’s chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, especially if she is on highly emetogenic chemotherapy. However, she has an allergy to aprepitant and as a result, medications in this class should be avoided.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of pain from swallowing and retrosternal burning chest pain for the past two weeks. The patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over time. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. The patient underwent an uncomplicated renal transplantation 6-months ago. He takes metformin, semaglutide, mycophenolate mofetil, and cyclosporine. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows marked epigastric tenderness. The oral mucosa is moist without any ulcerations. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows linear, shallow ulcers in the lower esophagus. Biopsy revealed intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive retrosternal chest pain and pain with swallowing, in combination with endoscopy findings of linear, shallow ulcers in the lower esophagus with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis, most likely due to immunosuppression following renal transplantation. The treatment of choice is intravenous ganciclovir.   

Ganciclovir, a guanosine analog, is triphosphorylated to form a nucleotide that inhibits DNA polymerases of CMV and herpes simplex virus (HSV) to cause chain termination. Ganciclovir is initially phosphorylated by the enzyme UL-97 kinase, which is found in CMV and HSV-infected cells. It is mainly used for prophylaxis and treatment of CMV retinitis and other CMV infections in immunocompromised patients (e.g., esophagitis, as in this patient). CMV resistance mechanisms involve mutations in the genes that code for the activating viral phosphotransferase and the viral DNA polymerase. Thymidine kinase-deficient HSV strains are also resistant to ganciclovir.  

It causes serious side effects, including suppression of the bone marrow, which manifests as leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and anemia. Other side effects include nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, mucositis, and seizures.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is an effective treatment option for HSV esophagitis, which presents with well-circumscribed lesions with a round-oval “volcano-like appearance”. This patient’s shallow linear ulcers with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions are suggestive of CMV infection. Acyclovir is not indicated for CMV infections.
❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is the treatment of choice in candida esophagitis, which typically presents with a white plaque on endoscopy. Shallow linear ulcers with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions are not seen.
✅ Ganciclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Omeprazole :
Incorrect: Omeprazole is an effective treatment option for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It usually presents with heartburn and reflux of acidic material in the mouth. The presence of shallow linear ulcers in the lower esophagus is suggestive of CMV infection.
❌ Symptomatic therapy:
Incorrect: Symptomatic therapy would be appropriate in patients with aphthous ulcers. This patient most likely has cytomegalovirus esophagitis and should receive treatment with ganciclovir.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral eye pain, which has been ongoing for the past 2 weeks. The pain was initially described as a “sand in my eyes” feeling, but it has now progressed to sharp, stabbing pain. The patient previously used artificial tears, but now they provide minimal symptomatic relief. In addition, the patient has been experiencing dryness in the mouth and joint pain in the fingers. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 145/83 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. There is bilateral conjunctival injection. The oral mucosal membranes are dry. A Shirmer test is performed and reveals decreased tear production. The patient is prescribed a medication that improves tear and saliva production. Several days later, the patient begins experiencing shortness of breath and wheezing. Which medication was she most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with dry eyes (due to decreased tear production), dry mouth, and joint pain. These findings are suggestive of Sjogren syndrome (SS), a chronic multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the lacrimal and salivary glands that results in dry eyes and mouth. This patient was most likely treated with systemic pilocarpine, a cholinomimetic that stimulates secretions from the lacrimal and salivary glands. Pilocarpine also acts on the bronchial smooth muscles, causing bronchospasm in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Cholinomimetics (e.g., bethanechol, carbachol, pilocarpine) have no absolute contraindications. However, since they cause bronchospasms, they should be avoided in individuals with COPD and asthma. Moreover, they increase gastric acid secretion and should be avoided in individuals with peptic ulcer disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pilocarpine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ipratropium:
Incorrect: Ipratropium is an anticholinergic medication used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Ipratropium is unlikely to exacerbate COPD symptoms.  
❌ Mirabegron:
Incorrect: Sympathomimetics such as mirabegron act on the β3-receptor to cause relaxation of the detrusor smooth muscle, which leads to increased bladder capacity. Mirabegron is used in the management of urinary incontinence, but has no role in increasing tear or saliva production. Moreover, it does cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Miconazole:
Incorrect: Miconazole is an antifungal agent used to treat oral candidiasis. Although this patient has a dry mouth, there is no evidence of a fungal infection. Moreover, miconazole does not cause chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.  
❌ Bethanechol:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a cholinomimetic agent that can be administered to stimulate intestinal motility in patients with ileus or bladder contractility and emptying in patients with urinary retention. Bethanechol is not typically used in the production of tears and saliva. Therefore, it is unlikely this patient was prescribed bethanechol.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral nipple discharge. The patient’s menstrual cycle has been irregular for the past 6-months. She has also experienced mild breast tenderness. The patient is not currently sexually active. Past medical history is significant for atopic dermatitis and recent hospitalization for an episode of psychosis. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s maternal grandmother. The patient does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or illicit substances. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Laboratory studies reveal a prolactin level of 80 mg/dL and TSH of 2 mU/L. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral nipple discharge, breast tenderness, and amenorrhea. She has a recent history of hospitalization for psychosis, during which she most likely received antipsychotic medication. In combination, these findings are suggestive of medication-induced hyperprolactinemia, likely secondary to a typical antipsychotic, such as haloperidol.

Typical antipsychotics block D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular pathway. Normally, dopamine inhibits prolactin release. When these receptors are blocked, prolactin is released in increased amounts.  Increased prolactin can cause bilateral milky nipple discharge, oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea, decreased libido, and gynecomastia.

In addition, typical antipsychotics can inhibit the nigrostriatal pathway and result in extrapyramidal symptoms. These may manifest as abnormal movements such as tardive dyskinesia, dystonia, akathisia, and pseudoparkinsonism.

Typical antipsychotics also block α1-receptors causing orthostatic hypotension; muscarinic receptors causing anticholinergic side effects including dry mouth, blurred vision, urinary retention, and constipation; and histamine H1 receptors causing sedation. Other side effects include QT interval prolongation and metabolic changes (e.g., weight gain, dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism can predispose patients to develop hyperprolactinemia. However, this patient’s TSH level is within normal limits, and she does not have other symptoms associated with hypothyroidism (e.g., lethargy, dry skin, cold intolerance).  
❌ Prolactinoma:
Incorrect: Prolactinomas are benign pituitary tumors that can cause visual disturbance, headache, galactorrhea, and irregular menstrual cycles. In affected individuals, prolactin levels are significantly elevated (>200 ng/mL). In contrast, this patient’s prolactin level is only mildly elevated, which is more suggestive of medication-induced hyperprolactinemia.  
❌ Primary breast malignancy:
Incorrect: A primary breast malignancy can present as a unilateral breast lump and bloody nipple discharge. In contrast, this patient has bilateral nipple discharge, elevated prolactin level, and a recent episode of psychosis. This history is more suggestive of hyperprolactinemia secondary to treatment with antipsychotic medication.  
❌ Polycystic ovarian syndrome:
Incorrect: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is associated with hyperandrogenism and presents with a combination of hirsutism, topical treatment-resistant acne, menstrual irregularities, acanthosis nigricans, and obesity. It can occasionally cause elevated prolactin levels. This patient does not have typical signs of hyperandrogenism.  
✅ Medication side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of progressive fatigue and weakness for the past six months. She also complains of chronic abdominal pain and dizziness. Past medical history is significant for pulmonary tuberculosis, which was treated completely three years ago. The patient immigrated from China five years ago. Family history is noncontributory. She does not smoke, consume alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. The physician decides to perform a metyrapone stimulation test, as a part of his current research. Which of the following changes will be observed following the administration of metyrapone in this patient?  

Laboratory value
Results
Early morning serum cortisol
2 mcg/dL (normal: 10-20 mcg/dL)
Morning serum ACTH concentration
502 pg/mL (normal: 6-76 pg/mL)
Serum cortisol 30 minutes after the administration of 250 mcg of intravenous cosyntropin
5 mcg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with chronic fatigue, weakness, dizziness, and nonspecific abdominal pain is likely suffering from a chronic metabolic abnormality. Laboratory findings of decreased serum levels of morning cortisol increased serum ACTH, and the minimal response of cortisol to cosyntropin stimulation makes primary adrenal insufficiency the most likely diagnosis. It might be secondary tuberculous adrenalitis (given her history of tuberculosis) or autoimmune adrenalitis (the most common cause of primary adrenal insufficiency).

Metyrapone is an adrenal hormone synthesis inhibitor that blocks the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol by inhibiting the enzyme 11-beta hydroxylase in the zona fasciculata. The metyrapone stimulation test is based on the idea that its administration will decrease serum cortisol levels and increase serum ACTH levels due to the cortisol loss of negative feedback to the hypothalamus. An immediate increase follows in serum 11-deoxycortisol, a cortisol precursor devoid of glucocorticoid activity. It is a sensitive indicator of hypothalamus-pituitary-adrenal axis integrity. Failure of a rise in serum 11-deoxycortisol levels is an indicator of primary or secondary adrenal insufficiency.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Increase in serum cortisol:
Incorrect: Metyrapone inhibits 11-beta-hydroxylase and will result in decreased serum cortisol levels irrespective of the adrenal pathology.  
❌ Decline in serum ACTH levels:
Incorrect: This patient demonstrated a minimal response to the cosyntropin stimulation test (<20µg/dL cortisol). Moreover, her serum ACTH levels are high, making primary adrenal insufficiency the most likely diagnosis. Metyrapone inhibits 11-beta hydroxylase, which, in turn, inhibits the production of cortisol, lifting its negative feedback on ACTH secretion, ultimately causing a further increase in serum ACTH levels.  
❌ Increase in serum renin:
Incorrect: Metyrapone decreases serum aldosterone levels by inhibiting  11-beta-hydroxylase. The mineralocorticoid effect of its precursor 11-deoxycorticosterone prevents the development of mineralocorticoid deficiency. Thus renin levels are rarely affected.  
❌ Decreased serum testosterone:
Incorrect: Metyrapone increases the production of adrenal androgens while inhibiting the production of cortisol. Serum testosterone tends to increase rather than decrease with metyrapone administration.  
✅ Failure of rising in 11-deoxycortisol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is referred to the oncology clinic due to persistent fever, night sweats and unintentional weight loss. He has a past medical history of hypertension that is well-controlled with medication. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlarged, firm, mobile cervical lymph nodes on both sides. Complete blood count shows an elevated white blood cell count. A subsequent peripheral blood smear shows smudge cells. Flow cytometry shows a population of clonal cells co-expressing CD19 and CD20, and the diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia is made. After discussion with the patient, a medication targeting CD52 is recommended. Which of the following medications is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient suffers from classic systemic symptoms (“B symptoms”) of an underlying neoplastic malignancy including night sweats, weight loss, fever, and fatigue. Further testing shows smudge cells on peripheral smear and flow cytometry shows a population of CD19 and CD23 clonal cells. These findings suggest that this patient suffers from B cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.   

Treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia is varied and depends on the patient’s symptomatology and disease progression. Typically, fludarabine is used as a first-line therapy for asymptomatic patients. Alternatively, combination therapy of fludarabine and rituximab is prescribed for symptomatic patients. More recently, alemtuzumab has emerged as a first-line therapy for B cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.  CD52 is an antigen found on the surface of both normal and malignant lymphocytes. The exact mechanism by which alemtuzumab mediates its biological effects of lymphocyte depletion is still not clearly understood, however, it is hypothesized that it is binding to the CD52 receptor promotes antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Major side effects of alemtuzumab therapy include cytopenias, infusion reactions, and immunosuppression which predisposes patients to infection. 

Option Analysis

✅ Alemtuzumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Imatinib:
Incorrect: Imatinib is a bcr-abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It has no effect on CD52. 
❌ Hydroxyurea:
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used in the treatment of melanoma and treatment-resistant CML, it has no effect on CD52. 
❌ Gemcitabine:
Incorrect: Gemcitabine, a thymidylate synthetase inhibitor. It has no effect on CD52. 
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist which binds to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). It has no effect on CD52.

questions.text: An experiment investigates the analgesic effects of three opioids in patients with refractory pain. The drugs are A, B, and C. A graph demonstrating the study results is shown below. Drug B is most similar to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Efficacy is the maximal effect a particular medication achieves when taken at the highest tolerated dose. The plateau value represents efficacy on a dose-response curve.  

A dose-response curve shows the relationship between the concentration of medication in the body (x-axis) and the effect it produces.    

As the medication concentration increases, more receptor-drug complexes form. Eventually, all the receptors get occupied, so the curve flattens out, and the maximum response or effect (Emax) is achieved. This process is described as a graded dose-response relationship.  

Based on the maximal pharmacologic response that occurs when all receptors are occupied, agonists can be divided into partial agonists and full agonists. Partial agonists (e.g. buprenorphine) produce a lower response at full receptor occupancy than full agonists (e.g., morphine, heroin, codeine).  



Option Analysis

❌ Morphine:
Incorrect: Morphine is a full opioid receptor agonist and will have high efficacy. As a result, its effect will be most similar to that of Drug A.
✅ Buprenorphine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a full opioid receptor antagonist. It is usually used to treat acute opioid intoxication. The effects of naloxone will be most similar to those of Drug C.
❌ Codeine :
Incorrect: Codeine is a full opioid receptor agonist. Its effect will be similar to that of Drug A.
❌ Naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is a full opioid receptor antagonist and is usually used to prevent relapse in patients with a history of opioid addiction. The effects of naltrexone will be most similar to those of Drug C.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressive abdominal distention and pain over the past 2 days. He has a history of alcohol-associated cirrhosis that was diagnosed 7 years ago. A recent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan diagnosed hepatocellular carcinoma. Temperature is 37℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals a distended and tender abdomen without rebound or guarding. There is a positive fluid wave and spider angiomas are present. An ultrasound with Doppler of the abdomen shows impaired blood flow and a hyperechoic mass extending into the portal vein. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) presents with worsening abdominal distension, new-onset abdominal pain, and doppler ultrasound confirming acute portal vein thrombosis. For this patient with underlying HCC, the most appropriate treatment is chemotherapy.  

Patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) secondary to underlying hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), should be managed differently from other patients with PVT, due to the complexities introduced by the cancer itself and its associated risks. The use of anticoagulation, typically the standard of care in PVT cases, is generally avoided in HCC-related PVT due to increased bleeding risks and limited efficacy. Focus shifts toward managing the primary malignancy and alleviating symptoms with systemic chemotherapy. Sorafenib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is commonly used in the treatment of advanced HCC. It has been shown to improve survival and to manage the systemic effects of HCC. The goal of treatment is to control the progression of HCC.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chemotherapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH):
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is not indicated in acute portal vein thrombosis secondary to hepatocellular carcinoma as there is an increased risk of bleeding from the tumor and limited efficacy of anticoagulants in malignancy-related thrombotic conditions.
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy is indicated in patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) presenting with variceal hemorrhage, or for screening in patients with cirrhosis and PVT who are being started on LMWH.
❌ Surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical thrombectomy is reserved for patients who are undergoing surgery for intestinal infarction and portal vein thrombosis (PVT), where thrombectomy can be performed during the laparotomy. 
❌ Thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Systemic thrombolytic therapy is not an appropriate management option for acute portal vein thrombus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with new-onset fatigue, nausea, and vomiting for the past day. Her past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis, for which she has taken methotrexate and prednisone for many years. She is visiting from out of town and forgot to pack prednisone for the trip. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 105/74 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self and place but not time. Mild tenderness is elicited with abdominal palpation. The patient is suspected to be experiencing an acute adrenal crisis. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Corticosteroids are categorized into three main divisions: glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgenic sex hormones. Glucocorticoids are pharmacologically similar to endogenous cortisol. They are used for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. They can be administered orally, intravenously, intramuscularly, or via inhalation.    

The secretion of cortisol is regulated by the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. The hypothalamus secretes corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which acts on the pituitary to release adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH travels to the adrenal glands, which bind to ACTH on adrenocortical cells. Glucocorticoids are then released from the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland. Glucocorticoids exert a negative feedback effect on the HPA axis and decrease the release of CRH and ACTH. Chronic use of exogenous glucocorticoids exerts a similar effect on the HPA axis and thus leads to decreased ACTH levels.    

Corticosteroids should never be discontinued abruptly as this can precipitate acute adrenal insufficiency, a medical emergency. The condition can present symptoms including fatigue, anorexia, nausea and vomiting, weakness, hypotension, and circulatory collapse. Treatment includes administering intravenous fluids, glucose, electrolytes, and parenteral glucocorticoids. Full recovery of the HPA axis can take up to one year after cessation of exogenous glucocorticoid use.   

Option Analysis

❌ Decreased potassium level:
Incorrect: This patient has tertiary adrenal crisis secondary to sudden discontinuation of chronic glucocorticoid therapy. This condition affects endogenous glucocorticoid secretion by the adrenal gland but not mineralocorticoid secretion. As a result, potassium levels are likely unaffected in tertiary adrenal insufficiency.
❌ Increased aldosterone level:
Incorrect: This patient has tertiary adrenal crisis secondary to sudden discontinuation of chronic glucocorticoid therapy. This condition affects glucocorticoid secretion by the adrenal gland but not mineralocorticoid secretion. As a result, aldosterone levels will be within normal limits.
❌ Normal corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) level:
Incorrect: This patient has been on chronic exogenous glucocorticoid therapy to manage rheumatoid arthritis. The medication leads to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. As a result, this patient most likely has decreased CRH secretion.
✅ Decreased adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased endogenous cortisol level:
Incorrect: Chronic use of exogenous glucocorticoids will suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and decrease, not increase, endogenous cortisol production.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of a new facial rash. The rash worsens with sun exposure. The patient has also experienced painful oral ulcers, joint pain, and hair loss. She has no significant past medical history. Her mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Physical examination reveals a bright red butterfly-like rash on the cheeks and nose, sparing the nasolabial folds. ANA titer is 1:320. She was diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus and started on oral prednisone. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which glucocorticoids exert their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effect?

choices.text: Decreased expression of nuclear factor-kappa beta (NF-κB)

questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to manage systemic lupus erythematosus. Glucocorticoids are a class of medication often used due to their immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory properties.    

Glucocorticoids bind to cytoplasmic glucocorticoid receptors. The glucocorticoid-receptor complexes then translocate to the nucleus, where they bind to glucocorticoid response elements (GREs) on chromatin and regulate gene expression.    

Most notably, glucocorticoids inhibit the production of NF-κB, a transcription factor that assists in synthesizing pro-inflammatory cytokines (e.g., IL-2, TNF-α). Moreover, glucocorticoids suppress B- and T-cell function and induce T-cell apoptosis.     

Moreover, glucocorticoids increase insulin resistance and are diabetogenic. Patients can develop hyperglycemia since insulin is no longer as effective at causing cells to take up glucose. This medication class also triggers gluconeogenesis via lipolysis to release free fatty acids and muscle proteolysis to release free amino acids, which are then used to synthesize glucose molecules. Overall, glucocorticoids have a catabolic effect on the body.  



Option Analysis

❌ Increased T-lymphocyte production:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids induce apoptosis of lymphocytes, eosinophils, and monocytes.
❌ Decreased expression of IL-10:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids increase the expression of IL-10, which promotes the expression of anti-inflammatory genes.
✅ Decreased expression of nuclear factor-kappa beta (NF-κB):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Increased expression of phospholipase A2:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids decrease the expression of prostaglandins and leukotrienes via the inhibition of phospholipase A2.
❌ Increased activation of activating protein-1 (AP-1):
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids suppress the production of AP-1, a transcription factor that promotes the expression of pro-inflammatory genes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic because she has noticed easy bruising, amenorrhea, and lower abdominal “stretch marks” that have been present for the past six months. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis and poorly controlled ulcerative colitis. Current medications include celecoxib, methotrexate, and high-dose prednisone. She has been on moderate to high doses of steroids for over three months. Vital signs are taken by the nurse and are not yet available for review. On physical examination, supraclavicular and dorsocervical fat pads are enlarged. The abdomen is obese with violaceous striae. Which of the following combination of findings would be expected given the likely underlying diagnosis?

choices.text: Thickened skin and enlargement of muscles of the extremities
Loss of abdominal fat and hirsutism

questions.solution:
This patient who has been on chronic moderate to high-dose steroids presents with easy bruising, amenorrhea, and new violaceous striae on the abdomen. These findings are concerning for Cushing syndrome, which can be due to the use of exogenous corticosteroids. Hypertension and polyuria from hyperglycemia secondary to glucose intolerance or uncontrolled DM can be seen in patients presenting with Cushing syndrome.

Cushing syndrome results from long-term exposure to high glucocorticoid levels in the blood. This can be secondary to exogenous glucocorticoids (e.g. from chronic corticosteroid use) or endogenous glucocorticoids (e.g. from adrenal hypersecretion of corticosteroids, pituitary hypersecretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)).

Patients can present with mood changes (e.g. irritability), signs and symptoms consistent with glucose intolerance or diabetes mellitus (e.g. polyuria), hypertension, skin findings (e.g. thinning skin, violaceous abdominal striae), and body composition changes (e.g. buffalo hump, moon facies or facial plethora, central obesity, extremity wasting). An enlarged dorsocervical fat pad (also known as a “buffalo hump”), moon facies or facial plethora, and central obesity result from fat redistribution from the effects of glucocorticoids. Proximal muscle weakness and wasting of the extremities results from glucocorticoid-mediated protein degradation. High glucocorticoid levels can also suppress gonadotropin secretion, leading to decreased libido or amenorrhea.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertension and polyuria:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypotension and polyuria:
Incorrect: Patients with Cushing syndrome can present with hypertension due to cortisol’s effects on blood pressure and signs of hyperglycemia (e.g. polyuria) from the development of glucose intolerance or diabetes mellitus. Hypotension is not typically associated with Cushing syndrome.  
❌ Thickened skin and enlargement of muscles of the extremities:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome is associated with several skin findings and body composition changes, including thinning skin, proximal muscle weakness, and wasting of the extremities.  
❌ Loss of abdominal fat and hirsutism:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome can lead to hirsutism, central obesity, and extremity wasting. Abdominal fat is increased in patients with Cushing syndrome.  
❌ Hirsutism and decreased urinary frequency  :
Incorrect: Patients with Cushing syndrome typically present with findings of hypertension and  signs and symptoms of hyperglycemia from glucose intolerance or uncontrolled DM (e.g. polyuria and polydipsia). Decreased urinary frequency would not be expected.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the endocrinology clinic for suspected Cushing syndrome. Over the past year, the patient has developed thin skin, easy bruising, central obesity, and abdominal striae. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and the patient takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0ºC (98.6ºF), blood pressure is 149/92 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and pulse is 84/min. On physical examination, the patient has moon facies, central obesity, and violaceous abdominal striae. Late-night salivary cortisol and 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels are elevated. Serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the endocrinologist with signs and symptoms of Cushing syndrome. The absence of exogenous glucocorticoid use and the elevated late-night salivary and 24-hour urinary free cortisol levels support a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome secondary to an endogenous source. The low adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) level indicates ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which is caused by adrenal cortisol hypersecretion either from adrenal hyperplasia or an adrenal mass. Further adrenal imaging should be performed to confirm the underlying cause.

Cushing syndrome is a syndrome resulting from long-term exposure to high glucocorticoid levels in the blood. This can be exogenous (e.g. chronic corticosteroid use) or endogenous (e.g. adrenal hypersecretion of corticosteroids, pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH). If patients have elevated cortisol levels demonstrated on late-night salivary cortisol or 24-hour urine free cortisol testing or they have an abnormal dexamethasone suppression test, then endogenous Cushing syndrome is confirmed. ACTH levels should be checked next to determine if ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome is present.
 



Option Analysis

✅ Adrenal hyperplasia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Iatrogenic Cushing syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient is not taking exogenous glucocorticoids and, therefore, does not have an iatrogenic cause of Cushing syndrome. An endogenous source of cortisol (e.g. adrenal tumor or adrenal hyperplasia) is the more likely cause.  
❌ Small cell lung cancer:
Incorrect: Given the low ACTH, this patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome (i.e. adrenal hyperplasia). Patients with small cell lung cancer can have ectopic ACTH production, which leads to ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome with elevated ACTH levels.  
❌ Pituitary macroadenoma:
Incorrect: This patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal hyperplasia. Pituitary tumors can cause ACTH-dependent disease. Patients found to have elevated ACTH levels and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome should have a pituitary MRI and possibly inferior petrosal sinus sampling to diagnose the cause of ACTH overproduction.  
❌ Pituitary microadenoma:
Incorrect: This patient has ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal hyperplasia. Pituitary tumors can cause ACTH-dependent disease. Patients found to have elevated ACTH levels and ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome should have a pituitary MRI and possibly inferior petrosal sinus sampling to diagnose the cause of ACTH overproduction.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of a new black scab on his right arm. He initially thought it was a bug bite since it was itchy and red. However, one day later, he noticed that the area had developed an ulceration and was swollen. Several days later, the lesion had turned into a black scab. The patient works as a sheep farmer. On physical examination, there is a black eschar surrounding light red erythema on the right arm. A skin biopsy is performed, and there is suspicion of cutaneous anthrax. The patient is started on a 60-day course of ciprofloxacin. What of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this antibiotic?

choices.text: Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors
Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome
Blockade of translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cutaneous anthrax caused by the Gram-positive rod Bacillus anthracis. As a result, he was started on a 60-day course of ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone.  

The fluoroquinolone class of antibiotics includes ciprofloxacin, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin. Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and gemifloxacin are known as respiratory fluoroquinolones since they have activity against respiratory pathogens.    

Fluoroquinolones are bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. They are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.  

Fluoroquinolones are associated with several adverse effects, including gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Moreover, fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, particularly in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. Finally, fluoroquinolones can cause QT prolongation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Binding of D-ala D-ala in cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent effective in treating serious multidrug-resistant infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria. Vancomycin is associated with nephrotoxicity, ototoxicity, thrombophlebitis, red man syndrome, and DRESS syndrome. 
❌ Inhibition of the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of tetracyclines. They are used to treat infections caused by organisms such as Borrelia burgdorferi, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia species, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The most common adverse effects include gastrointestinal distress, photosensitivity, tinnitus, and hepatotoxicity.
❌ Blockade of translocation at the 50S ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of clindamycin. It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that treats anaerobic infections, such as those caused by Bacteroides species and Clostridium perfringens. Clinically, it can treat lung abscesses, aspiration pneumonia, and pseudomembranous colitis. 
❌ Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of sulfonamides (e.g., sulfamethoxazole, sulfisoxazole, sulfadiazine), which prevent folate synthesis. In contrast, fluoroquinolones work via a different mechanism of action. 
✅ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a productive cough that developed two days ago. She has had increased production of green-brown sputum and dyspnea. Past medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and iron-deficiency anemia. Current medications include metoprolol, ferrous sulfate, hydrochlorothiazide, atorvastatin, and aspirin. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 128/79 mmHg, pulse is 86/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. On physical examination, the patient has bronchial breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the area of the left lower lung. Rapid influenza testing is negative. Community-acquired pneumonia is suspected, and she is started on a seven-day course of levofloxacin. Which medications should be discontinued while the patient is taking levofloxacin?
questions.solution:
The co-administration of fluoroquinolone antibiotics and mineral supplements containing iron, zinc, calcium, magnesium, and aluminum (multivalent cations) should be avoided. This precaution should be taken since the cations can chelate the drug and inhibit its absorption from the gastrointestinal tract.  

The fluoroquinolone class of antibiotics includes ciprofloxacin, enoxaparin, norfloxacin, and ofloxacin. Levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, and gemifloxacin are known as respiratory fluoroquinolones since they have activity against respiratory pathogens. Fluoroquinolones are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.  

This medication class is associated with several adverse effects, including gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Moreover, fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, particularly in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. Finally, fluoroquinolones can cause QT prolongation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between levofloxacin and hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ). HCTZ is a sulfa derivative, so it should not be given to patients with sulfa allergies. Side effects of HCTZ include hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, and hypercalcemia. 
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between fluoroquinolones and metoprolol. Beta-blockers should not be used in patients with symptomatic bradycardia, AV block, decompensated heart failure, or asthma. Beta blockers' most common side effects include fatigue, dizziness, nausea, and constipation. 
✅ Ferrous sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between fluoroquinolones and lisinopril. Lisinopril should not be taken with aliskiren, a direct renin inhibitor. When taken together, there is a high risk of acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia. 
❌ Atorvastatin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between fluoroquinolones and atorvastatin. However, statins can cause hepatotoxicity and myopathy, particularly when given fibrates and niacin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sweating, palpitations, and chest tightness. The symptoms began two hours ago while eating dinner at home. Past medical history includes a myocardial infarction six months ago and hypertension. She underwent percutaneous coronary angioplasty six months ago. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. An esmolol infusion results in rapid symptom relief and heart rate slowing. Which of the following changes will be observed on ECG after administration of this medication?

choices.text: PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval  No effect No effectNo effect

questions.solution:
On electrocardiography, the P wave represents atrial depolarization, and the QRS complex represents ventricular depolarization (normally < 100 msec). The PR interval refers to the time from starting atrial depolarization to the onset of ventricular depolarization (typically 120-200 msec). The QT interval refers to ventricular depolarization, mechanical contraction of the ventricles, and ventricular repolarization.  

Esmolol is a beta-blocker (class II antiarrhythmic) that prevents epinephrine and norepinephrine from binding to the beta receptors, which indirectly decreases the number of open L-type calcium channels and the amount of calcium that enters at the end of phase four (in pacemaker cells). This effect decreases the slope of phase four and conduction velocity through the AV node. On ECG, this presents as a prolonged PR interval. Beta-blockers (except sotalol, which carries class III antiarrhythmic properties) do not exert specific effects on QRS or QT interval durations.



Option Analysis

❌  PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval  No effect  ↑  ↑ :
Incorrect: Class 1a antiarrhythmics (e.g., quinidine and procainamide) inhibit Na+ and K+ channels on both atrial and ventricular myocytes and cells of the Purkinje fibers. This effect decreases the amount of sodium entering the cell (slowing depolarization) and K+ leaving the cells (slowing the rate of repolarization and yielding a longer effective refractory period). Manifestations of these effects include a prolonged QRS complex and QT interval.
✅  PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval ↑No effectNo effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval  No effect No effect↑↑:
Incorrect: Class III antiarrhythmics (e.g., ibutilide, dofetilide) inhibit K+ channels leading to a slower rate of repolarization. This results in a prolonged duration of the action potential and an effective refractory period. On the ECG, this manifests as a prolonged QT interval.
❌  PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval  ↑No effect ↑ :
Incorrect: Sotalol, a class III antiarrhythmic, increases the PR interval and QT interval due to its blockade effects at both β1 adrenergic receptors and K+ channels in the heart.
❌  PR interval  QRS duration  QT interval  No effect No effectNo effect:
Incorrect: Class Ib antiarrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine and mexiletine) carry weak Na+ channel blocking effects and selectiveness for ischemic tissue. These medications do not demonstrate significant ECG changes when administered.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe substernal chest pain. The patient reports associated palpitations but no shortness of breath, cough, or fever. Past medical history includes an appendectomy two years ago. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (98.9 F), pulse is 123/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The patient appears agitated and diaphoretic. His pupils are mydriatic and nasal mucosa appears atrophic. The cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with ST elevations in leads V1-V4 and reciprocal depressions. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe sudden onset substernal chest pain and ST elevation in leads V1-V4, consistent with acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Clinical findings of mydriasis tachycardia and hypertension in combination with atrophic nasal mucosa suggest cocaine intoxication. Beta-blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction, as their use can precipitate unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, worsening coronary vasoconstriction. Other contraindications of beta blockers include:  

  •  Pheochromocytoma due to unopposed alpha agonism  
  •  Concomitant use in patients with calcium channel blockers because of their additive effect on conduction velocity through the AV node leading to the disruption of electrical impulse conduction from the atria to the ventricles. 
  •  Obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma and COPD) 
  Side effects of beta blockers can be divided into cardiac and noncardiac.  
 
  •  Cardiac: SA node depression (sinus bradycardia), heart block, vasospastic angina (propranolol), and heart failure 
  •  Extracardiac: Fatigue, sedation, dyslipidemia (metoprolol), sleep disturbance, sexual dysfunction, dyspnea, and bronchospasm  
 
Beta blockers can lead to hypoglycemia unawareness. This refers to an individual with diabetes that takes a beta blocker and develops hypoglycemia without typical hypoglycemic symptoms. This occurs since beta-blockers inhibit the effects of epinephrine (e.g., tachycardia, palpitations, tremor, and anxiety).  



Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin carries antiplatelet effects and mitigates thrombus formation. It should be administered immediately in patients with chest pain and evidence of myocardial infarction.
❌ Nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin dilates large coronary arteries and arterioles, leading to increased perfusion. It is beneficial for cocaine-induced coronary artery vasospasm.
❌ Benzodiazepine:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines reduce anxiety and agitation and improve blood pressure and heart rate. It is often indicated in the management of chest pain associated with sympathomimetic use.  
✅ Propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Like nitroglycerin, diltiazem acts as a vasodilator and is beneficial for cocaine-induced coronary artery vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man admitted to the inpatient wards presents with hematuria. He has not had dysuria, straining, polyuria, abdominal pain, or fever. His medical history includes chronic lymphocytic leukemia, for which he underwent a bone marrow transplant two weeks ago, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic back pain. Before his transplant, he was treated with an antineoplastic drug that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 145/75 mmHg. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following findings are expected on urinalysis?

choices.text: Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hematuria following initiation of a chemotherapeutic regimen suggestive of hemorrhagic cystitis secondary to cyclophosphamide use.   

Cyclophosphamide is nitrogen mustard used for conditioning before hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT). Its mechanism of action involves the creation of cross-links between interstrand guanine bases of DNA, resulting in DNA damage and impairment of replication and repair. Cyclophosphamide is associated with adverse effects, including alopecia, GI disturbances, myelosuppression, hemorrhagic cystitis, gonadal toxicity, infertility, teratogenic effects, and SIADH.  

Hemorrhagic cystitis, following the use of nitrogen mustards like cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, is an inflammatory process induced by a toxic metabolite called acrolein. The liver metabolizes Cyclophosphamide, and acrolein is formed as a metabolic product. This substance is then filtered by the kidneys and concentrated in the bladder, where it promotes production of proinflammatory cytokines, generates reactive oxygen species, and production of nitric oxide. These compounds damage the urothelium, resulting in hemorrhage and edema. Forced saline diuresis, aggressive hydration, and pretreatment with MESNA are indicated in all patients receiving cyclophosphamide.  

Option Analysis

❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent  White blood cell casts  White blood cells  :
Incorrect: WBC casts in conjunction with clinical findings of fever, dysuria, and flank pain suggest pyelonephritis. 
✅  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Erythrocytes:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  +3 Absent Fatty castsEpithelial cells with oval fat bodies:
Incorrect: Proteinuria, fatty casts, and oval fat bodies indicate a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent PresentRed blood cell castsNone:
Incorrect:  Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can result in the presence of red blood cell casts and dysmorphic red blood cells. 
❌  Protein  Dysmorphic RBCs  Casts  Cells/Crystals  Absent  Absent Absent Envelope-shaped crystals, Erythrocytes:
Incorrect:  Envelope-shaped crystals are indicative of calcium oxalate calculi.

questions.text: A 40- year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate for evaluation of  convulsions. His roommate states the patient was experiencing dizziness and was walking “funny” earlier in the day. He does not have a fever, rash, vomiting, or headache. His medical history includes allergic rhinitis, AIDS, and primary CNS lymphoma treated with methotrexate, teniposide, carmustine, prednisone, and rituximab. He last received treatment two days ago. His current medications include HAART and over-the-counter decongestants. He uses intravenous heroin and smokes cocaine occasionally. He consumes two to three beers daily; his last drink was three hours ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals needle tracks in both arms. Mucous membranes are moist. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. He appears tired and lethargic but responds to verbal commands. He moves all his extremities spontaneously, and deep tendon reflexes are symmetric. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the medication/substance responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents
Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines
Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system
Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors

questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological symptoms suggest carmustine toxicity in the setting of treatment for primary CNS lymphoma. Carmustine belongs to the class of medications called nitrosoureas that act as alkylating agents. These medications require bioactivation of cytochrome P450 enzymes in the liver, cross the blood-brain barrier and induce DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links.    

Nitrosoureas like carmustine and lomustine are potentially neurotoxic when administered in high doses and include adverse effects such as convulsions, dizziness, and ataxia.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Indirect neurotransmitter that increases the concentration of sympathomimetic agents:
Incorrect:  Amphetamines like methamphetamine act as indirect neurotransmitters by incorporating in cytoplasmic vesicles and increasing concentrations of sympathetic agents like norepinephrine and epinephrine. Methamphetamine intoxication should be considered in patients with psychomotor agitation (including seizures), diaphoresis, hypertension, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. 
❌ Agonist at mu receptors :
Incorrect: Opioids like morphine act on mu receptors distributed throughout the central and peripheral nervous system. Opioid intoxication presents with depressed mental status, respiratory drive, and miotic pupils. Opioid withdrawal can present with a dysphoric mood, diarrhea, increased lacrimation, tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension. 
❌ Inhibition of the reuptake of sympathomimetic biogenic amines :
Incorrect: Cocaine is a stimulant that increases the availability of sympathomimetic biogenic amines like dopamine, epinephrine, and norepinephrine by blocking presynaptic reuptake.  Acute cocaine intoxication can present with psychomotor agitation (seizures, coma), chest pain, and vitals reflecting hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and dilated pupils.   
✅ Cross-linking of DNA strands in the central nervous system:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Withdrawal from a CNS depressant acting on GABA receptors:
Incorrect: Alcohol withdrawal can present with withdrawal seizures typically six to forty-eight hours after drinking has ceased. Other symptoms, such as agitation and tremors, are likely. Physical findings include hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of palpitations for one day. He also had a productive cough and worsening dyspnea for the previous three days. His medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and allergic rhinitis. His medications include over-the-counter decongestants, home oxygen therapy, albuterol, ipratropium, and oral prednisone. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and SpO2 is 87%. He is alert, cooperative, and able to form complete sentences. Pulmonary examination reveals diffuse expiratory wheezing and the use of accessory muscles for respiration. Heart sounds are irregular. Chest radiography demonstrates evidence of hyperinflation and bullae. ECG is shown below. The patient is provided with noninvasive ventilation, intravenous corticosteroids, and bronchodilators. Diltiazem is added to his treatment regimen. Which of the following is the pharmacological effect of this medication?
 
Reproduced from Wikipedia Commons

choices.text: Reduction of action potential duration in ischemic ventricular tissue
Prolongation of AV nodal refractory period
Reduced chronotropy due to vagal stimulation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a symptom complex consistent with a COPD exacerbation. The ECG indicates multifocal atrial tachycardia, a common tachyarrhythmia in patients with COPD or pulmonary disease. Multifocal atrial tachycardia is characterized by an irregular R-R interval and rapid rate (>100)  with >3 different P wave morphologies. The most appropriate initial treatment for patients presenting with MAT involves addressing the underlying cause. Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem can also be added to the treatment regimen should rates remain uncontrolled.
 

Verapamil and diltiazem are dihydropyridine channel blockers that target the L-type calcium channels of the heart. Specifically, L-type channels are concentrated in the pacemaker tissues (AV and SA nodes). The primary action of these medications is to reduce the phase 4 and phase 0 depolarisation in SA nodes resulting in bradycardia.
 

These medications also prolong the effective refractory period of the AV node. As a result, AV conduction is markedly slowed, and re-entry through the AV node terminates, thus aborting the associated arrhythmia.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperpolarization reduces AV nodal conduction:
Incorrect: Adenosine slows AV nodal conduction by activating K+ channels and causing membrane hyperpolarizations through interaction with A1 GPCRs at the AV node. Verapamil prolongs the AV nodal effective refractory period and slows AV nodal conduction. It does so by blocking L-type calcium channels and delaying phase four of the pacemaker action potential.  
❌ Reduction of action potential duration in ischemic ventricular tissue:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a type Ib antiarrhythmic that reduces action potential duration in ischemic ventricular tissue by blocking inactivated sodium channels. It is relatively selective for partially depolarized ventricular cells and those with longer action potential duration. The brevity of the atrial potential may explain its inefficiency in terminating atrial arrhythmias. Verapamil or diltiazem can reduce inotropy of ventricular tissues but does not affect the action potential duration of ventricular tissue.  
❌ Suppress adrenergic mediated ectopy:
Incorrect: Class II antiarrhythmics (Beta-blockers) suppress adrenergically mediated ectopic activity. The most important action of this class of medications is to prolong the effective refractory period of the AV node (an antiadrenergic action). Verapamil or diltiazem prolongs the AV node's effective refractory period; however, it does not exhibit adrenergic blockade.  
✅ Prolongation of AV nodal refractory period:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reduced chronotropy due to vagal stimulation:
Incorrect: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside that exhibits antiarrhythmic effects via vagal nerve stimulation, thus prolonging the effective refractory period of the AV node. Verapamil and diltiazem do not exert vagomimetic properties.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of lower extremity pain and unsteadiness. The pain is severe, stabbing, and rated as 8 out of 10 in severity. These pain episodes last for minutes at a time. Past medical history is significant for Streptococcal pharyngitis, and he developed a severe allergic reaction after being administered penicillin. The patient is sexually active with men and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination reveals miotic pupils in normal and low light that do not constrict further when exposed to a bright penlight. There is no direct or consensual pupillary dilation when the penlight is removed. The pupils constrict further when the patient is asked to focus on a nearby object. Neurological examination shows decreased vibration and proprioception sense in the lower extremities, absent lower extremity deep tendon reflexes, and a positive Romberg test. The patient is offered treatment with penicillin after desensitization. However, the patient inquires about alternate treatment options. Which of the following is the most appropriate alternative treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation is consistent with tabes dorsalis and Argyll-Robertson pupils, which are seen in neurosyphilis. The first-line treatment is intravenous penicillin. Ceftriaxone can be used as an alternative treatment option in patients with penicillin allergies.

It was previously believed that patients with penicillin allergies are at increased risk for cross-sensitivity to cephalosporins. However, recent studies suggest the incidence of a cephalosporin allergy is less than 1% in patients reporting a penicillin allergy without skin testing and approximately 2% in patients with a confirmed positive penicillin skin test. As a result, cephalosporins can generally be safely administered in patients with a penicillin allergy.

Moreover, due to the structural differences from penicillin, cephalosporins are less susceptible to penicillinases produced by Staphylococcal species. Some bacteria, however, develop resistance to cephalosporins via the production of other beta-lactamases that can inactivate drug molecules. Other modes of resistance to cephalosporins include decreased membrane permeability and changes in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) structure.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vancomycin:
