Incorrect: Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that is effective against Gram-positive bacteria,  including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It is not effective in the treatment of neurosyphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.  
✅ Ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tetracycline:
Incorrect: Tetracycline is a bacterial protein synthesis inhibitor that is effective against bacteria including Borrelia burgdorferi, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia species. It is not effective against Treponema pallidum for the treatment of neurosyphilis.  
❌ Chloramphenicol:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol has been historically used in the management of meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is rarely used in the United States nowadays due to its toxicity profile; in particular its ability to cause dose-dependent aplastic anemia. Moreover, chloramphenicol is not effective in the treatment of neurosyphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin is an alternative treatment option for Streptococcal infections in patients with penicillin allergies. However, it is not effective against Treponema pallidum for the treatment of neurosyphilis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of weakness in the arms and thighs. Over the past few days, he has had difficulty raising his arms above his head. Moreover, the patient gets easily fatigued and has difficulty climbing the stairs to his apartment. He was recently treated with azithromycin for a respiratory tract infection. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed two months ago, for which metformin and atorvastatin were started. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in his father. He is trying to lose some weight, and his diet consists of green leafy vegetables, ten ounces of grapefruit juice a day, and eight ounces of milk. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s muscular weakness?  

Laboratory Value
Result
Serum Chemistry

Sodium
139 mEq/L
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L
Chloride
95 mEq/L
Creatine phosphokinase (CPK)
2800 U/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
5 mm/hr
questions.solution:
This patient has signs and symptoms of symmetric proximal myopathy (difficulty raising arms above his head and climbing the stairs) while on statin therapy. The consumption of a macrolide and grapefruit juice (cytochrome P450 inhibitors) may have potentiated the damage by preventing the metabolism of statins by liver cytochrome enzymes, ultimately causing statin-induced myopathy.

Apart from their clinical utility as a hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase inhibitor, statins also reduce the production of coenzyme Q required for muscle cell energy production. Clinically, these effects may present with symmetric proximal muscle pain (myalgia) or muscle weakness (myopathy), with or without elevated serum CPK. Other less common adverse effects include:
  
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances 
  • Rash 
  • Hepatic dysfunction: Mild elevations in hepatic aminotransferases can occur, but three-fold elevation warrants immediate discontinuation or dose reduction 
  • Teratogenicity 
Concurrent therapy with several drugs or consumption of certain food/drinks can increase the patient’s risk of developing myopathy. These include fibrates, niacin, cytochrome P-450 inhibitors (listed below), and drugs with an independent risk of developing myopathy (e.g., glucocorticoids, cyclosporine, zidovudine).
 

Option Analysis

✅ Medication toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Polymyalgia rheumatica:
Incorrect: Polymyalgia rheumatica is an inflammatory disorder that usually presents with bilateral stiffness and pain in the muscles of the shoulders and hips. Patients usually have normal muscle strength, and ESR is significantly elevated, unlike this patient.  
❌ Neuromuscular junction disorder:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction disorder with symmetric proximal muscle weakness. However, it is usually accompanied by an oculo-bulbar weakness that fluctuates and worsens later in the day. Moreover, serum CPK is usually normal.  
❌ Inflammatory myopathy:
Incorrect: Polymyositis and dermatomyositis are inflammatory myopathies that usually cause symmetric proximal muscle weakness, with or without cutaneous manifestations, respectively. Pain is mild, if present, but serum CK and ESR are significantly elevated.  
❌ Nutrient deficiency:
Incorrect: Chronic vitamin D deficiency can manifest with myopathy. However, this patient has a history of developing symmetrical proximal muscle weakness and elevated CK after starting statin therapy. These findings suggest medication toxicity, as opposed to nutrient deficiency.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 4-month history of fatigue, intermittent fevers, night sweats, a 10-lb unintentional weight loss, and pruritus. He has not had any recent infections or travel. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he currently takes no medication. Family history is significant for breast cancer in his mother. Temperature is 37.7 °C (99.9 °F), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, heart rate is 78 beats/minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination reveals lymphadenopathy in the cervical and axillary regions and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Given the most likely underlying condition, which of the following best describes the likely findings on lymph node examination?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms (fatigue, fever, night sweats, pruritus, and unintentional weight loss), coupled with the physical examination findings (lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly) are concerning for lymphoma. In patients in this age group who present with lymphadenopathy, B symptoms (fatigue, fever, night sweats, pruritus, and unintentional weight loss) and pruritus, Hodgkin lymphoma should be considered. In patients with lymphoma, examination of the lymph nodes will reveal non-tender, firm, rubbery, and immobile lymph nodes.

Lymphadenopathy is a term used to describe lymph nodes that are of abnormal size or consistency. There are many causes of lymphadenopathy, including inflammatory conditions, infections, and malignancy. The history and physical examination provide clues to help narrow the differential. Specific symptoms may point to a specific diagnosis. Additionally, whether the onset of lymphadenopathy is rapid (e.g., in infectious causes) or more indolent (e.g., malignancy) can help guide the diagnostic workup.

A thorough physical examination can also provide insight into the underlying cause. Normal lymph nodes are small, mobile, non-tender, and soft. Acute inflammatory or infectious etiologies tend to result in rapid enlargement of lymph nodes that are tender to palpation. Lymph nodes tend to be firm and rubbery in lymphoma, while infiltrative processes (e.g., metastatic disease) or fibrosis can make the nodes feel hard. When surrounding tissue is infiltrated by cancer, the nodes can become fixed to the tissues or other nodes (e.g., matting).
   

Option Analysis

✅ Nontender, firm, rubbery, and immobile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nontender, hard, matted, and immobile:
Incorrect: These descriptors are consistent with malignancy, but are more indicative of lymphadenopathy secondary to metastatic solid organ cancer. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more concerning for lymphoma where nontender, firm, rubbery, and immobile lymph nodes would be expected.  
❌ Soft, discrete, tender, and mobile:
Incorrect: These descriptors suggest a systemic inflammatory or infectious process, where lymph nodes are reactive. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more indicative of a malignant process, such as lymphoma where nontender, firm, rubbery, and immobile lymph nodes would be expected.  
❌ Warm, erythematous, tender, and mobile:
Incorrect: This choice suggests an acute infectious process, like bacterial lymphadenitis, where lymph nodes are often inflamed, tender, and warm to the touch due to the active infection and immune response. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more indicative of a malignant process, such as lymphoma where nontender, firm, rubbery, and immobile lymph nodes would be expected.  
❌ Small, soft, and mobile:
Incorrect: Lymph nodes with these descriptors are likely to be benign. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more indicative of a malignant process, such as lymphoma where nontender, firm, rubbery, and immobile lymph nodes would be expected.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a fever for the past 6 hours. He is currently undergoing chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and reports that his most recent cycle was completed 10 days ago. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), heart rate is 110/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 126/70 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor without skin lesions or erythema and evidence of mucositis. The abdomen is soft and nontender, without hepatosplenomegaly. Lung auscultation is within normal limits, and cardiac exam shows regular heart rhythm with normal heart sounds. Laboratory tests are shown below. Blood cultures are drawn. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Complete Blood Count 
 Hemoglobin   10.2 g/dL 
 White blood cells   1,000/µL 
 Platelets  100,000µL 
 Absolute neutrophil count (ANC)  300/µL 
 Neutrophils  30% 
 Lymphocytes  65% 
 Monocytes  3% 
 Eosinophils  1% 
 Basophils  1% 
 General Chemistry
 Creatinine  2.1 mg/dL

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and recent chemotherapy, presents with fever and severe neutropenia (ANC < 500/µL), indicating febrile neutropenia, which is a hematology/oncology emergency. The primary treatment is prompt empirical antibiotic therapy with broad-spectrum antibiotics like intravenous cefepime. Cefepime covers both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms and also provides coverage against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a frequent and serious pathogen in patients with febrile neutropenia.    

Cefepime, a fourth-generation cephalosporin, is favored due to its efficacy and its relatively low toxicity profile. Alternative antibiotics can include piperacillin-tazobactam or carbapenem, especially in healthcare settings with high rates of antibiotic resistance. In patients with febrile neutropenia, the risk of bacterial infection is high, and delays in antibiotic administration are associated with increased mortality. Empirical antibiotics should be initiated within one hour of presentation. The choice of antibiotic should be adjusted based on culture results, clinical response, and local antibiogram patterns. Further investigations, including blood cultures and thorough physical examinations, are essential to identify the source of infection. However, these should not delay the initiation of antibiotics. 

Option Analysis

✅ IV cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF):
Incorrect: G-CSF stimulates neutrophil production but is generally not recommended for most patients with febrile neutropenia. The first step should be initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest:
Incorrect: While imaging of the chest may be performed to rule out a pulmonary source of infection, it is not the immediate priority in the management of febrile neutropenia. The first step should be initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics to address potential life-threatening bacterial infections.
❌ Intravenous (IV) vancomycin:
Incorrect: Vancomycin, which primarily targets gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA, is not typically used as monotherapy in the initial management of febrile neutropenia, particularly when signs of skin, soft tissue, or catheter-related infection are absent. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started in cases of febrile neutropenia.
❌ Intravenous (IV) fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is used for suspected fungal infections or in cases of prolonged neutropenia. The initial treatment for febrile neutropenia is broad-spectrum antibiotics like IV cefepime.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue, fever, and frequent nosebleeds over the past month. Past medical history is significant for Hodgkin lymphoma 8 years before presentation, which was treated with radiation and a chemotherapy regimen that included doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. Family history is significant for colon cancer in his father. He lives in a residential area that is exposed to radon. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), heart rate is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals mild splenomegaly, pale mucous membranes, and scattered petechiae on the lower extremities. Bloodwork results are shown below. Blood smear shows numerous lymphoblasts. Which of the following factors in this patient’s history likely increased his risk of developing the likely underlying condition?

 Complete Blood Count
 Hemoglobin   9.2 g/dL 
 White blood cells (WBC)  60,000/µL 
 Platelets  20,000µL 
 Neutrophils  5% 
 Lymphocytes  70% 
 Monocytes  3% 
 Eosinophils  1% 
 Basophils  1% 
 Blasts  20%
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of Hodgkin lymphoma treated with radiation and a chemotherapy regimen, including doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine, presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of leukemia including persistent fatigue, fever, frequent nosebleeds, mild splenomegaly, pale mucous membranes, and petechiae. These clinical findings, combined with the laboratory abnormalities of an elevated WBC count with lymphocyte predominance and a high percentage of blasts, makes acute lymphoblastic leukemia the likely diagnosis. The most significant risk factor for the development of leukemia is that this patient has prior radiation therapy, where risk peaks 5-9 years after treatment, as well as treatment with the alkylating chemotherapy agent dacarbazine.    

The clinical presentation of leukemia encompasses a range of symptoms and signs related to both bone marrow failure and organ infiltration. Patients may experience fatigue, fever, and recurrent infections, indicative of anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, respectively, due to disrupted hematopoiesis. An important consideration, especially in adolescent patients, is that testicular enlargement or swelling can be one of the first signs of leukemia. Risk factors for leukemia include prior radiation therapy, alkylating chemotherapy agents, genetic predisposition, and environmental exposures.

Option Analysis

✅ History of radiation therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of doxorubicin therapy:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute lymphoblastic leukemia. While doxorubicin has long-term cardiotoxic effects, it is not associated with an increased risk of secondary leukemia. The risk factors for the development of therapy-related leukemia are the use of alkylating agents and radiation therapy.
❌ History of bleomycin therapy:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis, especially with high cumulative doses. However, it is not associated with the development of secondary leukemia.
❌ Family history of colon cancer:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Although a family history of colon cancer suggests a genetic predisposition to certain cancers, it does not significantly increase the risk for leukemia, especially compared to known factors like prior radiation therapy.
❌ Residential radon exposure:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Radon exposure is a recognized risk factor for lung cancer, especially in uranium miners. However, there have been no definitive studies documenting a direct association with the development of leukemia in adults with residential radon exposure.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with two days of dizziness, weakness and fatigue, and shortness of breath. Over the past week, the patient has also noticed easy bruising and bleeding while brushing her teeth. She has not had epistaxis, hematuria, hematochezia, or melena. Her past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which was treated fifteen years ago with chemotherapy and radiation. The patient does not currently take any medications. Temperature is 37.6ºC (99.7ºF), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 85/62 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 100% on room air. On physical examination, there is conjunctival pallor. There are diffuse scattered petechiae and small ecchymoses on skin examination. Chest radiograph shows no acute abnormalities. Serum complete blood count shows white blood cells 2300/mm<sup>3</sup> (50% neutrophils), hemoglobin 6.8 g/dL, and platelets 18,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Transfusion of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient who presents with dizziness, shortness of breath, weakness, fatigue, and easy bruising is found to have severe pancytopenia. Patients aged 60 and older, especially those at increased risk (i.e. prior benzene, chemotherapy, or radiation), who present with pancytopenia should be evaluated for myelodysplastic syndrome. This patient who likely has myelodysplastic syndrome and is hypotensive with a hemoglobin < 7 g/dL should have transfusion of packed red blood cells and intravenous fluids.

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) refers to a group of hematologic malignancies characterized by impaired hematopoiesis. All three cell lines (white blood cells, red blood cells, platelets) can be affected, which may manifest as abnormal morphology, abnormal function, or abnormal numbers (cytopenias). Common risk factors include environmental exposures (e.g. benzene), prior chemotherapy, and prior radiation therapy. Patients typically present with signs or symptoms of cytopenias, which may include anemia (e.g. fatigue, exertional shortness of breath), leukopenia (recurrent infections, poor wound healing), and thrombocytopenia (e.g. easy bruising, bleeding, petechiae).

When MDS is suspected, other causes of cytopenia should first be ruled out. If clinical suspicion remains high for MDS, then a peripheral blood smear and bone marrow biopsy (aspiration) should be performed. If MDS is confirmed, further cytogenetic and molecular testing should be performed to determine the best treatment. Patients presenting acutely with signs of anemia should receive transfusion of blood products if hemoglobin is < 7 g/dL. Patients should receive transfusion of platelets if the platelet count is less than 10,000/mm3 or if there are signs of active bleeding. Patients with MDS have a high risk of infection, so clinical suspicion and evaluation for infection is an important part of treatment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transfusion of packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: While a bone marrow biopsy will be necessary to evaluate the pancytopenia, acute management should come first. This patient with hypotension and a hemoglobin below 7 g/dL should receive a unit of packed red blood cells as well as intravenous fluids.  
❌ Transfusion of pooled platelets:
Incorrect: Although this patient is thrombocytopenic, transfusion of platelets is usually reserved for a platelet count less than 10,000/mm3 unless patients are actively bleeding or undergoing procedures. This patient has no signs of active bleeding.  
❌ Prophylactic ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient with pancytopenia and prior exposure to chemotherapy and radiation most likely has myelodysplastic syndrome. While myelodysplastic syndrome can increase the risk of infection, she does not have severe neutropenia warranting prophylactic antibiotics, and ceftriaxone would not be an appropriate choice for prophylactic coverage.  
❌ Intravenous vasopressors:
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive but has not yet received intravenous fluids or blood products. If she remains hypotensive after transfusion and fluid resuscitation, vasopressors would be appropriate.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with three months of fatigue and severe wrist and hand pain that started two months ago but has worsened in the past few days. She has also been experiencing hair loss and ulcers in her mouth. The patient has no known past medical history. Temperature is 37.4 ºC (99.3 ºF), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 146/91 mmHg, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there are several areas of alopecia and multiple aphthous ulcers in the mouth. The lungs are clear to auscultation, cardiac exam is within normal limits. Multiple proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are tender to palpation with evidence of effusions. Serum white blood cell count is 1,800/mm<sup>3</sup> and platelet count is 96,000/mm<sup>3</sup>. Which of the following clinical or diagnostic findings is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Arthrocentesis showing > 100,000 white blood cells/mm3 in the synovial fluid

questions.solution:
This 33-year-old woman presents with arthritis of the small joints of both hands that have been present for more than three months, along with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias. Together, these findings suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and the classic butterfly or malar rash would most likely be seen on a physical exam.

For patients presenting with subacute or chronic joint pain (≥ 6 weeks) involving multiple joints, a combination of history, physical exam, imaging findings of involved joints, and diagnostic blood work can help determine the diagnosis. In patients with active synovitis (tender, warm, swollen, erythematous joints) and elevated inflammatory markers ESR and CRP, inflammatory arthritis should be suspected. Initial blood work can include ESR, CRP, ANA (SLE and other autoimmune conditions), and rheumatoid factor (RF). Based on these results, further blood work may be needed to narrow down the diagnosis and can include anti-CCP antibody (RA), HLA B27 (ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis), anti-ds DNA and anti-smith antibodies (SLE), anti-Scl 70 (scleroderma), and anti-SSA and anti-SSB (Sjögren syndrome). The specific diagnosis will be made based on a combination of clinical findings, laboratory results, and imaging findings.

SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems in addition to the joints of the musculoskeletal system, and patients can present with a myriad of signs and symptoms reflecting the particular organs involved. Patients with inflammatory arthritis tend to have migratory symmetric polyarthritis. Most patients have skin and mucous membrane involvement at some point in their diseases. The most common skin manifestation is the classic “butterfly” rash after sun exposure, which appears as a malar rash over the cheeks and nose, but sparing the nasolabial folds.  

Option Analysis

✅ Malar rash:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Low back pain and stiffness:
Incorrect: Low back pain is associated with spondyloarthritis (e.g. ankylosing spondylitis), which typically presents as chronic low back pain and stiffness in young men with a family history of chronic back pain. This patient who presents with arthritis in multiple small joints of the hands associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Pencil-in-cup deformity on hand radiographs:
Incorrect: This deformity refers to the appearance of severe, erosive joint destruction in the DIP joints. It is a finding that can be seen in psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is typically associated with asymmetric oligoarthritis, nail deformities, dactylitis, and skin psoriasis. This patient presenting with small joint arthritis associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Arthrocentesis showing > 100,000 white blood cells/mm3 in the synovial fluid:
Incorrect: This degree of elevation of the white blood cell count in the synovial fluid is consistent with septic arthritis which typically presents as one warm, swollen, and exquisitely tender joint. This patient who presents with small joint polyarthritis associated with alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias is more likely to have SLE.  
❌ Positive anti-SSA autoantibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies are found in Sjögren syndrome. Patients with Sjogrens may have arthritis and leukopenia; however, they also typically have sicca symptoms (dry eyes, dry mouth).

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man is found unconscious in his apartment by a neighbor who calls emergency services. Upon arrival at the emergency department (ED), the patient is confused and somnolent. The patient’s full medical history is not known, but the neighbor states that the patient has a history of psychiatric illness. Temperature is 37.0 ℃ (98.6 ℉), heart rate is 116/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 98/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, dry mucous membranes and significantly decreased skin turgor are noted. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Neurologic examination is nonfocal. A urinary catheter is placed and a large amount of clear yellow urine is evacuated. Initial laboratory tests are listed below. The ED physician initiates fluid resuscitation and insulin therapy for a suspected diagnosis of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Which of the following is most likely the correct diagnosis, and based on that diagnosis, what changes should be made to the initial treatment?

 Laboratory study  Result 
 Serum sodium  154 mEq/L 
 Serum glucose  136 mg/dL 
 Serum osmolality  320 mOsm/kg 
 Serum beta-hydroxybutyrate   <0.05 mmol/L 
 Lactic acid  3.1 mmol/L 
 Urine osmolality  110 mOsm/kg

choices.text: Diabetes insipidus; fluid resuscitation is appropriate.
Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state; current management should be continued.
Psychogenic polydipsia; water restriction should be instituted.
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion; water restriction should be instituted.
Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state; insulin should be held until the sodium is corrected.

questions.solution:
Given the findings of high serum sodium and osmolality with inappropriately low urine osmolality, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is diabetes insipidus (DI). This patient also has dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor indicating hypovolemia. Although the serum glucose is elevated, it is not sufficiently high for a diagnosis of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). Despite the incorrect initial diagnosis, fluid resuscitation remains a cornerstone of managing dehydration in diabetes insipidus.  

DI is a disorder characterized by the inability to appropriately reabsorb water in the renal tubules, leading to excessive urination and thirst. It is divided into central DI, due to insufficient production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) by the brain, and nephrogenic DI, where the kidneys are unable to respond to ADH. Key laboratory findings include high serum sodium and osmolality, indicative of dehydration, alongside low urine osmolality, reflecting inappropriately dilute urine despite a free water deficit.  

Patients presenting with severe manifestations of DI should undergo an ABCDE assessment, and appropriate stabilization measures should be taken. Initial management for both types, especially in the presence of dehydration (hypovolemia with hypernatremia), focuses on fluid rehydration to correct the intravascular volume deficit. This step is crucial to restore normal osmolarity and prevent further complications associated with hypovolemia and hypernatremia. After that, the type of DI will guide treatment. Central DI is treated with desmopressin (an ADH analog) whereas management of nephrogenic DI involves addressing the underlying cause (e.g. discontinuing causative medications) and may include the use of thiazide diuretics or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diabetes insipidus; fluid resuscitation is appropriate.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state; current management should be continued.:
Incorrect: While the patient presents with elevated glucose and serum osmolality, the low urine osmolality is indicative of an inability to concentrate urine, suggesting an alternative diagnosis such as diabetes insipidus.
❌ Psychogenic polydipsia; water restriction should be instituted.:
Incorrect: Psychogenic polydipsia involves excessive water intake. The low urine osmolality in the context of high serum osmolality and sodium contradicts the expected findings in psychogenic polydipsia, where both serum osmolality and sodium would typically be lower.
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion; water restriction should be instituted.  :
Incorrect: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) would present with hyponatremia due to inappropriate water retention, not the hypernatremia observed here. Additionally, urine osmolality would typically be inappropriately high relative to serum osmolality in SIADH, which is not the case.
❌ Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state; insulin should be held until the sodium is corrected.:
Incorrect: Holding insulin based solely on the serum sodium level is not appropriate in the management of suspected hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). Insulin plays a critical role in lowering elevated glucose levels. However, this patient's presentation aligns more closely with diabetes insipidus, which should be treated with fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents for a follow-up appointment regarding management of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus diagnosed 6 months ago. He reports adhering to a low sodium and low protein diet as recommended but continues to experience significant polyuria and polydipsia. The patient’s vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. The patient expresses concern about the new plan to initiate hydrochlorothiazide, fearing it might exacerbate dehydration. What information can be provided to the patient about the mechanism of this medication in the treatment of diabetes insipidus?

choices.text: It leads to mild hypovolemia, which results in enhanced sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule.
It directly increases the renal tubules’ sensitivity to antidiuretic hormone, which allows for proper water reabsorption.
It induces mild hypovolemia, which stimulates the release of antidiuretic hormone from the pituitary gland.
It directly enhances sodium and water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.
It decreases the glomerular filtration rate to reduce urine output.

questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics block sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to mild hypovolemia which enhances proximal tubule sodium and water reabsorption, ultimately reducing urine volume in patients with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.  

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder characterized by the inability to concentrate urine, leading to excessive urination and thirst. There are two primary types: central DI, resulting from a deficiency in the production or release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) by the brain, and nephrogenic DI, where the kidneys are resistant to the action of ADH. Regardless of the type, underlying causes should be treated if possible.  

Institution of fluid and nutrition management is useful for both forms of DI. This includes a low sodium, low protein diet to reduce osmotic load. Additionally, it’s vital to maintain adequate hydration, and electrolytes and hydration status should be carefully monitored. Central DI is managed with desmopressin, a synthetic analog of ADH, which compensates for the hormone's deficiency and reduces urine output. In contrast, nephrogenic DI does not respond to desmopressin therapy. Instead, thiazide diuretics such as hydrochlorothiazide can be used. These indirectly decrease urine volume by inducing mild intravascular volume depletion and subsequent renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system activation. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are another option; these reduce prostaglandin synthesis and potentially increase responsiveness of the kidneys to ADH.  

Option Analysis

✅ It leads to mild hypovolemia, which results in enhanced sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ It directly increases the renal tubules’ sensitivity to antidiuretic hormone, which allows for proper water reabsorption.:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics do not directly affect the renal tubules' sensitivity to antidiuretic hormone. Instead, their mechanism of action in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is related to an indirect effect on sodium and water reabsorption pathways.
❌ It induces mild hypovolemia, which stimulates the release of antidiuretic hormone from the pituitary gland.:
Incorrect: While thiazide diuretics do induce a state of mild hypovolemia, their beneficial effect in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is not primarily through the stimulation of antidiuretic hormone release but through alterations in sodium and water handling in the kidneys.
❌ It directly enhances sodium and water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics do not enhance sodium and water reabsorption directly in the distal convoluted tubule in the context of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Its mechanism involves blocking sodium reabsorption, leading to downstream effects on urine volume.
❌ It decreases the glomerular filtration rate to reduce urine output.:
Incorrect: The mechanism for thiazides’ ability to reduce urine output in the context of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is not through decreasing the glomerular filtration rate. Their action is focused on blocking the absorption of sodium and water in the distal convoluted tubule, resulting in downstream effects on urine volume.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful, rapidly-spreading rash involving his trunk, extremities, and face that started 24 hours ago. The patient reports preceding symptoms of fever and malaise. He states the rash started on his face and chest yesterday and that today the rash extended to his back and all extremities; he also developed lesions in his mouth. He has a past medical history of obesity, hypertension treated with amlodipine, and gout for which allopurinol was started one month prior. The patient returned from an uncomplicated medical mission trip to South America three months ago. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 112/60 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On skin examination, the patient has extensive dusky erythema, flaccid bullae, and painful erythema of the palms and soles bilaterally. He has bilateral conjunctival erythema. Findings from the oral exam are seen below. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following most likely contributed to the development of the underlying condition?



  Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a painful rapidly-spreading rash with flaccid bullae, oral lesions, and bilateral conjunctivitis likely has Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is the recent initiation of allopurinol.  

Characteristic clinical features of SJS/TEN include prodromal flu-like symptoms (e.g. cough, sore throat, malaise, fever), followed by development of a characteristic rash. Lesions typically begin on the face and chest and are symmetrically distributed. Early lesions appear as coalescing, erythematous macules, which evolve to dusky erythema, purpuric spots, and flaccid bullae. Mucosal involvement (i.e. mouth, perineum, or eyes) is highly suggestive of the disease. The rash can progress to extensive sheet-like detachment of the skin and erosions, and positive Nikolsky sign can be seen (i.e. extension of epidermal detachment with gentle lateral pressure applied). Physical examination may also reveal findings associated with pulmonary and renal involvement.  

All patients with SJS/TEN should have a careful history performed to assess for potential causative medications as most cases are caused by medications. Medications highly associated with this disease process include anticonvulsants, sulfasalazine, sulfamethoxazole, allopurinol, certain NSAIDS, and nevirapine (which is used to treat HIV). Infections may also cause SJS/TEN. Risk factors for SJS/TEN include a history of immunodeficiency, HIV, active malignancy, and older age.   

Option Analysis

✅ Allopurinol use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amlodipine use:
Incorrect: Amlodipine is not typically associated with the development of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. 
❌ Recent travel to South America:
Incorrect: Infections can cause Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. However, the patient had no noted infections during or immediately after his trip, and his travel was months prior to the onset of symptoms.
❌ History of hypertension:
Incorrect: Hypertension is not a risk factor for the development of Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. 
❌ Age:
Incorrect: Older patients are at increased risk of developing Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic-epidermal necrolysis. This patient's age would not be a contributing risk factor.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to discuss concerns about his weight. Over the past year, the patient has unintentionally lost 15 lb. (6.8 kg). He has not started any new medication. He has no fevers, chills, night sweats, insomnia, or anhedonia. The patient has a bowel movement daily and frequently has two loose bowel movements per week. His past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease stage 1 and well-controlled major depressive disorder. Current medication includes citalopram and multivitamins. The patient lives in an apartment attached to the home of his daughter and her family, whom he sees often. Vital signs are within normal limits. His current weight is 142 lb. (64.4 kg). On physical examination, the patient has temporal wasting and poor extremity muscle mass. He has dentures in place which fall out of his mouth several times during the exam. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 0.35 µU/mL and free T4 is 1.4 ng/dL. Which of the following elements is the most probable cause of this patient’s unintentional weight loss?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with significant unintentional weight loss and is found to have poorly fitting dentures during history and physical. The rest of his history, physical examination, and evaluation does not suggest an alternate cause, making impaired caloric intake from an oropharyngeal condition the most probable cause.    

Unintentional weight loss refers to a weight loss >5% of body weight over 6-12 months in a patient not actively trying to lose weight. The differential is extremely broad. It can be due to medication side effects, socioeconomic barriers, or underlying medical conditions. Underlying medical conditions can be further broken down into increased metabolic demand, impaired caloric intake, or impaired absorption.    

For patients with unintentional weight loss history, it is often the most useful tool in making a diagnosis. A thorough medication review should be performed to assess for medication side effects that can lead to weight loss. Discussion with the patient should include an assessment of socioeconomic barriers such as isolation, functional limitations, financial barriers, and poor access to transportation. Patients should also be screened for depression and dementia in older patients. If none of these factors are present, then history and physical should focus on determining the underlying medical condition. Patients with gastrointestinal disorders may have symptoms such as abdominal discomfort, bloating, nausea, early satiety, or diarrhea. Patients should be assessed for oropharyngeal pain, dysphagia, or poorly fitting dentures in cases of impaired caloric intake. If none of these are present, then a thorough review of systems, physical examination, and laboratory work can help determine the underlying medical condition leading to increased metabolic demands.  

 



Option Analysis

✅ Poorly fitting dentures:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Loose bowel movements:
Incorrect: Significant diarrhea may be a sign of malabsorption (e.g., Celiac disease, chronic pancreatitis). This patient frequently has two loose bowel movements per week; considering otherwise normal bowel movements, the loose stool is not significant enough to represent malabsorption, leading to weight loss. 
❌ Chronic kidney disease:
Incorrect: Chronic advanced kidney disease, like other chronic and advanced medical diseases, is associated with weight loss from increased metabolic demands. However, stage 1 chronic kidney disease would not significantly contribute to weight loss. 
❌ Antidepressant use:
Incorrect: While untreated depression can lead to weight loss (or weight gain), this patient’s major depressive disorder is well-controlled. In addition, antidepressants tend to lead to weight gain and not weight loss. 
❌ Abnormal thyroid studies :
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can lead to increased metabolism and thus weight loss. This patient’s TSH is minimally decreased but serum-free T4 is normal, ruling out hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after a fall. She has not had any recent fever, joint pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain. A family member at the bedside states the patient has been depressed and more forgetful for the past several months. She has also unintentionally lost 20-lb. in the past year. The patient has no known past medical history and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0 ºC, pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/81 mmHg. Current BMI is 19 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is alert and oriented to person and place, but not to time, and has frequent difficulty with word finding and repeating words. There are no extra heart sounds on auscultation and the lungs sound clear on both sides. There is mild epigastric tenderness to palpation. There is asymmetric joint hypertrophy at the distal joints in both hands with minimal tenderness. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s weight loss?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with unintentional weight loss, forgetfulness, impaired orientation, and a depressed mood. With an otherwise unremarkable physical examination, these findings together suggest a neuropsychiatric condition (e.g., cognitive impairment or dementia) as the cause of her unintentional weight loss.   

Unintentional weight loss refers to a weight loss >5% of body weight over 6-12 months in a patient not actively trying to lose weight. The differential is overly broad and can be due to medication side effects, socioeconomic barriers, or underlying medical conditions. Underlying medical conditions can be further broken down into increased metabolic demand, impaired caloric intake, or impaired absorption.    For patients with unintentional weight loss, a thorough medication review and assessment for socioeconomic barriers are imperative. If an underlying medical condition is suspected, then the history, physical, review of systems, and laboratory/imaging studies can help determine the underlying cause.   

Patients with neuropsychiatric conditions can also develop unintentional weight loss. All patients should be screened for depression (generally with a PHQ-2, patient health questionnaire form) if they present with any concerning symptoms such as depressed mood, fatigue, and anhedonia. Older patients should be screened for dementia with a mini-mental status exam. They may present with confusion, memory loss, or mood changes, and physical examination may show aphasia or apraxia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Neuropsychiatric condition:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Upper gastrointestinal tract condition:
Incorrect: While this patient does not have an obvious reason for the mild epigastric discomfort, the lack of any other gastrointestinal symptoms makes this unlikely to be a significant cause of weight loss. A gastrointestinal cause of weight loss should be suspected in patients with early satiety, vomiting, dysphagia, or other symptoms. 
❌ Autoimmune condition:
Incorrect: Autoimmune diseases can lead to a hyperinflammatory state and increased metabolic demands, leading to weight loss. This patient’s hand arthritis is likely due to osteoarthritis, and she has no fever or rash to suggest an autoimmune condition. 
❌ Chronic cardiopulmonary disease:
Incorrect: Chronic advanced cardiopulmonary disease leads to unintentional weight loss due to increased metabolic demand. This patient has no past medical history and has a normal cardiopulmonary exam and no peripheral edema, which makes cardiopulmonary disease an unlikely cause of her weight loss. 
❌ Gastrointestinal malabsorption:
Incorrect: Malabsorption can lead to significant weight loss. However, this patient has no nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, to suggest malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by ambulance after being found confused at home. The patient is unable to provide a reliable history. Per the neighbor who found the patient and called an ambulance, the patient has had nausea and vomiting on and off for the past several days and has not eaten during this time. Emergency medical services brought the patient’s prescription medication bottles to the ED, which include aspirin, ethambutol, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and rifampin. Temperature is 36.8 ºC (98.2 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is confused and oriented only to person. Mucous membranes are dry. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Arterial blood gas and serum bloodwork are obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
 Serum Laboratory Test     Result   
 Arterial pH     7.28    
 Arterial pCO2     35 mm Hg    
 Sodium     133 mEq/L    
 Chloride     98 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     15 mEq/L    
 Glucose     180 mg/dL    
 Beta-hydroxybutyrate     0.9 mmol/L (nml 0.5 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
This 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion after several days of nausea, vomiting, and poor oral intake. Given that this patient has been prescribed isoniazid (for tuberculosis treatment or prophylaxis) and has an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis, the most likely diagnosis isoniazid toxicity. Pyridoxine is a cornerstone in the treatment of isoniazid toxicity.

There are several causes of an elevated (or high) anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is defined as an anion gap > 12. HAGMA is due to unmeasured acids, so toxic ingestions, poor clearance of acids, and systemic causes of acid buildup may be the cause. Common toxic ingestions include ethylene glycol, methanol, isoniazid, iron, or salicylates. Lactic acidosis (often from sepsis or tissue bowel ischemia) and ketone production (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis) lead to an increase in acids. Additionally, severe acute kidney injury can lead to poor clearance of organic acids.   

Option Analysis

✅ Isoniazid toxicity:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Type 2 renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Type 2 renal tubular acidosis leads to hypokalemia and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has an elevated anion gap. 
❌ Type 4 renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Type 4 renal tubular acidosis leads to hyperkalemia (due to hypoaldosteronism) and a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has an elevated anion gap. 
❌ Salicylate toxicity:
Incorrect: Salicylate toxicity leads to respiratory alkalosis and typically, during later stages, an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis may be present. It can also cause hypotension. This patient’s acute acid-base status, as well as recent nausea, vomiting, and altered mentation, make isoniazid toxicity more likely. 
❌ Diabetic ketoacidosis:
Incorrect: This patient has mild hyperglycemia with only a small elevation in serum ketones. As this patient has not eaten for several days, this is more likely due to starvation ketosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. The patient has not seen a physician in over 10 years. She has no known medical conditions and does not currently take prescription medication. Surgical history includes laparoscopic appendectomy at the age of 20. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs, and she works as a veterinarian. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 66/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 144/92 mm Hg. BMI is 33 kg/m2. A thorough history and physical exam are performed. Bloodwork is obtained during this visit and shows a normal complete blood count and a serum bicarbonate of 30 mEq/L. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present given the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Family history of renal tubular acidosis type 4

questions.solution:
This young patient presents with hypertension, an elevated BMI, and an elevated serum bicarbonate (metabolic alkalosis), raising concern for Cushing syndrome. Signs of Cushing syndrome on physical exam include the presence of a buffalo hump, central obesity with extremity wasting, and violaceous abdominal striae.    

In patients with metabolic alkalosis, history should focus on determining potential causes like gastrointestinal losses, such as vomiting (from gastrointestinal illnesses or bulimia nervosa); chronic diarrhea (especially from laxative abuse); and renal losses. Patients with a suspected eating disorder should be asked about laxative and diuretic abuse. Patients with metabolic alkalosis should be asked about a family history of cystic fibrosis, Bartter syndrome, and Gitelman syndrome. New onset hypertension and body habitus changes could indicate Cushing syndrome. Patients with recent and/or severe blood pressure changes could have a renin-secreting tumor or renal artery stenosis. Exogenous causes of metabolic alkalosis include milk-alkali syndrome and patients should be asked about calcium supplementation and antacid use.    

The physical examination in patients with metabolic alkalosis should focus on volume status, as hypovolemia can often coexist with metabolic alkalosis. Patients with an eating disorder may have dental erosions or abrasions on the dorsum of the hand(s). Patients with cystic fibrosis can have classic findings, such as wheezing and digital clubbing. Patients with Cushing syndrome may have characteristic findings as seen in the illustration below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Buffalo hump:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent-onset diarrhea:
Incorrect: Chronic diarrhea may lead to a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, or metabolic alkalosis in the case of laxative abuse. Recent-onset diarrhea is more likely to cause metabolic acidosis due to loss of bicarbonate in the stool. 
❌ Family history of renal tubular acidosis type 4:
Incorrect: Type 4 renal tubular acidosis leads to a non-anion gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis. It would not cause a metabolic alkalosis which is seen in this patient. 
❌ Over-the-counter salicylate use:
Incorrect: Salicylate toxicity can lead to respiratory alkalosis and potentially high anion gap metabolic acidosis. It would not cause a metabolic alkalosis as seen in this patient. 
❌ Severely elevated blood glucose level:
Incorrect: Severely elevated blood glucose levels may be seen with diabetic ketoacidosis which causes an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis and not metabolic alkalosis as seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of intermittent episodes of loss of vision in her right eye that she describes as episodes of complete blackness that last several minutes and then resolve spontaneously. She has also been experiencing frequent dizziness over the past month. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she does not take any daily medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Extraocular muscles are intact, and a full ophthalmologic exam is pending. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are within normal limits. Splenomegaly is present on abdominal examination. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following additional findings is most likely present given the likely underlying condition? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     12.6 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     37 %    
 Platelet count     1,150,000/mm3

choices.text: Burning pain in the hands and feet

questions.solution:
The patient's episodes of temporary vision loss are consistent with amaurosis fugax, suggesting occlusion of the retinal artery. Given low hemoglobin and significantly elevated platelet count, essential thrombocythemia (ET) is the most likely diagnosis. Patients with ET can present with burning pain in the feet and hands that can be associated with erythema and warmth (erythromelalgia).      

ET is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by an elevated platelet count, which can lead to both thrombosis and bleeding complications. Patients can present with headaches, dizziness, vision loss, and burning pain in the feet and hands, associated with erythema and warmth (erythromelalgia). Additionally, they can present with signs and symptoms secondary to hemorrhage or thrombosis.       

Polycythemia vera (PV) and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) are other myeloproliferative neoplasms with distinct clinical presentations. In PV, symptoms arise from increased blood viscosity due to elevated red blood cell mass, leading to headaches, dizziness, and a ruddy complexion. Patients often experience pruritus, especially after warm baths or showers, as well as erythromelalgia. Gastrointestinal symptoms and thrombotic events are common. CML, characterized by the Philadelphia chromosome and uncontrolled proliferation of predominantly myeloid cells, presents with fatigue, night sweats, and unexplained weight loss. Splenomegaly is frequently observed, contributing to abdominal discomfort and early satiety. Unlike PV and ET, symptoms of CML are mostly attributable to leukocytosis and chronic inflammation.   

Option Analysis

❌ White blood cell (WBC) count of 100,000 mm3:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with essential thrombocythemia (ET), which typically presents with normal or mild-moderately elevated WBC counts. Patients with chronic myeloid leukemia present with a significantly elevated WBC count that can be as high as 100,000 mm3  
✅ Burning pain in the hands and feet:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Frequent infections :
Incorrect: Low white blood cell counts and frequent associated infections are more often seen with infiltrative diseases. Patients with chronic myeloid leukemia may also present with frequent infections. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with essential thrombocythemia (ET). 
❌ Severe bone pain:
Incorrect: Bone pain is more characteristic of primary myelofibrosis or infiltrative bone marrow diseases. It is not a common symptom of essential thrombocythemia, which primarily affects platelet count and function.
❌ Neutropenia:
Incorrect: Patients with acute myelocytic leukemia can present with neutropenia, however patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET) typically present with normal or mild to moderately elevated WBC counts.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 3-month history of fatigue, 10-lb weight loss, and night sweats. He reports a feeling of fullness in his left abdomen, which he notes has become more prominent. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 124/77 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The spleen tip is palpable on abdominal examination. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following additional tests should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis?  

 Test     Result    
 Leukocytes     39,180 mm3   
 Hemoglobin     13.0 g/dL   
 Hematocrit     40.%   
 Platelets     216,000 /mm³   
 Differential         
 Neutrophils     67%   
 Bands     9%   
 Lymphocytes     7%   
 Monocytes     2%   
 Eosinophils     3%   
 Basophils     4%   
 Metamyelocytes     3%   
 Myelocytes     5%
questions.solution:
Patients with significant leukocytosis and other findings consistent with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) such as fatigue, weight loss, abdominal fullness, and splenomegaly as seen in this patient, should have a peripheral smear performed followed by bone marrow biopsy with genetic testing. The definitive diagnostic test for CML is the identification of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome), as this mutation is responsible for the pathogenesis of the disease.       

CML is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of granulocytes. Markedly elevated leukocytosis, accompanied by the presence of immature granulocytes such as myelocytes and promyelocytes strongly suggests CML. The presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene is indicative of the presence of the Philadelphia (Ph) chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t(9;22). This translocation leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, which encodes a fusion protein that acts as an abnormal tyrosine kinase driving uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ Erythropoietin level:
Incorrect: Erythropoietin (EPO) level testing is used in the evaluation of polycythemia to differentiate between primary polycythemia vera and secondary causes of erythrocytosis; it is not part of the diagnostic testing for chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). 
✅  BCR-ABL1 genetic testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CALR mutation testing:
Incorrect: Philadelphia-negative myeloproliferative neoplasms (essential thrombocytosis, polycythemia vera, primary myelofibrosis) can be associated with JAK2 V617F, CALR, or MPL mutations, which can result in uncontrolled myeloid cell division and proliferation. 
❌ JAK2 mutation testing:
Incorrect: Philadelphia-negative myeloproliferative neoplasms (essential thrombocytosis, polycythemia vera, primary myelofibrosis) can be associated with JAK2 V617F, CALR, or MPL mutations, which can result in uncontrolled myeloid cell division and proliferation. Diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is confirmed by the presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome). 
❌ Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):
Incorrect: Elevated LDH levels can indicate tissue breakdown and are seen in a variety of conditions, including certain cancers and hemolytic anemias, but they are nonspecific and can be elevated in many conditions with increased cell turnover and damage.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to an addiction medicine physician to establish care after referral by his primary care physician. The patient reports that he has been using oxycodone daily due to persistent cravings and has been requiring a higher dosage to achieve the same effects. The patient uses it daily before driving to work. On several occasions, he has missed work because of falling asleep at home, and he has missed multiple important work deadlines. The patient reports that the few times he temporarily ran out of opioids, he developed abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and vomiting before he could procure them again. He does not currently have nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is oriented and able to answer all questions appropriately. Pupils are equally round and reactive. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several clinical features consistent with opioid use disorder. Using the DSM-V criteria, he has 5 of the 11 symptoms including: cravings, recurrent opioid use resulting in failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, recurrent opioid use in situations in which it is physically hazardous, tolerance, and withdrawal. He can be diagnosed with moderate opioid use disorder.        

Opioid use disorder is a medical condition characterized by the inability to control the use of opioids, despite adverse health and social consequences. Opioids comprise a wide array of medications ranging from medically prescribed analgesia to illegal substances such as heroin.        

Diagnosis of opioid use disorder is based upon guidelines outlined in the DSM-V. There are eleven criteria as detailed in the chart below, and patients must meet at least two criteria to be formally diagnosed with this condition. Patients with 2-3 symptoms have mild opioid use disorder, those with 4-5 symptoms have moderate use disorder, and patients with 6 or more symptoms have severe use disorder. Opioid use severity assessment is an important tool for clinicians, as it can help guide treatment.        

Regional poison control centers in the United States are available around the clock for consultation on patients with known or suspected poisoning, and those who may be critically ill, require admission, or have clinical pictures that are unclear (1-800-222-1222).  



Option Analysis

✅ Moderate opiate use disorder:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mild opiate use disorder:
Incorrect: Mild opiate use disorder is characterized by the presence of 2-3 criteria out of the eleven criteria listed in the DSM-V. This patient meets 5 criteria and can be diagnosed with moderate opioid use disorder. 
❌ Severe opiate use disorder:
Incorrect: Severe opiate use disorder is characterized by the presence of 6 or more of the eleven symptoms listed as criteria in the DSM-V. This patient has 5 symptoms and can be diagnosed with moderate opioid use disorder. 
❌ Opioid withdrawal:
Incorrect: Symptoms of opioid withdrawal include anxiety, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. This patient has none of these symptoms. 
❌ Acute opioid intoxication:
Incorrect: Patients who are acutely intoxicated may appear sedated with slurred speech and pinpoint pupils. This patient does not exhibit these findings.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of two days of left upper leg swelling, warmth, and erythema. He has not had any recent surgeries or recent travel and has no personal or family history of thrombophilia. On review of symptoms, he states that for the past six weeks, he has had low grade fevers, chills, and a new cough. He states that he has not seen a doctor in 15 years. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. The patient smokes two packs of cigarettes a day and has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The left leg is swollen with nonpitting edema and erythema from the calf to the mid-thigh. Duplex ultrasonography demonstrates incompressible popliteal and femoral veins. The patient is started on anticoagulation. Which of the following tests should be performed to further evaluate the recent history of fevers?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with unilateral swelling and erythema is found to have a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Review of systems reveals a six-week history of low grade fevers, chills, and cough. Given this patient’s significant smoking history, there should be a strong suspicion for an underlying malignancy as the cause of the DVT and fever, chills, and cough. This patient should undergo chest imaging with CT of the chest.

Venous thromboembolism and malignancy can both cause fevers in adults; however, in this patient with two days of lower extremity signs and symptoms but six weeks of fevers, chills, and cough, lung cancer is the most likely cause of his fever. Patients who present with an unprovoked venous thromboembolism (VTE) without clear risk factors, such as recent surgery, immobilization, or a known clotting disorder, should be evaluated for underlying malignancy. Cancer can increase the risk of clot formation through various mechanisms, including the production of procoagulant substances, direct vessel wall invasion, and external compression of blood vessels thereby promoting stasis.    

Option Analysis

❌ CT scan of abdomen:
Incorrect: While a CT scan of the abdomen can be useful in identifying abdominal pathologies, including certain cancers, it is not the first-line test for a patient who is newly diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with a significant smoking history, recent fevers, and a new cough. Lung cancer should be ruled out with chest CT. 
✅ Chest CT:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Factor V leiden mutation testing:
Incorrect: Testing for the Factor V Leiden mutation is appropriate in patients who present with a DVT and have a personal or family history of clotting disorders. In this patient, without prior history of VTEs, a malignancy workup should be performed, starting with chest imaging given his significant smoking history and new cough for six weeks. 
❌ Protein C and S testing:
Incorrect: Like Factor V Leiden testing, Protein C and S testing is indicated in patients with DVTs who are suspected of having hereditary thrombophilia. Given this patient’s age, smoking history, and recent history of fevers and new cough, lung cancer is most likely. 
❌ Serum lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: Elevated lactate dehydrogenase can be a marker of tissue breakdown, including from certain cancers, but it is nonspecific and not a first-line test for evaluating a patient with a new DVT, fevers, cough, and significant smoking history. Underlying lung cancer is the most likely cause of the DVT, fever, and cough in this patient and should be evaluated with a CT of the chest.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to a primary care clinic to establish care. She states that she is in good health, and she only takes a multivitamin daily. She mentions that she received her last Tdap booster five years ago and has had annual influenza vaccinations, with the most recent dose administered in the past fall. She completed her COVID-19 vaccination series and received a booster dose. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago, which was normal. There is no family history of malignancy. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 21 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate screening for this patient?

choices.text: Screening for problematic use of alcohol

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old woman presents for a general health visit, and she has no significant past medical history or family history and no current health issues or symptoms. In this patient, it is appropriate to screen for problematic use of alcohol as part of a comprehensive preventive health approach. The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening adults aged 18 years or older for alcohol misuse and providing patients engaged in risky or hazardous drinking with brief behavioral counseling to reduce alcohol misuse.

Patients can be assessed for problematic use of alcohol by using a screening test, such as the CAGE or AUDIT. CAGE is a screening test that asks about the patient’s ability to Cut down their alcohol use, Annoyance regarding other people’s concern about their alcohol use, presence of Guilty feelings related to alcohol use, and use of Eye-openers. The Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test or AUDIT is a screening test that asks patients about the volume and frequency of alcohol use; changes in behavior due to drinking; feelings of regret and guilt; injury to self or others due to alcohol use; history of blackouts; need for an eye-opener or drink first thing in the morning; and concern from others about the patient’s alcohol use. If a patient has a score of ≥ 2 on the CAGE, or ≥ 8 on the AUDIT, alcohol use disorder (AUD) should be suspected.

However, with these screening tools, patients often underreport their alcohol use, potentially due to embarrassment or lack of insight into the severity of their condition. Signs of alcohol misuse include sleep disturbances like insomnia and interpersonal difficulties in relationships and work environments.  Patients with alcohol use disorder may have a history of mood or personality disorders, such as depression or borderline personality disorder, or past childhood trauma. Family history may include alcohol or other substance use disorders which can increase the risk for AUD. During the physical examination, signs that might suggest chronic alcohol use include hypertension, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Additionally, indicators of advanced liver disease such as jaundice, palmar erythema, spider angiomata, or ascites might be present, although some patients may have a normal physical examination.       

Option Analysis

❌ Diabetes mellitus blood testing:
Incorrect: There is no indication from the patient's history or presentation that she has risk factors for diabetes mellitus such as obesity, hypertension, high cholesterol, or a family history of diabetes that would necessitate screening at this time. 
❌ Pap smear:
Incorrect: According to the current guidelines, a Pap smear is recommended every three years for women aged 21 to 65 if they have a history of normal screenings. Since her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and was normal, she is not due for another Pap smear at this visit. 
❌ Thyroid dysfunction blood testing:
Incorrect: Screening for thyroid dysfunction is not routinely recommended in asymptomatic adults without risk factors or clinical indications, neither of which are present in this patient. 
✅ Screening for problematic use of alcohol :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Mammography:
Incorrect: Mammography is recommended for women starting at age 40 unless there are risk factors such as a family history of breast cancer. This patient is not at increased risk; therefore, a mammogram is not indicated until she is 40 years old.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a headache and vomiting which started 2 hours ago. The headache is pulsating and worse with physical activity. Noises sound louder than usual and make the headache worse. She has vomited twice since the onset of the headache. She has had six similar episodes in the last year, usually around the onset of her menstrual period. The patient has no chronic medical conditions and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mmHg. On examination, the patient appears to be in pain. There is no abdominal tenderness. Cranial nerves II-XII are grossly intact and the rest of the neurologic exam is nonfocal. Which of the following sets of additional findings would most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent episodes of vomiting, phonophobia, and headache that typically occur around her menstrual cycle, likely has migraine headaches. Migraine can be diagnosed clinically when patients have recurrent headaches with classic migraine features that may include unilateral location of the pain, photophobia, and aura symptoms such as visual changes.

The diagnostic workup in patients with chronic vomiting varies depending on the most likely underlying cause of the symptoms. The first step in evaluating patients with chronic vomiting is to determine whether it is likely from an abdominal or non-abdominal cause. Patients who do not have bowel changes, abdominal pain, or abdominal tenderness with their vomiting are likely to have a non-abdominal cause, such as a neurologic condition, adrenal insufficiency, or renal failure. Symptoms that indicate a possible neurologic cause include headaches, which are seen with increased intracranial pressure and migraine, as well as dizziness which is suggestive of a vestibular cause. Brain imaging should be considered when a neurologic condition is suspected that cannot be confirmed clinically, or when red flag symptoms are present.
   

Option Analysis

✅  Unilateral headache     Photophobia     Visual changes    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Thunderclap headache     Hyponatremia     Orthostatic hypotension    :
Incorrect: A thunderclap headache is concerning for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, whereas this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with migraine. Hyponatremia and orthostatic hypotension can be seen with adrenal insufficiency but are not typically seen with migraine headaches.  
❌  Previous headaches lasting 7 days     Positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver     Generalized headache    :
Incorrect: This patient has historical and clinical findings that are consistent with a migraine headache; migraines typically last 4 to 72 hours and are unilateral. A positive Dix-Hallpike would suggest benign paroxysmal positional vertigo or other vestibular cause of vomiting. 
❌  Weight loss     Hyperpigmented skin     Papilledema    :
Incorrect: Weight loss and hyperpigmentation of the skin can be seen in adrenal insufficiency; this patient’s vomiting is likely caused by migraine headaches.  Papilledema is seen with increased intracranial pressure, which is not likely the cause of vomiting and headaches in this patient. 
❌  Electrolyte disturbances     Peripheral edema     Muscle cramps    :
Incorrect: Electrolyte disturbances, peripheral edema, and muscle cramps can be seen in patients with renal failure which may lead to vomiting; however, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with migraine headaches.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because he has been having intermittent vomiting and abdominal pain. This has occurred occasionally over the past three years but has been occurring more frequently for the past few months. Abdominal pain occurs after eating and is located in the upper abdomen with radiation to the back. The patient’s stools seem to be “greasy” and are difficult to flush. He has no melena or hematochezia. He drinks three glasses of whiskey every evening and six beers per day. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 142/92 mmHg. On physical examination, there is mild epigastric tenderness to palpation. Laboratory studies show serum C-reactive protein of 0.2 mg/dL, serum lipase of 138 U/L, and fecal elastase of 152 µg/g (normal = >200 µg/g). Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol

questions.solution:
This patient’s recurrent episodes of vomiting and radiating abdominal pain, associated with steatorrhea and low fecal elastase, are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis.

Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography should be performed to evaluate for chronic pancreatitis. Excessive alcohol use and smoking are both risk factors for this condition.

When formulating a differential diagnosis for patients with chronic vomiting, it is helpful to determine if the cause is abdominal or non-abdominal.  In patients with a likely abdominal cause, the location and nature of abdominal pain, description of bowel movements, timing of symptoms concerning meals, physical examination findings, and risk factors can all help further narrow the differential. Laboratory studies such as complete blood count, inflammatory markers, pancreatic enzymes, and stool studies can be performed. Cross-sectional imaging or direct endoscopic visualization may be required depending on the most likely etiology. 

Chronic pancreatitis typically causes long-standing episodic or persistent epigastric abdominal pain, often with radiation to the back. Steatorrhea and epigastric tenderness are common. Risk factors include excessive alcohol consumption, smoking, hypertriglyceridemia, autoimmune conditions, genetic conditions, and direct insult to the pancreas either through injury or infection. Amylase and lipase may be elevated early in the course of the disease but may be normal or low later. Fecal elastase less than or equal to 200 µg/g is suggestive of chronic pancreatitis and should prompt further investigation with CT or MRI.    

Option Analysis

✅ Computed tomography of the abdomen with pancreatic protocol:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) :
Incorrect: An EGD helps evaluate conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease, peptic ulcer disease, gastroparesis, and other disorders of the esophagus and stomach lining.  This patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis for which CT is indicated.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy helps evaluate conditions such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Patients with IBD may also have low fecal elastase, however, typically inflammatory markers will be elevated. This patient’s history and findings are more consistent with chronic pancreatitis.  
❌ Endoscopic ultrasound:
Incorrect: Endoscopic ultrasound is a useful test for evaluating the pancreas and can be utilized in patients with suspected chronic pancreatitis with equivocal CT or MRI imaging. This patient has not yet had initial imaging with CT of the abdomen.  
❌ Gastric emptying study:
Incorrect: A gastric emptying study is useful in cases of suspected gastroparesis. This patient’s clinical symptoms of radiating epigastric pain and steatorrhea along with his physical exam and low fecal elastase are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of early satiety and bloating for the past several weeks. He also reports sporadic bouts of hematemesis. He reports that over this same period, he has lost 11-lb due to decreased appetite. The patient has no significant past medical history. CT shows a 2 X 2 cm mass in the antrum of the stomach. Upper endoscopy is performed, and a mass is visualized in the stomach. An excisional biopsy was taken. On pathology, the patient is found to have a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).
