Molecular pathology reveals a mutation in KIT. Which of the following is the best therapeutic intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, who presented with symptoms of early satiety, bloating, and weight loss, was found to have a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) with a KIT mutation. The ideal therapy for this patient would be to target this mutation selectively. Only imatinib, a small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitor, does this of the listed answer choices.

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor commonly used for chronic myelogenous leukemia, acute lymphocytic leukemia, and some types of GISTs. Imatinib functions by inhibiting the kinase domain of the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase. Tyrosine kinases are enzymes responsible for signal transduction cascades responsible for cell proliferation. Inhibition of tyrosine kinases selectively inhibits the proliferation of cancers that overexpress them. The KIT kinase is structurally similar to the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase. This prompted a clinical trial immediately to investigate the use of imatinib in the treatment of KIT tumors, such as GISTs. Now, using imatinib is established as first-line therapy in treating metastatic GIST. A common side effect of imatinib therapy is fluid retention, hepatotoxicity, and Stevens-Johnson Syndrome. Other tyrosine kinase inhibitors targeting BCR-ABL include nilotinib, bosutinib, ponatinib, and afatinib, which are marketed as second-line therapeutic agents.    

Option Analysis

❌ Cetuximab :
Incorrect: Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody targeting EGFR. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
❌ Bevacizumab :
Incorrect: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting VEGF-A. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
✅ Imatinib :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Alemtuzumab :
Incorrect: Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting CD52. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.  
❌ Hydroxyurea :
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used to treat melanoma and treatment-resistant CML. It has no relevance for KIT mutations.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to her physician after being diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma. She is being treated with rituximab. Based on its naming convention, what kind of monoclonal antibody is rituximab?
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibodies are a collection of relatively new classes of therapeutic biologic agents. As the name suggests, monoclonal antibodies are antibodies created from a single parent cell exogenously. They bind to specific protein targets on the extracellular cell membrane of tumors or virus-ridden cells. The parent cell where the antibody was created may vary, with some being created in different mammalian cells such as hamsters, primates, mice, etc. Furthermore, antibodies can be chimeric, fuzing variable regions from one species like a mouse, with another such as humans. While the suffix of all monoclonal antibodies ends with “-mab”, substems precede the suffix that describes the origin of the drug (see table below). In the case of rituximab, the “xi” substem shows that this agent is a chimeric monoclonal antibody.  

Option Analysis

❌ Primate :
Incorrect: Primate monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-i-.” 
❌ Mouse :
Incorrect: Mouse monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-o-.”  
❌ Hamster :
Incorrect: Hamster monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-e-.” 
❌ Humanized :
Incorrect: Humanized monoclonal antibodies have the substem “-zu.” 
✅ Chimeric  :
Correct: see main explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the oncology clinic for a follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma two years ago and completed treatment. Repeat imaging last month showed concerns for disease relapse, and a lymph node biopsy last week confirmed the recurrence of Hodgkin lymphoma. The patient has no significant medical history other than lymphoma and does not take any medications. After a discussion with the oncologist, the decision is made to start nivolumab; which of the following is the mechanism of action of this medication?

choices.text: Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4)
Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases

questions.solution:
This patient is now presenting with relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma. In recent years, programmed death-1 receptors (PD-1) inhibitors, such as nivolumab, have been approved to treat relapsed Hodgkin lymphoma. PD-1 inhibitors are also used in many other malignancies, including non-small cell lung cancer and metastatic melanoma. 

PD-1 is an immune checkpoint receptor expressed on T-cells. Certain malignancies can express PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds PD-1 and inactivates T-cells, effectively avoiding destruction by the immune system. PD-1 inhibitors (e.g. nivolumab, pembrolizumab) bind this receptor and prevent the PDL1 of cancer cells from binding PD-1 and downregulating that immune cell, allowing the immune system to attack malignant cells.

An important difference is that PD-1 inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab, pembrolizumab) bind to the PD-1 receptors on T cells, which prevents them from binding to the PDL1 ligand found on tumor cells. In contrast, PDL1 inhibitors (e.g., atezolizumab, durvalumab, avelumab) bind to the PDL1 ligand found on tumor cells to prevent them from binding to the PD-1 receptor found on T cells. This is illustrated in the diagram below. 

Since PD-1 (and PDL1) inhibitors disrupt normal immune system regulation, side effects similar to autoimmune phenomena can occur. Common side effects include colitis, thyroiditis (often manifesting as hypothyroidism), and skin rash.   

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein-4 (CTLA-4) :
Incorrect: CTLA-4 inhibitors (e.g. ipilimumab) block CTLA-4, which normally downregulates the immune response. These can allow the immune system to attack malignant cells. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA repair by topoisomerases :
Incorrect: Topoisomerase inhibitors prevent DNA repair by binding to topoisomerase enzymes.  Examples include etoposide and irinotecan. 
❌ Intercalation of DNA strands :
Incorrect: Medications such as doxorubicin can insert between DNA strands, preventing DNA replication. 
❌ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) ligand :
Incorrect: Some cancer cells express the PD-1 ligand (PDL1), which binds to the PD-1 receptor on T-cells, evading destruction by T-cells. Atezolizumab is a common inhibitor of the PD-1 ligand. 
✅ Inhibition of programmed death-1 (PD-1) receptor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of white spots on her tongue. The patient first noticed them about a week ago. The patient does not have pain or difficulty swallowing. Past medical history is significant for asthma and hepatitis C. The patient went to the doctor one month ago for the first time in over five years. At that time, the primary care physician prescribed sofosbuvir, an albuterol inhaler, and daily inhaled fluticasone. The patient is sexually active with one male partner; her last HIV test was negative, and she does not have a history of sexually transmitted infections. The patient has been smoking a pack of cigarettes a day since the age of 16. The patient does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows white mucosal plaques on the oral mucosa and tongue that are easily scraped off using a tongue depressor. The rest of the examination is within normal limits. Random blood glucose is 100 mg/dL with an A1c of 6.2%. Which of the following measures could have prevented this patient’s current abnormal findings?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has mild persistent asthma that is managed with inhaled albuterol and fluticasone. Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICSs) are generally well tolerated, though they tend to weaken the immune response in the mouth and throat, making oropharyngeal candida infections more common. Mouth rinsing after using the medication or using a spacer (a device that allows the medication to enter the back of the throat slowly) can be used to prevent this complication. 

Systemic side-effects from ICS are rarely observed and include increased susceptibility to infections, growth delay in children, easy bruising, hyperglycemia, and weight gain. Systemic therapy could cause pituitary-adrenal suppression, resulting in reduced cortisol production. It is important to reduce the dose gradually to give the adrenal gland time to ramp up cortisol production when aiming to stop the medication.   

Option Analysis

❌ Vitamin A supplementation :
Incorrect: Vitamin A deficiency can impair cell-mediated immunity and create higher susceptibility to oropharyngeal candidiasis. It typically presents with drying and thickening of the skin and conjunctiva. This patient’s physical examination is otherwise unremarkable, making improper administration of inhaled corticosteroids more likely to be the cause.  
✅ Oral rinsing after inhaler use :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Using topical betamethasone :
Incorrect: Topical betamethasone is first-line treatment for oral lichen planus. Lichen planus can be associated with hepatitis C. The oral lesions of lichen planus can appear as painless white streaks on the inside of the cheeks and sides of the tongue that are not easily scraped away.  
❌ Periodic glucose monitoring :
Incorrect: Although uncontrolled blood glucose levels can increase the risk of developing oropharyngeal candidiasis, it is unlikely to be the case in this patient with normal blood glucose and A1c of 6.2%. 
❌ Smoking cessation :
Incorrect: Leukoplakia presents as a non-scrapable white patch on the tongue. Though it is associated with smoking, this patient's white patches are scrapable and the history of inhaled corticosteroid use make that more likely to be the cause than leukoplakia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for fever and low back pain that radiates down her legs and is associated with numbness and weakness. She states her symptoms began three days ago and have progressively worsened to the point where she can no longer ambulate without assistance. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The spine is tender to palpation in the lumbar region at L4/L5. The lower extremities have decreased sensation to touch, diminished reflexes, and 3/5 muscle strength. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,500/µL (13.5 × 109/L). Blood cultures are collected. Which of the following, if present, would be a risk factor associated with the development of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of fever, lumbar back pain with radiation down the legs, associated numbness and weakness, spinal tenderness on exam, and systemic signs of infection suggests a spinal epidural abscess (SEA). Injection drug use is a known risk factor for spinal epidural abscess since it can introduce bacteria directly into the bloodstream, leading to hematogenous spread and abscess formation, particularly in the spine due to its rich blood supply.        

Physical examination in a patient with SEA will demonstrate signs and symptoms of local inflammation at the site of the abscess as well as systemic signs of infection. Back pain is the most common presenting symptom and is present in 70 percent to 100 percent of cases. Fever is an important diagnostic clue but can be absent on presentation. Spinal tenderness to palpation can be seen. Neurologic deficits are found in up to half of the cases of spinal epidural abscess and may include motor weakness, radiculopathy, and bowel and bladder dysfunction. Once paralysis develops, it may quickly become irreversible. Thus, urgent intervention is required if progression of weakness or other neurologic findings are detected. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with and without gadolinium contrast is the preferred imaging test because it is often positive early in the course of the infection, and it provides the best visualization of the location and extent of inflammatory changes.  



Option Analysis

❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: This patient with low back pain, lower extremity weakness, fever, and spinal tenderness most likely has a spinal epidural abscess. Tobacco use is not associated with the development of a spinal epidural abscess.  
❌ Recent travel history:
Incorrect: This patient with low back pain, lower extremity weakness, fever, and spinal tenderness most likely has a spinal epidural abscess. While travel can expose individuals to endemic diseases, it is less likely to cause an acute spinal epidural abscess without other risk factors being present, like immunosuppression. 
❌  Recent insect bite:
Incorrect: Insect bites can transmit infections such as West Nile virus, which can cause neuroinvasive disease. However, patients typically present with meningoencephalitis rather than a localized infection like a spinal epidural abscess, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.  
✅ Injection drug use:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Asthma controlled with steroid inhaler:
Incorrect: Long-term use of high dose oral or intravenous glucocorticoids can lead to immunosuppression and increased risk of spinal epidural abscess. However, use of inhaled steroids would not significantly increase the risk.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a three-month history of progressive dyspnea and a persistent, dry cough. She also reports experiencing dry eyes and dry mouth for the past year, which she initially attributed to aging. She has never smoked, has not traveled recently, and has not been exposed to sick contacts. Temperature is 37ºC (98.6°F), heart rate is 92/min, blood pressure is 145/94 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals a decreased salivary pool, dry eyes, and conjunctival injection. Examination and palpation of the joints is unremarkable. High-resolution computed tomography (CT) of the chest reveals widespread ground-glass opacities with minor subpleural reticulations and centrilobular nodules. Which of the following tests will most likely confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of progressive dyspnea, persistent dry cough, dry eyes (xerophthalmia), and dry mouth (xerostomia) along with findings on high resolution chest CT of interstitial lung disease  (ILD) are consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. Testing for the presence of anti-Ro/SSSa and anti-La/SSB antibodies can confirm the diagnosis of Sjögren's.          

The types of ILD can be classified based on their etiologies as exposure-related, autoimmune disease-related, and idiopathic.    
     
  1.  Exposure-related ILDs include those induced by certain drugs, such as chemotherapy agents, methotrexate, amiodarone, and macrolides. There’s also those caused by occupational or environmental factors, like inorganic dust, organic dust, gases, fumes, and radiation.   
 
  1.  Autoimmune-related ILDs are associated with diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and Sjogren’s syndrome.  
 
  1.  Idiopathic ILDs, where the cause is unknown, encompass idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP), non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP), sarcoidosis, and cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP).   
 
Antibody testing along with clinical findings can be used to determine which type of autoimmune diseases is the cause of interstitial lung disease when autoimmune related ILD is suspected. Patients with rheumatoid arthritis typically present with a history of small joint pain and swelling and the presence of rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies. Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus may have malar rash and other systemic symptoms and serologies that are positive for ANA and anti-double-stranded DNA. Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis is characterized by skin thickening and the presence of anti-Scl-70 and anti-centromere antibodies. Polymyositis and dermatomyositis are associated with muscle weakness and distinctive skin rashes, and patients may have myositis-specific antibodies such as anti-Jo-1. Patients with Sjogren's syndrome may have dry eyes and mouth and positive anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies.  



Option Analysis

❌ Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) :
Incorrect: This patient’s history, ,symptomatology and findings (e.g. dry eyes, dry mouth, interstitial lung disease) are most consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. While antinuclear antibodies (ANA) can be positive in Sjögren's syndrome, they are not specific for Sjögren's. Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies are specific for Sjögren's. 
❌ Rheumatoid factor:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and symptomatology and findings (e.g. dry eyes, dry mouth, interstitial lung disease) are most consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is typically elevated in rheumatoid arthritis; while it can be elevated in Sjögren's syndrome, it is not specific for Sjögren's.  
✅ Anti-Ro/SSA antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and symptomatology and findings (e.g. dry eyes, dry mouth, interstitial lung disease) are most consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies (anti-CCP) are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) but are not specific for  Sjögren's.   
❌ Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and symptomatology and findings (e.g. dry eyes, dry mouth, interstitial lung disease) are most consistent with Sjögren's syndrome. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with vasculitides, such as granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis, and not with Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with enterococcus endocarditis. He is treated with penicillin and gentamicin. During hospitalization, the patient develops worsening pulmonary edema secondary to valvular insufficiency and requires intravenous furosemide therapy. The patient improves over the next few days and is discharged home on the same medications. The patient returns for a routine follow-up visit and notes experiencing muffled hearing and difficulty understanding speech since being discharged from the hospital. Vitals are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination is unremarkable. Audiometry shows a bilateral symmetrical sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Squamous cell debris in the inner ear

questions.solution:
This patient, who is being treated with penicillin and aminoglycoside, develops decompensated heart failure and receives intravenous furosemide. He subsequently experiences difficulty hearing and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, which is consistent with drug-induced ototoxicity.        

Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide, bumetanide, torsemide) act on the ascending limb of the loop of Henle by binding and inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter. Inhibition of a similar symporter in the inner ear can cause tinnitus, vertigo, hearing impairment, and deafness. This side effect usually occurs with high doses, rapid intravenous administration, coexisting renal dysfunction, or co-administration with other ototoxic drugs (as in the case of this patient). Ototoxicity is usually reversible after stopping the medication.      

Other side effects of loop diuretics include hyperuricemia and gout attacks secondary to increased proximal tubule reabsorption of uric acid. They can also cause hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. This phenomenon results from an increased concentration of sodium ions in the collecting duct, which leads to increased secretion of potassium and hydrogen ions from the blood into the urine. Finally, the loss of sodium associated with loop diuretic use causes increased excretion of magnesium and calcium, thereby resulting in hypomagnesemia and hypocalcemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Squamous cell debris in the inner ear:
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are collections of squamous cell debris in the middle ear. Symptomatic patients can present with recurrent otorrhea and conductive hearing loss. In contrast, this patient has a bilateral sensorineural hearing loss after starting furosemide, which is more concerning for drug-induced ototoxicity. 
✅ Drug-induced ototoxicity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stiffening of the ossicles:
Incorrect: Otosclerosis is caused by abnormal bone deposition and results in stiffening of the ear ossicles. Patients typically present with conductive hearing loss and a paradoxical improvement in speech understanding with background noise. In contrast, this patient’s audiometry testing shows a sensorineural hearing loss. 
❌ Tumor of schwann cells :
Incorrect: Acoustic neuromas arise from the Schwann cells covering the vestibular branch of cranial nerve VIII. These patients typically present with asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss. This patient has bilateral sensorineural hearing loss after initiating furosemide therapy, which is more suggestive of drug-induced ototoxicity. 
❌ Scarring of the tympanic membrane:
Incorrect: Tympanosclerosis can cause stiffening of the tympanic membrane and lead to conductive hearing loss. Otoscopic examination often shows chalky patches on the tympanic membrane. In contrast, this patient’s otoscopic examination is unremarkable.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man visits the office for a follow-up of type II diabetes mellitus. He has no active complaints except for occasional lower extremity numbness. He was diagnosed with diabetes five years ago. At that time, lifestyle modifications were advised, and the patient was started on metformin, with which he has been adherent. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits with no orthostatic changes. Physical examination is unremarkable. His HbA1c is found to be 7.2%. A decision to start exenatide is made. Which of the following is the most common adverse effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Glucagon-like-peptide-1 (GLP-1) is a type of incretin released from the gut in response to increased glucose levels and results in postprandial insulin secretion by binding to GLP-1 receptors on pancreatic beta cells. This patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus is started on exenatide, a GLP-1 agonist. Gastrointestinal upset is the most common adverse effect of this medication. Other side effects include pancreatitis and weight loss.        

GLP1 receptor agonists are injectable hypoglycemic agents that lower glucose levels through various methods but mainly by increasing insulin secretion, reducing glucagon release, slowing down gastric emptying, and enhancing satiety.       



They are resistant to degradation by the enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) and therefore have a longer half-life. GLP-1 agonists are not the first-line drug for glycemic control but can be used in combination with metformin in patients with inadequate glycemic control with metformin monotherapy and those who require weight loss or avoidance of hypoglycemia. 

Option Analysis

❌ Weight gain :
Incorrect: Exenatide is a GLP-1 agonist and can cause weight loss (not weight gain). However, hypoglycemic drugs, including thiazolidinediones, sulfonylurea, meglitinides, and insulin preparations, are associated with a significant weight gain. 
✅ Gastrointestinal upset :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lactic acidosis :
Incorrect: Metformin, a biguanide, is associated with an increased risk of lactic, especially in patients with hypoperfusion (e.g., sepsis, heart failure) or impaired renal or liver function. It occurs secondary to the inhibition of gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase, the first step of gluconeogenesis. Exenatide does not affect the glucose metabolic pathway. 
❌ Hypoglycemia :
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia is the most common side effect of insulin secretagogues (sulfonylureas and meglitinides) synthetic insulin preparations. Exenatide is responsible for glucose-mediated insulin release from pancreatic beta cells and rarely causes hypoglycemia. 
❌ Vulvovaginal candidiasis :
Incorrect: Vulvovaginal candidiasis is a known adverse effect of sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors due to the increased glucose concentration in the urine provides a medium for fungal growth. Exenatide does not affect urine glucose concentration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to establish care. He was recently seen in the emergency department for abdominal pain, which has since resolved. CT scan performed at that time showed bilateral kidney cysts. Last week, the patient moved heavy boxes and has had low back pain radiating to the flanks since then, which worsens with exercise. He was treated eight months ago for a urinary tract infection that resolved with antibiotics. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 136/86 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is no costovertebral angle tenderness to percussion and kidneys are not palpable. The abdominal exam is within normal limits. There is bilateral paraspinal muscle tenderness in the lumbar spine. The left first toe is warm, swollen, erythematous, and tender to palpation. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following indicates the need for genetic testing in this patient?

choices.text: Monoarticular arthritis of the first metatarsal joint of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an incidental finding of cystic kidney disease. On physical exam, he has evidence of monoarticular arthritis in the big left toe, which is consistent with gout. Cystic kidney disease and gout are seen in patients with autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD). Genetic testing for UMOD and MUC1 mutations is necessary to diagnose ADTKD. Patients with cystic kidney disease and gout usually have a mutation in UMOD.

Kidney cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can be found in the cortex and/or medulla. They can occur as primary lesions, acquired due to underlying medical disease, or inherited. Certain cystic kidney diseases are associated with loss of renal function and chronic kidney disease. The most common types of cystic kidney disease are simple renal cysts, medullary sponge kidney disease, acquired renal cystic disease, autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), and ADTKD. Cysts are typically seen on ultrasound, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), or computed tomography (CT). A combination of the patient’s history, physical examination findings, and laboratory studies (e.g., renal function studies, and urinalysis) will typically help differentiate which cystic kidney disease is present. Genetic testing is needed to make the diagnosis of ADTKD.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Monoarticular arthritis of the first metatarsal joint of the foot :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Elevated blood pressure:
Incorrect: Elevated blood pressure is a nonspecific finding that can be seen in various conditions, including autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which typically does not necessitate genetic testing for diagnosis. Hypertension can also be seen in autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease, the combination of early-onset gout and cystic kidney disease is indicative of this disease. The diagnosis requires genetic testing to confirm. 
❌ Flank pain :
Incorrect: Flank pain may be present in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, which does not require genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. However, in this patient, the flank pain seems more likely related to a recent lower back muscular injury. 
❌ Non-palpable kidneys:
Incorrect: Kidneys may be palpable in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease and are not palpable in other cystic kidney diseases. Lack of palpable kidneys would not be an indication of a specific type of cystic kidney disease. 
❌ Prior urinary tract infection:
Incorrect: Recurrent urinary tract infections and kidney stones may suggest medullary sponge kidney disease or autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease. This patient had one episode of a urinary tract infection that resolved, and the presence of monoarticular arthritis consistent with gout is more suggestive of a diagnosis of autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease, which requires genetic testing to confirm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office for right flank pain, dysuria, and blood in the urine. The patient has a family history of kidney disease in multiple relatives. Her past medical history is significant for hypothyroidism, for which she takes levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 152/96 mm Hg. On physical exam, there is mild suprapubic tenderness and mild tenderness at the bilateral flanks. In-office urinalysis is positive for hematuria and leukocyte esterase. Which of the following findings would most likely be seen on kidney ultrasound?

choices.text: Enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts
Normal-sized kidneys with sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cortical cysts
Small kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts

questions.solution:
This patient presents with bilateral flank pain, hypertension, hematuria, and a urinary tract infection. Additionally, she has a strong family history of kidney disease. The most likely diagnosis is autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Findings on ultrasound in patients with ADPKD include enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts bilaterally.

Kidney cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can be found in the cortex and/or medulla of one or both kidneys. They can occur as primary lesions, acquired due to underlying medical disease, or inherited. The most common types of conditions in which renal cysts are seen are simple renal cysts, medullary sponge kidney disease, acquired renal cystic disease, ADPKD, and autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease (ADTKD). After a thorough history and physical are performed, ultrasound imaging should be performed to assist with differentiating between these conditions.

Patients with ADPKD will often present with recurrent urinary tract infections, hematuria, and flank pain (due to the large cyst burden and the resultant kidney enlargement). Elevated blood pressure is a common finding, and the kidneys may be palpable on exam due to their enlargement. Serum testing may show elevated creatinine, and urinalysis can indicate proteinuria and hematuria.   

Option Analysis

✅ Enlarged kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Normal-sized kidneys with sharply demarcated, smooth-walled cortical cysts:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings are consistent with simple renal cysts, which, depending on size and characteristics, may require no further monitoring or periodic imaging surveillance. This patient has a family history of kidney disease, flank pain, urinary tract infection, and hypertension consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 
❌ Small kidneys with multiple cortical and medullary cysts:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings suggest an acquired renal cystic disease, such as that seen with advanced chronic kidney disease and patients on hemodialysis. This patient has a family history of kidney disease, flank pain, urinary tract infection, and hypertension consistent with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). 
❌ Multiple medullary cysts:
Incorrect: This ultrasound finding would be consistent with autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease in a patient with elevated serum creatinine and gout.  
❌ Multiple medullary cysts and nephrocalcinosis:
Incorrect: These ultrasound findings suggest medullary sponge kidney disease, for which computed tomography or intravenous pyelogram should be performed. While this disease may present with hematuria and flank pain, this patient’s elevated blood pressure and strong family history instead suggest autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of HIV on antiretroviral therapy is admitted to the hospital for sepsis secondary to severe community-acquired pneumonia. During the hospital stay, she continues to spike fevers despite antibiotic administration. An infectious disease consult is requested to guide antimicrobial therapy. The medical team is alerted to a critically low platelet count, which was within normal range upon admission. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 111 /minute, respiratory rate is 20 /minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on 2 L via nasal cannula. The patient is ill appearing. Additional follow-up laboratory tests demonstrate a prolonged PT and aPTT, low fibrinogen, and an elevated d-dimer. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be consistent with the most likely underlying cause of thrombocytopenia in this patient?

choices.text: Hepatomegaly with a positive fluid wave test

questions.solution:
This patient presents with sepsis and has developed thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy, which is concerning for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Of the physical examination findings listed, bleeding from mucosal surfaces is the most likely finding associated with this condition.

DIC is characterized by widespread activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to the formation of blood clots, often in the microvasculature resulting in the consumption of platelets and coagulation factors, which can lead to severe bleeding. DIC is often triggered by an underlying condition, such as sepsis, trauma, malignancy, or obstetric complications.

Patients may present with thrombosis and/or bleeding. Common symptoms include bleeding from multiple sites, such as the gums, nose, and intravenous catheter sites. Patients may also exhibit widespread bruising (ecchymoses) and small, pinpoint hemorrhages (petechiae). Severe cases can lead to hematuria, hematemesis, and melena. Thrombosis can lead to signs and symptoms of venous thromboembolism, arterial thrombosis, or organ dysfunction. Evidence of organ dysfunction may include respiratory distress, jaundice, and decreased urine output.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bleeding from mucosal surfaces :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Splenomegaly :
Incorrect: Splenomegaly is commonly associated with thrombocytopenia due to increased platelet sequestration in conditions like cirrhosis or hematologic disease. However, this patient’s sepsis and laboratory findings make disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) a more probable cause of thrombocytopenia. 
❌ Oral ulcers and pallor :
Incorrect: Oral ulcers and pallor are more commonly seen in conditions like aplastic anemia or bone marrow failure syndromes. These conditions can also cause thrombocytopenia but do not present with the same coagulopathy profile seen in patients like this one with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). 
❌ Hepatomegaly with a positive fluid wave test :
Incorrect: These findings may be seen in patients with liver disease and portal hypertension, which can be associated with thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy. However, this patient’s sepsis and laboratory findings make disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) a more probable cause of thrombocytopenia. 
❌ Lymphadenopathy :
Incorrect: Enlarged lymph nodes are associated with lymphoproliferative disorders or infection, both of which can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). However, lymphadenopathy is not a feature of DIC, itself.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of stage IV pancreatic cancer presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. He reports feeling more fatigued than usual but denies acute bleeding or bruising. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals mild pallor and scattered petechiae over his lower extremities. There are no signs of active bleeding. Laboratory results from the past few months show a consistently low platelet count. Which of the following sets of laboratory results would support a diagnosis of chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation?
questions.solution:
Chronic disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) refers to an ongoing but compensated coagulopathy. As such, mild thrombocytopenia, mildly prolonged PT and aPTT, normal fibrinogen, and elevated d-dimer levels as seen in answer A would support the diagnosis.

Chronic DIC is characterized by continuous, low-grade activation of the coagulation cascade, leading to a relative balance between thrombosis and fibrinolysis. It is typically associated with chronic illnesses, such as malignancy (particularly solid tumors like pancreatic or gastric cancer) and autoimmune disorders. Unlike acute DIC, chronic DIC may be asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms and gradual onset. In chronic DIC, the body partially compensates for ongoing coagulation, preventing severe bleeding episodes seen in acute cases. Thrombosis is more prevalent than bleeding with chronic DIC.

Typical laboratory findings in chronic DIC include mildly decreased or normal platelet counts, normal or mildly prolonged PT and aPTT, normal or even elevated fibrinogen levels, and elevated D-dimer levels. Additionally, microangiopathic changes, such as schistocytes, may be evident on peripheral blood smear.   

Option Analysis

✅  Laboratory study     Result     Platelet count     90,000 /µL     Prothrombin time (PT)     14 seconds     Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     35 seconds     Fibrinogen     350 mg/dL     D-dimer     2.0 µg/mL    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Laboratory study     Result     Platelet count     150,000 /µL     Prothrombin time (PT)     12 seconds     Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     30 seconds     Fibrinogen     300 mg/dL     D-dimer     0.2 µg/mL    :
Incorrect: These values are within normal ranges and do not reflect the coagulopathy seen with chronic DIC. 
❌  Laboratory study     Result     Platelet count     100,000 /µL     Prothrombin time (PT)     15 seconds     Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     35 seconds     Fibrinogen     120 mg/dL     D-dimer     0.5 µg/mL    :
Incorrect: Although the platelet count is low and there are mild elevations in PT and aPTT, the fibrinogen level and D-dimer level are lower than what is typically seen in patients with chronic DIC.  
❌  Laboratory study     Result     Platelet count     30,000 /µL     Prothrombin time (PT)     22 seconds     Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     45 seconds     Fibrinogen     100 mg/dL     D-dimer     5.0 µg/mL    :
Incorrect: These values are more consistent with acute DIC, showing severe thrombocytopenia, significantly prolonged coagulation times, exceptionally low fibrinogen, and highly elevated D-dimer level. 
❌  Laboratory study     Result     Platelet count     200,000 /µL     Prothrombin time (PT)     11 seconds     Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     28 seconds     Fibrinogen     250 mg/dL     D-dimer     0.3 µg/mL    :
Incorrect: These values are all within normal ranges and do not indicate DIC.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for a routine check-up. She reports feeling well and has no concerns. The patient is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms regularly. She does not have fever, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, vaginal discharge, or gastrointestinal issues. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no known chronic illnesses. For the last three months, the patient has been using intravenous opiates. Vitals are within normal limits. There is no pharyngeal erythema, oral lesions or cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. No rashes are seen on the skin. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay is the recommended initial screening test for human immunodeficiency (HIV) infection because it can detect both HIV-1 and HIV-2 antibodies as well as the HIV-1 p24 antigen, allowing for the identification of both acute and established infections. The inclusion of the p24 antigen increases the sensitivity of the test during the early stages of infection when antibodies may not yet be detectable. Screening for HIV infection is recommended for all patients between the ages of 13 and 65 as part of their routine health care. All patients with risk factors should also be offered screening. 

The diagnostic workup for an adult who is due for screening or who has symptoms consistent with HIV infection begins with taking a thorough history to identify risk factors and clinical signs suggestive of HIV. The initial laboratory test of choice is the HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay, which detects both HIV antibodies and the p24 antigen, allowing for the identification of both acute and established infections. If this test is positive, it should be followed by an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay to confirm the diagnosis and distinguish between HIV-1 and HIV-2 infection. In cases where the initial combination immunoassay is non-reactive but there is suspicion for recent infection (e.g. known exposure or acute symptoms), an HIV-1 nucleic acid test (NAT) should be performed to attempt to detect the virus during the early window period. Patients with a positive combination immunoassay but negative or indeterminate differentiation test should also have HIV RNA testing.        

Option Analysis

❌ Qualitative HIV-1 nucleic acid test (NAT):
Incorrect: The HIV-1 NAT is highly sensitive and can detect HIV RNA shortly after exposure, but it is not typically used as the initial screening test due to its higher cost and complexity compared to the combination immunoassay.  
❌ HIV Western blot testing:
Incorrect: The Western blot is used as a confirmatory test following a positive initial screening test but is no longer recommended as a standalone initial screening tool due to lower sensitivity for detecting early HIV infection.  
✅ HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CD4 count:
Incorrect: The CD4 count measures immune function and helps monitor the progression of HIV infection, but it is not used for initial HIV screening because it does not directly detect the presence of the virus or HIV antibodies.  
❌ Quantitative HIV ribonucleic acid (RNA) testing:
Incorrect: Quantitative HIV RNA testing is done through nucleic acid amplification (HIV-1 NAT) and can be used to detect HIV when very early infection is suspected (i.e. less than 2 weeks) and combination antibody/antigen testing is indeterminate. It can also be used to monitor response to treatment. Combination immunoassay would be the preferred initial test for this patient.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic after recently being diagnosed with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) following a routine screening test. She reports feeling well and denies any symptoms such as fever, weight loss, night sweats, or gastrointestinal issues. Past medical history is significant for genital herpes. She has had multiple sexual partners in the past, with inconsistent condom use. She has no history of intravenous substance use. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results are reviewed and confirm the diagnosis of HIV infection with antibodies to HIV-1 detected on an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. CD4 count is 500 cells/µL. Viral load is pending. Hepatitis B and C and pregnancy testing is negative. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Start two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI)
Perform confirmatory HIV Western blot testing

questions.solution:
The recommended treatment approach for patients with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is to begin antiretroviral therapy (ART) as soon as possible after diagnosis. The goals of therapy are to suppress viral replication, reduce the viral load to undetectable levels, prevent disease progression, and reduce disease transmission. A typical ART regimen includes two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI). This combination targets different parts of the HIV life cycle, enhancing the effectiveness of treatment and reducing the risk of resistance.

Baseline HIV-1 RNA levels (viral load) and CD4 counts should be obtained to assess the stage of the infection and guide treatment decisions. Genotype resistance testing is recommended to identify drug-resistant strains of HIV, allowing for tailored therapy; however, testing should not delay initiation of ART as discussed above, which can be later adjusted based on the results of resistance testing.

Management of HIV also includes vaccination against preventable infections, such as influenza, pneumococcal disease, hepatitis B, and human papillomavirus (HPV). Patient education should emphasize the importance of medication adherence to prevent resistance, safe sex practices to reduce transmission risk, avoidance of intravenous substance use, and regular follow-up appointments to monitor treatment efficacy and manage side effects or complications.   

Option Analysis

❌ Await viral load results and start antiretroviral therapy (ART) if >5000 copies/mL  :
Incorrect: Delaying initiation of antiretroviral therapy is not recommended as early treatment improves clinical outcomes, reduces HIV transmission, and prevents the progression to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).  
❌ Begin protease inhibitor (PI) monotherapy:
Incorrect: Monotherapy with protease inhibitors is not recommended due to the increased risk of developing drug resistance and inferior efficacy compared to combination antiretroviral therapy (ART). 
✅ Start two nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI) :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Start two non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) :
Incorrect: NNRTIs can be used in combination with nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) for initial HIV treatment, but they are not recommended as monotherapy.  
❌ Perform confirmatory HIV Western blot testing:
Incorrect: HIV Western blot testing is no longer recommended for initial or confirmatory testing due to its lower sensitivity compared to modern combination immunoassays and nucleic acid tests.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with concerns about recent easy bruising. She notes that the bruises appear spontaneously, without significant trauma, and are particularly pronounced on the lower extremities. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis currently managed with methotrexate and low-dose prednisone. She has not had any recent infections, arthritis flares or changes in her medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is no joint swelling or active synovitis. Multiple non-tender ecchymoses are present on the extremities. Laboratory results are shown below. A mixing study shows that the prolonged aPTT does not correct when the patient’s plasma is mixed with normal plasma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Serum chemistries         
 Hemoglobin     11.8 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count      5,900 /mm3    
 Platelet count     200,000/mm3    
 Prothrombin time (PT)     12 seconds    
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)     60 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient presents with easy bruising, rheumatoid arthritis, and a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). The aPTT does not correct with a mixing study. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is the presence of a factor VIII inhibitor.        

This condition is known as acquired hemophilia A and is characterized by the spontaneous development of autoantibodies against factor VIII which inhibits its coagulant function. Unlike congenital hemophilia, which is rare in adult women, acquired hemophilia can occur in men and women. It is associated with autoimmune conditions, malignancies, certain medications, pregnancy, or it may be idiopathic.    

Option Analysis

❌ Factor VIII deficiency:
Incorrect: This condition, also known as hemophilia A, typically presents with a prolonged aPTT that corrects with a mixing study due to the addition of functional factor VIII. In this vignette, the mixing study did not correct the prolonged aPTT. Additionally, hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder which would be highly unlikely in this female patient. 
❌ Factor IX deficiency:
Incorrect: Also known as hemophilia B, this condition would typically present with a prolonged aPTT that corrects with a mixing study due to the addition of functional factor IX. The lack of correction with the mixing study makes this diagnosis unlikely.    
✅ Factor VIII inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Von Willebrand disease:
Incorrect: This condition can present with a variable aPTT and patients may have a normal platelet count. History typically includes frequent mucocutaneous bleeding, which is not seen in this case. An abnormal aPTT in von Willebrand disease typically corrects with mixing studies, which did not occur in this case. 
❌ Vitamin K deficiency :
Incorrect: Patients with vitamin k deficiency typically present with a prolonged PT. A prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) may be seen with active bleeding. However, in less severe cases, aPTT is typically normal or mildly elevated. The normal PT in this vignette makes this an unlikely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to increasing shortness of breath over the past eight hours. Over the past several months, she has had a persistent dry cough and unintentional weight loss of 10 lbs (4.5 kg). Initially, she demonstrates increased work of breathing but is not in respiratory distress. A chest radiograph is performed in the emergency department and shows a large perihilar mass. The patient subsequently becomes more short of breath and vomits more than one cup of bright red blood. A nasal cannula is placed, and oxygen is administered. Temperature is 36.3 ºC (97.3 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 35/min, blood pressure is 100/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 6 liters nasal cannula oxygen. On examination, the patient is in respiratory distress with intercostal retractions. There are bibasilar crackles and rhonchi in both lungs. An 18-gauge peripheral intravenous line is placed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 71-year-old woman who presents with a chronic dry cough, unintentional weight loss, and shortness of breath likely has lung cancer, based on the large perihilar mass seen on chest x-ray. Hemoptysis is a common symptom of lung cancer, and in severe cases, erosion and invasion of bronchopulmonary vessels can cause significant bleeding. Following an episode of large-volume hemoptysis, this patient develops respiratory decompensation and should undergo endotracheal intubation to secure the airway and prevent respiratory failure.    

Subacute cough refers to a cough lasting 3-8 weeks, and chronic cough refers to a cough lasting more than 8 weeks. While some causes (e.g., upper airway cough syndrome) do not require acute management, certain conditions, such as advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, can present with respiratory compromise requiring emergent management.   

For patients with subacute or chronic cough who present emergently, a focused ABCDE (airway, breathing, circulation, disability, exposure) assessment should be performed. Patients with a pulmonary cause of subacute or chronic cough may exhibit signs of respiratory distress, including tachypnea, hypoxia, and increased work of breathing. In these cases, endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary to prevent impending respiratory failure. Once the patient is stabilized, additional diagnostics and treatment can be directed at the underlying cause. In this patient’s case, additional management options could include computed tomography imaging of the chest, bronchoscopy, and/or bronchial artery embolization.   

Option Analysis

✅ Perform endotracheal intubation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Consult interventional radiology:
Incorrect: While interventional radiology may embolize a bleeding bronchial artery, stabilizing the patient’s airway and breathing status with endotracheal intubation is necessary. 
❌ Consult interventional pulmonology:
Incorrect: While interventional pulmonology may be able to intervene and help treat the cause of this patient’s hemoptysis, stabilizing the patient’s airway and breathing status with endotracheal intubation is necessary at this time. 
❌ Place a central venous catheter:
Incorrect: Central venous catheters should be placed if certain medications, such as vasopressors, are used. This patient already has a large-bore peripheral intravenous line, which will allow for fast administration of resuscitative fluids. 
❌ Transfuse packed red blood cells (PRBCs):
Incorrect: While this patient may eventually need a blood transfusion, securing the airway and respiratory status takes priority over transfusing blood products.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to a dry cough that started five weeks ago. He initially attributed it to “allergies,” but the cough has not improved. He also experienced a runny nose, nasal congestion, and frequent throat clearing over this same period. He has not experienced itchy or red eyes, a sour taste in the mouth in the morning, or substernal burning. He has no known medical history, takes no medication, and is not aware of any medication or food allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, he is well-appearing with no rashes and no conjunctival injection or discharge. Tiny amounts of drainage are seen at the posterior oropharynx. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following additional findings would be present on physical examination?
questions.solution:
This patient, presenting with a subacute cough (3-8 weeks), rhinorrhea, nasal congestion, and frequent throat clearing, likely has upper airway cough syndrome (UACS; commonly known as “post-nasal drip”). It can be allergic or nonallergic. A cobblestone appearance of the oropharynx would be consistent with this diagnosis.    

Evaluation of a patient with subacute or chronic requires a thorough history and physical exam, and often chest radiography. A detailed history should include questions about the frequency, quality, and degree of sputum production associated with the cough. For example, patients with bronchiectasis tend to have copious sputum production, whereas patients with UACS may have minimal sputum, and patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) have none. Environmental exposures, known allergies, and tobacco use should also be explored. Associated symptoms may also point toward the underlying etiology, such as heartburn (GERD), shortness of breath (asthma or COPD), an abnormal sensation in the throat, or frequent throat clearing (UACS).    

Physical examination should include examination of the ears, nose, throat, and lungs. Patients with UACS may have a cobblestone appearance of the posterior oropharynx (as seen in the image below). Alternatively, individuals with COPD may have a prolonged expiratory phase, and wheezing can be present in patients with severe GERD or asthma. However, lung sounds are normal in UACS, GERD, and nonasthmatic eosinophilic bronchitis.    



Image courtesy of Science Direct   

Figure 1. Cobblestone appearance of the posterior oropharynx in UACS   

Option Analysis

✅ Cobblestone appearance of oropharynx:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prolonged expiratory phase:
Incorrect: A prolonged expiratory phase may be seen in poorly controlled or advanced obstructive lung disease. This patient is more likely to have upper airway cough syndrome with cobblestone appearance of the oropharynx. 
❌ Mild diffuse wheezing:
Incorrect: Wheezing can be heard in conditions like asthma, COPD, and heart failure. This patient is more likely to have upper airway cough syndrome with cobblestone appearance of the oropharynx. 
❌ Epigastric tenderness:
Incorrect: Epigastric tenderness may be observed in patients with a chronic cough due to gastroesophageal reflux disorder. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with upper airway cough syndrome and cobblestone appearance of the oropharynx may be seen on physical examination. 
❌ Finger clubbing:
Incorrect: Finger clubbing is a chronic change associated with conditions such as cystic fibrosis or advanced lung cancer. It would not be seen with upper airway cough syndrome.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by friends after being found unresponsive at a party. The friends are unsure if the patient used recreational substances at the party. Temperature is 36.0 °C (96.8 °F), pulse is 48/min, respiratory rate is 10/min, blood pressure is 106/64 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 81% on room air, with increase to 86% on 6L nasal cannula. The patient is somnolent and minimally responsive to painful stimuli. Pupils are pinpoint and non-reactive. Heart sounds are slow but normal, and bilateral lung fields are clear to auscultation. The patient is given naloxone intravenously twice with minimal improvement in symptoms. An arterial blood gas is subsequently obtained, and results are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Arterial blood gas    
 pH     7.18   
 PaO2     57 mmHg   
 PaCO2     60 mmHg   
 HCO3-     23 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with acute opioid intoxication, including somnolence, pinpoint (miotic) pupils, hypotension, bradycardia, bradypnea, and hypoxemia. The arterial blood gas (ABG) shows respiratory acidosis (low pH, high PaCO2), which is indicative of hypoventilation, which is a common consequence of opioid overdose. Although the opioid antagonist naloxone was administered, this patient showed minimal improvement in respiratory status. This suggests either a severe overdose or delayed response to naloxone. Given the patient’s continued respiratory depression and hypoxemia despite initial naloxone administration, the next best step is to secure the airway and provide adequate ventilation. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are necessary to protect the airway, provide controlled ventilation, and correct hypoxemia and hypercapnia.      

If a patient presents with signs and symptoms suggesting substance use disorder and intoxication/overdose, an ABCDE assessment should be performed to determine stability. Unstable patients may need endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Following stabilization, IV access should be established, and continuous monitoring of vital signs should be provided with cardiac telemetry. Patients with substance-use disorder can present with various unstable conditions; for instance, cocaine toxicity may lead to cardiac ischemia and seizures, while opioid toxicity can cause severe drowsiness, respiratory depression, and coma. Benzodiazepine toxicity typically results in central nervous system depression, and withdrawal from benzodiazepines or alcohol can provoke potentially fatal seizures.        

Option Analysis

❌ Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation:
Incorrect: Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation may temporarily improve oxygenation, but it is not sufficient for a patient like this one with somnolence, severe respiratory depression, and inadequate airway protection. Endotracheal intubation is necessary to provide definitive airway management.  
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Intravenous fluids:
Incorrect: Intravenous fluids can help stabilize blood pressure but do not address the critical issue of respiratory failure in this patient. The primary concern is the patient's compromised airway and breathing, necessitating intubation.  
❌ Urine drug screen:
Incorrect: A urine drug screen can confirm the presence of opioids and other substances but would not provide immediate information necessary to manage acute respiratory failure. This patient's clinical condition requires urgent intervention to secure the airway and restore adequate ventilation.  
❌ Additional doses of naloxone:
Incorrect: Administering additional doses of naloxone could be considered, but this patient failed to significantly respond to the initial doses, indicating the need for a more immediate intervention to secure the airway and ensure adequate ventilation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for a routine follow-up. He reports drinking alcohol daily, typically having 3-4 drinks each evening to unwind. His drinking occasionally exceeds what he intends, leading to mild hangovers that have begun to affect his job performance as an attorney. Despite recognizing these issues, he has been unable to cut back on his own. He has not had any legal, social, or health consequences related to his drinking but is concerned about the potential for future problems. He expresses interest in a treatment plan that will be minimally disruptive to his demanding job. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with mild alcohol use disorder reports daily drinking affecting his job performance and seeks treatment that minimally impacts his work. Cognitive-behavioral therapy helps patients modify their drinking behaviors through targeted interventions and can be conducted on an outpatient basis, making it suitable for someone with a demanding job seeking a minimally disruptive treatment option.       

The stepwise, evidence-based approach to treating an adult with substance-use disorder begins with assessing the severity based on DSM-5 criteria, followed by personalized treatment planning. For mild cases, counseling techniques like motivational interviewing and cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) are primary interventions, often supplemented by peer support groups such as Alcoholics Anonymous (AA) or Narcotics Anonymous (NA). Moderate cases benefit from additional structured treatment programs which can be outpatient or inpatient based on the patient's needs and resources. Severe cases require intensive inpatient rehabilitation where patients can undergo monitored detoxification. Pharmacologic therapies, such as naltrexone or buprenorphine for opioid use disorder, are essential parts of treatment for moderate to severe cases of opioid use disorder but are less commonly used for other substances.   

Option Analysis

❌ Outpatient alcohol rehabilitation:
Incorrect: While outpatient rehabilitation can be effective, it often involves more intensive treatment schedules that might be challenging for a patient like this one who has a demanding job. Cognitive-behavioral offers a flexible and targeted approach that would be more suitable to this patient's needs. 
✅ Cognitive-behavioral therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Disulfiram:
Incorrect: Disulfiram is a medication that blocks the oxidation of alcohol at the acetaldehyde stage; when taken concomitantly with alcohol there is an increase in serum acetaldehyde leading to unpleasant side effects (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diaphoresis) when alcohol is consumed. It is used for patients with an elevated risk of relapse and is not first-line for someone with mild alcohol use disorder. 
❌ Inpatient alcohol rehabilitation :
Incorrect: Inpatient rehabilitation is typically reserved for individuals with more severe alcohol use disorders or those who require medical detoxification. It is highly disruptive and unnecessary for a patient like this one with mild alcohol use disorder. 
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: The benzodiazepine lorazepam is used for managing acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms but is not suitable for long-term management of alcohol use disorder due to its potential for dependence and sedation. Cognitive behavioral therapy would be more appropriate for this patient.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to a primary care office for evaluation of bilateral foot pain. She has had burning pain and tingling across both feet for the last year. She reports the symptoms worsen at night, and she has had two falls since symptom onset. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. There is no joint pain, swelling, or edema of the lower extremities. The skin is intact without rashes and distal pulses are 3+. There is decreased sensation in both feet using monofilament testing. Vibration perception is absent in the feet bilaterally and distal proprioception is reduced. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin A1C of 9.1% and vitamin B12 of 422 pg/mL. Which of the following additional findings is most consistent with the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Soft tissue mass in the third intermetatarsal space on magnetic resonance imaging
Positive Tinel test at the ankle

questions.solution:
This patient’s diffuse, bilateral, burning foot pain and tingling in the setting of type II diabetes mellitus associated with decreased sensation, vibration sense, and proprioception is concerning for diabetic neuropathy. Diabetic neuropathy can be diagnosed clinically when classic symptoms correlate with the diagnostic examination findings including decreased or absent ankle reflexes.

In addition to numbness, tingling, and neuropathic pain, patients may present with recurrent falls and poor balance from reduced proprioception. Abnormalities of vibration perception, monofilament testing, thermal discrimination, and pinprick sensation are also common.

Foot pain caused by trauma may be associated with a fracture, joint dislocation, sprain, or strain. These injuries commonly cause local bruising, swelling, tenderness to palpation, and changes to the patient’s gait. Neuropathic pain can be caused by conditions such as diabetic neuropathy, Morton neuroma, and tarsal tunnel syndrome, which may be distinguished by the location within the foot (diffuse or localized), and bilateral or unilateral nature Osteomyelitis of the foot and is commonly associated with diabetes and typically presents with localized pain, tenderness to palpation, warmth, erythema, and edema about an ulcer of the affected area of the foot. Systemic symptoms may or may not be present. Arthralgias may be localized to one or two joints and worsen with use, as in osteoarthritis, or diffuse across many joints and associated with morning stiffness, as in most rheumatologic conditions. Most dermatologic conditions of the feet can be diagnosed clinically based on classic diagnostic features seen on skin exams.   

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased Achille reflexes bilaterally:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ankle-brachial index less than 0.9:
Incorrect: An ankle-brachial index less than 0.9 is suggestive of peripheral vascular disease. This patient’s normal pulses and nocturnal symptoms are more suggestive of neuropathic pain rather than pain caused by vascular disease, which typically worsens with activity (claudication).  
❌ Soft tissue mass in the third intermetatarsal space on magnetic resonance imaging :
Incorrect: A soft tissue mass in the third intermetatarsal space on magnetic resonance imaging would be consistent with a Morton neuroma, which is a compressive neuropathy. This patient's symptoms are bilateral and diffuse, whereas patients with Morton neuroma describe unilateral pain isolated to the affected area. 
❌ Positive Tinel test at the ankle:
Incorrect: A positive Tinel test at the ankle is consistent with nerve entrapment, or tarsal tunnel syndrome. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a common co-morbidity in patients with diabetic neuropathy. However, it usually occurs unilaterally. This patient’s bilateral, diffuse symptoms and abnormal monofilament, proprioception, and vibration tests in the setting of poorly controlled Type II DM are more consistent with diabetic neuropathy. 
❌ Elevated methylmalonic acid:
Incorrect: Elevated methylmalonic acid is seen in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, which can cause peripheral neuropathy. However, this patient’s vitamin B12 level is within normal range and her hemoglobin A1C is elevated, making diabetic neuropathy the most probable cause of her symptoms.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the primary care office for evaluation of three weeks of worsening right foot pain. He has had a chronic, non-healing ulcer over his heel for four months, but it did not initially cause him pain due to having decreased sensation from diabetic neuropathy. Three weeks ago, he noticed redness and swelling around the area and pain deep within the foot. His past medical history includes poorly controlled insulin-dependent type II diabetes and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 124/82 mmHg.  On examination, there is a stage 3 ulcer over the plantar surface of the right foot at the heel with surrounding erythema, warmth, and edema that extends to the ankle. In addition to laboratory studies, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the foot
Computed tomography (CT) scan of the foot
Combined positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) of the foot

questions.solution:
This patient likely has osteomyelitis of the foot, as evidenced by a grade 3 ulcer surrounded by erythema, warmth, and edema in the setting of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus. Initial diagnostic testing for osteomyelitis typically includes obtaining both a plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging of the foot when available, along with blood cultures, complete blood count, and inflammatory markers such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate and C-reactive protein. Bone biopsy can provide a definitive diagnosis when needed. 

Fractures, joint dislocations, arthritis, and other causes of bony pain like calcaneal spur) can typically be diagnosed via X-ray imaging. Neuropathic pain caused by diabetic neuropathy can be diagnosed clinically. Patients with tarsal tunnel syndrome or neuropathy without a clear cause may benefit from evaluation via electromyography (EMG) and nerve-conduction study. Ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging are helpful when a mass is suspected (e.g., morton neuroma). Most dermatologic causes of foot pain can be diagnosed clinically, but laboratory and imaging studies may be needed in patients with deep or persistent skin ulcerations, especially if the patient has a history of diabetes.    

Option Analysis

✅ Plain X-ray and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the foot:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial wound culture:
Incorrect: A culture from a superficial wound is unlikely to be helpful in the management of osteomyelitis. Cultures obtained from bone biopsy during surgery can make a definitive diagnosis and help with directing antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of the foot :
Incorrect: CT is not as sensitive or specific as MRI for diagnosing osteomyelitis. It may be used in addition to plain films when MRI is not available or contraindicated. 
❌ Combined positron emission tomography (PET)/computed tomography (CT) of the foot:
Incorrect: PET/CT is effective in identifying osteomyelitis but is not widely used due to the cost, time-cost, and exposure to radiation. MRI is the study of choice for patients with suspected osteomyelitis, coupled with plain radiography.  
❌ Three-phase bone scintigraphy:
Incorrect: Three-phase bone scintigraphy is a nuclear medicine study that can be used to diagnose osteomyelitis when MRI is not available or contraindicated.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of right ankle pain that has progressively worsened over the past three weeks. He describes the pain as deep and constant and that it is occasionally sharp. He has not had recent trauma. He reports intermittent fevers, chills, and night sweats. He also notes increased swelling and redness over the right ankle over the past week. The patient has a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes with a recent HbA1c of 9.2%. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The right ankle is erythematous, swollen, and tender to palpation with noticeable warmth. There is a small, non-healing ulcer on the plantar surface of the forefoot. There is a reduced range of motion of the foot due to pain, but there is no crepitus or obvious deformity. Pedal pulses are present but diminished. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick over the right foot and toes. Examination of the left foot reveals decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick but is otherwise normal. An X-ray of the ankle shows a lucent area in the distal tibia with surrounding periosteal reaction and no other bony deformities. Examination of the left foot and ankle is within normal limits. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory value      Result    
 Leukocyte count     15,000/µL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     50 mm/hr    
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     45 mg/L

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the ankle joint

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes presents with progressive, subacute ankle pain; intermittent fevers; and night sweats along with the findings of a non-healing foot ulcer and peripheral neuropathy. Osteomyelitis is the most likely diagnosis, and the diagnosis is supported by the images showing a lucent area over the distal tibia with periosteal reaction and elevated inflammatory markers with white blood cell count on bloodwork.

When evaluating a patient with ankle pain, traumatic etiologies, such as fractures or sprains, should first be ruled out. When injury is present, The Ottawa ankle rules can be applied to determine the necessity of imaging to exclude an ankle fracture. In the absence of trauma, infectious causes like septic arthritis and osteomyelitis should be considered in patients with systemic symptoms, such as fever or a history of intravenous drug use or diabetes with ulcers. Blood tests, arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis, and imaging studies such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can help determine if these conditions are present. In patients with diabetes, diabetic neuropathy should be considered, and testing with nerve conduction velocity studies along with imaging should be performed. Cases of suspected tendinopathies, osteoarthritis, or rheumatoid arthritis may require evaluation with X-rays, ultrasound, MRI, or joint aspiration.   

Option Analysis

❌ Septic arthritis of the ankle joint :
Incorrect: Patients with septic arthritis typically present with the acute onset of severe joint pain, swelling, and erythema—often accompanied by joint effusion and significantly limited range of motion. Early on, X-rays may be normal or show swelling and edema. The findings on X-ray of a lucent area and periosteal reaction indicate osteomyelitis. 
❌ Neuropathic arthropathy:
Incorrect: Neuropathic arthropathy, or Charcot joint, is characterized by joint deformity and lack of pain despite joint destruction. While this patient does have longstanding diabetes and evidence of peripheral neuropathy, the presence of fever and lack of deformity along with the imaging findings of lucency and periosteal reaction suggest osteomyelitis. 
❌ Achilles tendinopathy:
Incorrect: Achilles tendinopathy is associated with pain localized to the Achilles tendon that is made worse with dorsiflexion. It is caused by overuse. The findings of fever and ulceration and lucency and periosteal reaction on imaging are more consistent with osteomyelitis. 
❌ Gout:
Incorrect: Patients with gout usually presents with acute onset of severe pain, erythema, and swelling of one or a few joints. It most commonly affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint. The findings of a non-healing ulcer and lucency and periosteal reaction on imaging are more suggestive of an osteomyelitis.  
✅ Osteomyelitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of severe left ankle pain and swelling and the inability to bear weight on the left foot for the past 24-hours. He has also been experiencing fevers and chills. There is no history of trauma. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 104/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Multiple track marks are present on the upper extremities bilaterally. The patient is unable to bear weight on the left foot. The left ankle is erythematous, swollen, warm, and tender to palpation with the presence of an effusion. The patient refuses to actively plantar or dorsiflex the foot as there is significant pain and limited range of motion with passive range of motion of the left ankle. Examination of the right ankle and foot is within normal limits. Which of the following tests will be most helpful for making a definitive diagnosis and guiding treatment?

choices.text: Complete blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the ankle

questions.solution:
This patient with a likely history of intravenous drug use (suggested by the multiple track marks present on physical exam) presents with severe left ankle pain, swelling, erythema, warmth, joint effusion, limited range of motion, and inability to bear weight. The most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid aspiration and analysis will be most helpful for confirming the diagnosis, ruling out other causes, such as crystal arthritis, and guiding treatment with tailored antibiotics. 

A thorough history and detailed physical examination should be used to create a differential diagnosis for a patient with ankle pain. Initially, traumatic causes, such as fractures or sprains, should be considered, especially in patients with a recent history of injury. The Ottawa ankle rules can be applied to determine the necessity of imaging to exclude fractures.
