In the absence of trauma, infectious causes like septic arthritis or osteomyelitis should be considered. This is particularly important in patients with systemic signs and symptoms, such as fever or chills, or with risk factors, like a history of intravenous drug use. These conditions can be confirmed with blood tests, synovial fluid analysis, and imaging (with MRI). If trauma and infection are unlikely but diabetes is present, then patients should be assessed for neuropathic pain with nerve conduction velocity studies. If tendinopathies, osteoarthritis, or systemic arthritis like rheumatoid arthritis is suspected, further evaluation with ultrasound, MRI, joint aspiration, and specific blood tests should be considered.   

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count and C-reactive protein (CRP) :
Incorrect: While an elevated white blood cell count or CRP may support the diagnosis of a joint infection (i.e. septic arthritis), they would not definitively identify the causative organism or confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ X-ray of the ankle:
Incorrect: An X-ray can help identify fractures or signs of osteomyelitis, but X-ray is not sensitive or specific enough for diagnosing septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the best test for diagnosing septic arthritis and guiding treatment. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the ankle:
Incorrect: MRI is useful for providing detailed imaging of the soft tissue and bone, but arthrocentesis would be better to confirm the diagnosis of septic arthritis and to guide the choice of antibiotics. 
❌ Nerve conduction velocity study:
Incorrect: Nerve conduction velocity studies are used to diagnose neuropathies. This patient's symptoms and history and physical examination findings are more indicative of septic arthritis. Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the best test for confirming the diagnosis of septic arthritis and guiding treatment. 
✅ Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of decreased appetite, frequent belching, and unintentional weight loss of 8 pounds over the past two months. He also reports intermittent epigastric pain which worsens after meals. His diet consists of red meat and spicy foods. He does not use non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The patient smokes half a pack per day of cigarettes and drinks 1-2 beers daily. His medical history is unremarkable, and there is no history of recent gastrointestinal infections or travel. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is tenderness in the epigastric region. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Upper endoscopy (EGD) shows hyperemia, enlargement of mucosal folds, and nodularity in the gastric antrum and body. Biopsy results show chronic active gastritis with glandular atrophy and the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria within the gastric epithelium. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Smoking cessation and counseling on alcohol use
Proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin

questions.solution:
his patient presents with decreased appetite, frequent belching, unintentional weight loss, and epigastric pain and tenderness. EGD shows hyperemia, enlarged mucosal folds, and nodularity, and biopsy results indicate chronic active gastritis with glandular atrophy and the presence of spiral-shaped bacteria. The most likely diagnosis is H. pylori gastritis. The best next step in management is triple therapy, which consists of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to reduce gastric acid secretion, plus clarithromycin, and amoxicillin (or metronidazole in case of penicillin allergy) to eradicate the H. pylori infection. This regimen is typically administered for 14 days.        

The treatment of gastritis varies depending on the underlying cause. Stress gastritis is managed with PPIs or H2 blockers for acid suppression and addressing underlying stressors (e.g., burns, severe illness). Chemical gastritis, caused by NSAIDs, alcohol, or bile reflux, requires discontinuation of the offending agent along with PPIs or H2 blockers. Autoimmune gastritis involves vitamin B12 supplementation, PPIs for symptom management, and lifestyle modifications. Reactive gastritis should be treated by removing the irritant along with PPIs or H2 blockers plus sucralfate to protect the gastric mucosa.    

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitor:
Incorrect: While PPIs are part of the treatment regimen for H. pylori gastritis, monotherapy with a PPI alone is insufficient to eradicate the infection and address the underlying cause of the gastritis.  
❌ Smoking cessation and counseling on alcohol use:
Incorrect: While smoking cessation and reducing alcohol intake are beneficial for overall health and may improve gastritis symptoms, they would not directly treat the H. pylori infection which is responsible for the patient's condition.  
❌  Dietary modifications and probiotics:
Incorrect: Dietary modifications and probiotics can support gastrointestinal health but are not sufficient as primary treatments for H. pylori gastritis. Eradicating the infection requires a specific regimen of PPIs and antibiotics. 
✅ Proton pump inhibitor, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sucralfate:
Incorrect: Sucralfate can be used to protect the gastric mucosa and aid in healing ulcers, but it would not address the underlying H. pylori infection.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for his annual visit. Since his last visit one year ago, he has had no new concerns. He reports adequate sleep, nutrition, and exercise. He drinks alcohol socially but does not smoke or use other recreational substances. His last Tdap booster was six years ago. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is well-appearing and in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary, abdominal, and musculoskeletal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following vaccinations is indicated now?
questions.solution:
This patient, who is 53 years old with a past medical history significant for hypertension and without health concerns or other chronic conditions, presents for routine evaluation with his primary care physician. A core component of annual primary care evaluation is ensuring that patients are up-to-date on vaccinations. Based on this patients age, he is a candidate for the recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) which is administered to help prevent shingles. Two doses of recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) to prevent shingles and related complications is recommended for adults aged ≥50 years.       

Immunizations, also known as vaccines, stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against specific microorganisms. These antibodies disable pathogens and remain in the body to provide long-term immunity, decrease the likelihood of infection, and decrease its severity. The vaccination schedule for adults is determined by age and underlying immune status and can be divided into recommendations for four diverse groups based on age, 19-26yo, 27-49yo, 50-64yo, and patients aged 65 and older. Administration of vaccines should occur based on the recommendations for each age group and the compounding risk factors such as pregnancy or immunosuppression.    

Option Analysis

✅ Recombinant (Zoster) vaccine (RZV):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tdap booster:
Incorrect: This patient has received a Tdap booster within the last ten years. It is unnecessary to have another vaccination for 4 more years unless he sustains a severe wound that is at high-risk for infection.  
❌ RSV vaccine:
Incorrect: There is no specific recommendation regarding immunization against RSV infection for patients aged 50-60. For patients older than 60 years, immunization is recommended for immunocompromised patients and those with certain chronic diseases.  
❌ HPV vaccine:
Incorrect: The HPV vaccine is not recommended for adults greater than age 45.  
❌ Hepatitis A vaccine:
Incorrect: The hepatitis A vaccine is not routinely indicated for patients 50 years and older unless they are unvaccinated and at increased risk for infection or at increased risk for severe disease from infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 3-week history of severe low back pain radiating to her right leg. She describes the pain as a sharp, burning sensation that starts in her lower back and travels down the posterior aspect of her right thigh to her calf. The pain worsens with sitting, bending forward, and coughing. She denies any recent trauma but recalls lifting a heavy box three weeks ago, after which the pain started. She has had intermittent numbness and tingling in her right foot but has not had   bowel or bladder incontinence. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient has an antalgic gait and prefers to stand rather than sit. There is minimal tenderness to palpation over the lower lumbar spine and paraspinal muscles. The straight leg raise test is positive on the right at 40 degrees, reproducing her leg pain. Motor examination reveals 4/5 strength in right foot dorsiflexion, and sensory examination shows decreased sensation over the dorsum of the right foot. Reflexes are diminished in the right Achilles tendon. Which of the following is most likely to be seen with diagnostic imaging?

choices.text: L5-S1 disc protrusion with impingement at the neural foramen
Degenerative changes in the facet joints
Vertebral body compression fracture at L3
Narrowing of the spinal canal at multiple levels

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms and physical examination findings consistent with an L5-S1 disc herniation, including severe low back pain radiating to the right leg, positive straight leg raise test, motor weakness in right foot dorsiflexion, decreased sensation over the dorsum of the foot, and diminished Achilles reflex. The most likely advanced imaging finding would be L5-S1 disc protrusion with impingement at the neural foramen, causing compression of the exiting nerve root.

The diagnostic workup for an adult with mechanical back pain begins with a detailed history and physical examination to identify the nature and characteristics of the pain, along with any red flag symptoms. Initial imaging studies, such as plain X-rays, can be useful to detect bony abnormalities like spinal fractures, spondylolysis, and spondylolisthesis. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard for evaluating soft tissue structures and helping to differentiate spinal stenosis (narrowing of the spinal canal with neural impingement), disc herniation (evidenced by protrusion or extrusion of intervertebral discs causing nerve root compression), and spondylosis (degenerative changes including disc space narrowing, osteophytes, and facet joint hypertrophy). Muscle strain or sprain is typically diagnosed clinically. Spondylolysis often presents with a "Scotty dog" sign on oblique X-rays, while spondylolisthesis shows vertebral displacement relative to the adjacent vertebrae.   

Option Analysis

✅ L5-S1 disc protrusion with impingement at the neural foramen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Degenerative changes in the facet joints:
Incorrect: Degenerative changes in the facet joints, typically seen in conditions like spondylosis, generally cause chronic back pain with stiffness and limited range of motion but do not usually present with acute radicular pain or neurological deficits like those described in this patient.   
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture at L3:
Incorrect: A vertebral body compression fracture at L3 would cause significant localized back pain and tenderness at the site of the fracture, often associated with trauma or osteoporosis risk factors. 
❌ Narrowing of the spinal canal at multiple levels:
Incorrect: Narrowing of the spinal canal at multiple levels, indicative of spinal stenosis. Patients may present with neurogenic claudication, characterized by bilateral leg pain, numbness, and weakness that worsens with walking and standing, rather than unilateral radicular symptoms which are worse in flexion as seen in this patient. Furthermore, it typically affects individuals over the age of 60 years.  
❌ Pars interarticularis defect at L5:
Incorrect: A pars interarticularis defect at L5, which can be seen in spondylolysis, can cause localized lower back pain that may radiate into the buttocks but does not typically cause the acute, unilateral radicular symptoms or neurological deficits that are characteristic of disc herniation.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of recurrent palpitations for the past two days. The patient reports that every time she stands up, she feels lightheaded and dizzy. She says she sees stars and feels like she is going to pass out. She recently had a viral gastrointestinal infection that lasted three days. The patient has not recently traveled and has no significant past medical history. She does not smoke and drinks alcohol socially. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse seated is 88/min and regular and upon standing is 120/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 107/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient has dry mucous membranes. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals a regular pulse with clear lungs bilaterally on auscultation. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Further clinical evaluation is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
  

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with ECG findings (regular, tachycardic rhythm with, narrow QRS complexes with P-waves) that are consistent with sinus tachycardia, which is a type of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). When patients present with sinus tachycardia, they should be assessed for physiologic causes like anxiety, pain, and exercise, or pathologic causes, like infection, hypovolemia, and anemia. This patient has clinical findings suggestive of dehydration, including vasovagal symptoms with standing up. Given recent gastroenteritis, poor oral intake, vomiting, and diarrhea are the most likely causes of sinus tachycardia. Fluid repletion is likely to resolve this patient’s symptoms.

All patients presenting with supraventricular tachycardia tend to exhibit similar symptoms including lightheadedness, dizziness, syncope, palpitations or occasionally exercise intolerance. However, symptoms alone are not effective in further elucidating the type of SVT, and all patients should have an electrocardiogram for formal diagnosis of the arrhythmia. Physical examination may reveal clues (e.g., regular pulse or irregular pulse) or bounding neck pulses, which are occasionally observed in patients with AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT). Importantly, patients should be assessed for signs of instability including altered mental status, poor perfusion (e.g., delayed capillary refill), or hypotension. Further history may provide additional clues regarding the origination of arrhythmia such as recent alcohol or caffeine intake, dehydration, or medical comorbidities such as hypertension, congestive heart failure, or smoking.

Option Analysis

✅ Poor oral intake, vomiting, and diarrhea:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Family history of arrythmia:
Incorrect: A family history of arrhythmia may predispose patients to conditions such as Wolf-Parkinson-White; however, WPW typically predisposes patients to orthodromic AVRT, which presents as a regular, narrow complex tachycardia with P-waves that immediately follow the QRS complex. A resting ECG will reveal a short PR interval followed by a delta-wave. This patient's ECG shows sinus tachycardia, and she most likely has dehydration from poor oral intake, vomiting, and diarrhea secondary to gastrointestinal illness. 
❌ Lower extremity swelling:
Incorrect: Unexplained tachycardia should prompt consideration for pulmonary embolism, especially in the setting of chest pain and hypoxia. This patient's clinical history and examination are more suggestive of hypovolemia secondary to poor intake, vomiting, and diarrhea from gastrointestinal illness.  
❌ History of endocrinopathy:
Incorrect: Thyroid disease (e.g., Grave disease) should be considered for all patients presenting with unexplained palpitations and sinus tachycardia. However, this patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with hypovolemia secondary to poor intake, vomiting, and diarrhea from gastrointestinal illness. 
❌ History of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD):
Incorrect: Patients with multifocal tachycardia often have underlying pulmonary disease. And present with an irregular pulse and ECG showing changing morphology of the P waves and a variable PR interval. This patient's ECG shows sinus tachycardia, and her clinical presentation is more consistent with hypovolemia secondary to poor intake, vomiting, and diarrhea from gastrointestinal illness.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for one week of progressive fatigue, cough and dyspnea, and hemoptysis that occurred today, causing him to call an ambulance. He has no significant medical history and takes no medication. He has smoked a pack per day for 8 years. He is unable to speak in full sentences, so additional history is limited. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure is 102/62 mmHg, respiratory rate is 34/min, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. The patient appears diaphoretic and pale. Accessory muscles are used during respiration. Auscultation of the lungs reveals crackles diffusely in the bilateral lung fields. Laboratory values are shown below. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse bilateral interstitial opacities. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory study     Result    
 Creatinine     2.7 mg/dL    
 Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)     Negative    
 Anti-myeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies     Negative    
 Antiproteinase-3 antibodies     Negative    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies     Positive    
 Urinalysis     3+ blood    3+ protein    Numerous erythrocytes and erythrocyte casts
questions.solution:
This young, previously healthy patient presents with hemoptysis and acute respiratory distress. He is found to have diffuse, bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, indicative of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. Additionally, his laboratory studies reveal evidence of kidney injury and anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM), consistent with anti-GBM disease, (also referred to as Goodpasture disease). He has significant hypoxemia and impending respiratory failure. The immediate priority is to secure the airway and ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation, which requires endotracheal intubation.        

If a patient is presenting acutely with signs and symptoms suggestive of an underlying vasculitis, it is critical to perform an ABCDE (airway, breathing, circulation, disability, exposure) assessment. Unstable patients require emergent interventions, which may include securing the airway, obtaining IV access, and initiating continuous vital sign monitoring. Additional measures will depend on the clinical situation. Once the patient is stabilized, further testing to determine the underlying vasculitis can be performed. Initial testing typically includes obtaining a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), c-reactive protein (CRP), and urinalysis, which will help determine if an inflammatory condition is present and the extent of organ involvement. More specific tests, such as ANCA, ANA, and anti-GBM antibodies, can be ordered to help make the diagnosis, but results will take time to come back.    

Option Analysis

❌ High-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: While high-dose corticosteroids are used in the treatment of anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease to reduce inflammation and immune response, they do not address the immediate need for airway management and oxygenation in this patient with respiratory failure from hemoptysis.
❌ Plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is an important treatment for removing circulating anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies from the blood, but it is not an emergency intervention for acute respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure from hemoptysis.  
❌ Cyclophosphamide:
Incorrect: Cyclophosphamide is an immunosuppressive agent used to treat anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. However, it does not provide immediate relief for respiratory distress. Airway management must be addressed first in this patient. 
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: While a renal biopsy is useful for diagnosing anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease by identifying characteristic linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, it is not an urgent intervention for this patient in acute respiratory distress and impending respiratory failure from hemoptysis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man presents to the primary care office due to recurrent bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence for the past several months. His stools have mostly been a watery liquid consistency, and his symptoms are worse after meals. He recently started training to become a competitive bodybuilder and has been on a diet consisting of milk and whey protein shakes, yogurt, and red meat at every meal. He has not had recent illnesses, nocturnal diarrheal symptoms, or recent weight loss. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes only multivitamins. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination reveals normoactive bowel sounds without tenderness to palpation. Stool osmotic gap is 110 mOsm/kg. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of watery diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and flatulence that occur after the intake of lactulose-containing foods (e.g., milkshakes, and yogurt), are indicative of lactose intolerance.         

Lactose intolerance occurs due to a deficiency in lactase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down lactose in the small intestine. The undigested lactose is fermented by colonic bacteria, producing hydrogen gas and organic acids, which can be detected by an increase in breath hydrogen content and a decrease in stool pH. The hydrogen breath test is a non-invasive diagnostic tool that can be used to help identify lactose intolerance when the diagnosis is not apparent from the clinical evaluation and a trial of dairy avoidance.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Fecal bile acid level:
Incorrect:   An elevated fecal bile acid level is associated with diarrhea caused by over-production or insufficient absorption of bile acids that lead to a secretory type of diarrhea. This patient’s elevated osmotic gap is more suggestive of osmotic diarrhea from lactose intolerance, which can be confirmed with a hydrogen breath test if needed.    
❌ Fecal pancreatic elastase-1 level :
Incorrect: Fecal pancreatic elastase-1 level measures pancreatic function and is used to diagnose pancreatic insufficiency, which typically presents with steatorrhea and malabsorption, not with the symptoms described in this patient, which are more consistent with lactose intolerance. 
✅ Hydrogen breath test:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tissue transglutaminase IgA level:
Incorrect: Tissue transglutaminase IgA level is a serological test used to diagnose celiac disease, which is caused by gluten intolerance and often presents with steatorrhea, weight loss, and evidence of malabsorption. This patient’s watery diarrhea after intake of dairy products is more suggestive of lactose intolerance, which can be confirmed with a hydrogen breath test.  
❌ 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid level:
Incorrect: The 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid testing is used to diagnose carcinoid syndrome, which can be associated with flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing due to serotonin production by carcinoid tumors. This patient’s isolated intestinal symptoms after eating milk-containing products and elevated stool osmotic gap are more suggestive of osmotic diarrhea caused by lactose intolerance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of left lower extremity pain. Over the past four weeks, he has developed aching pain in the left anterior hip and thigh. It does not radiate and is not associated with numbness or tingling. He describes it as moderate pain that worsens after prolonged sitting and diminishes upon standing. He does not recall recent trauma to the area. He has a history of playing competitive soccer. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. There is pain in the left groin with passive flexion and internal rotation at the hip, especially when combined with adduction. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on radiographs of the left hip?

choices.text: Joint space narrowing of the hip joint
Subchondral bone destruction of the hip joint

questions.solution:
This 30-year-old man with a history of playing competitive soccer presents with a gradual onset of left anterior hip pain over four weeks that worsens with prolonged sitting and improves with standing. Physical exam is significant for pain in the left groin with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip (FADIR maneuver). These findings in this athletic patient without an inciting event likely represent femoroacetabular impingement. Left hip radiographs would most likely show Cam morphology.    

Hip pain is quite a common reason for patients to seek medical care. It can be caused by hip joint pathology or from local musculoskeletal issues causing radiation into the hip joint (e.g., lumbar or knee issues). In many cases, the history and physical examination are sufficient to make a diagnosis. However, imaging may be required.    

When the diagnosis is uncertain, radiographs of the hip and pelvis should be obtained. Further imaging such as ultrasound, computed tomography (CT), or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may also be required if radiographs are unrevealing, there is concern for significant soft tissue pathology (e.g., ligament, muscle, tendon) or infection, or for surgical planning.    

Fractures or dislocations are usually visible on plain radiographs, and a defect of the labrum can be seen on X-rays. Radiographic signs of hip osteoarthritis include subchondral sclerosis, osteophytes, and joint space narrowing.    

Femoroacetabular impingement is when there is abutment of the femoral head-neck junction against the acetabular rim due to an aspherical femoral head (Cam morphology), over-coverage of the femoral head (pincer morphology) or a combination of the two morphologies. This can result in bony prominence of the femoral head and flattening of the head-neck junction as seen in the radiograph below.  



Image courtesy of STATdx   
Figure 1. Cam morphology of femoroacetabular impingement: The white arrow shows the bony prominence of the femoral head, resulting in flattening of the head-neck junction.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cam morphology of femoroacetabular impingement:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Joint space narrowing of the hip joint :
Incorrect: While joint space narrowing is typically seen in osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis would be an unlikely cause of hip pain in this young, otherwise healthy patient. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Osteophytes at the hip joint:
Incorrect: Osteophytes are typically seen in osteoarthritis. This patient is an otherwise healthy 30-year-old, making this diagnosis unlikely. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Defect of the hip labrum:
Incorrect: A hip labral defect would suggest a labral tear, which typically occurs acutely due to a traumatic inciting event (e.g. sports injury), which does not fit with this patient’s presentation. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs. 
❌ Subchondral bone destruction of the hip joint:
Incorrect: Subchondral bone destruction may be seen in severe cases of septic arthritis. This patient’s pain level, chronic or subacute course, and lack of fever do not support a diagnosis of septic arthritis. Femoroacetabular impingement is the most likely diagnosis with Cam morphology present on radiographs.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of erectile dysfunction. The patient reports a gradual decline in his ability to sustain an erection over the past several years. He used to wake up with erections, but no longer does. The patient retired from the army eight years ago. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral neuropathy, post-traumatic stress syndrome (PTSD), stable angina, and a prior myocardial infarction. Ophthalmologic evaluation six months ago revealed diabetic retinopathy, which was treated with photocoagulation. Current medications include metformin, escitalopram, aspirin, nitroglycerin, and atorvastatin. He drinks two to three drinks per week and has a 25 pack per year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased vibration sensation in both feet and a reduced pedal pulse on the left side. The patient requests a prescription of sildenafil. Which of the following is the most important consideration in prescribing sildenafil to this patient?
questions.solution:
Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitors are first-line medications for the management of organic erectile dysfunction. Its use, however, is contraindicated in patients on nitrates (in this case, nitroglycerin).   

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. However, PDE-5, normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP, is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in cGMP accumulation, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used with nitrates. Their use together is absolutely contraindicated.   

Option Analysis

✅ Current use of nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Peripheral neuropathy :
Incorrect: Peripheral neuropathy is not a contraindication to PDE-5 inhibitors. In fact, according to some studies, sildenafil has shown to decrease the symptoms of diabetic peripheral neuropathy. 
❌ Current use of atorvastatin :
Incorrect: There is no significant interaction between atorvastatin and PDE-5 inhibitor. 
❌ Diabetic retinopathy :
Incorrect: Although PDE-5 inhibitors are associated with temporary bluish visual discoloration due to the cross reactivity with PDE-6 inhibitors in the retina, this medication is not contraindicated in patients with diabetic retinopathy. 
❌ Current use of escitalopram :
Incorrect: Serotonin syndrome is an important consideration in prescribing a new serotonergic medication to a patient currently taking a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). However, sildenafil is not a serotonergic drug, so there is no concern regarding this patient’s use of escitalopram.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her spouse due to dull pain in the abdomen and back, burning pain in the legs, and recent onset of paranoia. According to the spouse, the patient was recently diagnosed with a seizure disorder and has been on phenobarbital for the past two weeks. The patient eats three meals every day and regularly exercises. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 139/85, and SpO2 is 96% on room air. Physical examination shows mild diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation, as well as agitation. Laboratory studies show hyponatremia and normal white blood cell count. Urinalysis shows a significantly elevated level of porphobilinogen. Which of the following explains why this patient developed these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of acute porphyria, including abdominal and back pain, neuropathic limb pain, nausea/vomiting, agitation, and elevated levels of porphobilinogen. She most likely has acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), likely precipitated by the recently initiated phenobarbital.       

Barbiturates like phenobarbital induce cytochrome p450 expression. Cytochrome p450 is an enzyme that contains heme. In patients taking p450 inducers (e.g. barbiturates), circulating levels of heme are reduced as more p450 enzymes are produced. Lack of circulating heme reduces the negative feedback of ALA synthase-1, promoting the production of more heme (see image below). The underlying etiology of acute intermittent porphyria is an impairment in the activity of porphobilinogen deaminase, which leads to an accumulation of porphobilinogen (PBG). This can be detected in the urine. High levels of ALA and PBG can build up and become toxic.       

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant disorder, caused by a mutation in the HMBS (also called PBGD) gene, which codes for porphobilinogen deaminase. Patients with AIP are often asymptomatic, with some patients never experiencing any symptoms. Of patients that do experience a porphyric attack, they are usually precipitated by three main factors – cytochrome p450 inducers, prolonged fasting, or acute infection (see image below). Porphyric attacks occur with varying symptomatology and usually include some combination of abdominal pain, back pain, neuropathic limb pain, and nausea and vomiting. Attacks can vary in severity, with more severe cases involving mental status changes, progressive renal dysfunction, and even death. The vast majority of patients are diagnosed with genetic testing for HMBS gene mutations.     

Option Analysis

❌ Depletion of delta-aminolevulinic acid :
Incorrect: Delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is an important intermediary in the heme biosynthesis pathway. During an attack of acute intermittent porphyria, ALA levels are dramatically increased, not decreased.  
❌ Exposure to sunlight  :
Incorrect: Photosensitivity is a pathognomonic cause of skin lesions in porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). This patient has acute intermittent porphyria, not PCT. 
✅ Induction of ALA synthase -1 :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Induction of heme oxygenase :
Incorrect: Heme oxygenase is an important liver enzyme involved in the degradation of heme. Its actions are accelerated in acute inflammation. This vignette is not suggestive of an acute inflammatory response (e.g. no fever, no leukocytosis, no supportive physical exam findings). 
❌ Prolonged fasting  :
Incorrect: Fasting is one of the main ways to develop a porphyric attack in a patient with suspected acute intermittent porphyria. However, the vignette states that this patient eats three meals per day.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath and wheezing that began while the patient was eating dinner. The patient reports that he has been experiencing increased coughing and wheezing over the past week and recently ran out of his albuterol inhaler. The patient has a history of asthma treated with an as-needed albuterol inhaler and opiate use disorder treated with daily buprenorphine. The patient smokes 2-3 cigarettes daily and does not use alcohol. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate 123/min, blood pressure 100/68 mmHg, respiratory rate 26/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 95% on room air. The patient appears short of breath with auditory wheezing and use of supraclavicular accessory muscles. He is alert and oriented. He is able to talk in 5–7-word sentences. Pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally. Pulmonary exam reveals minimal air movement and faint expiratory wheezes bilaterally. Cardiac examination is normal. The patient is placed on the cardiac monitor and initial stat blood gas results are obtained, which show pH 7.25 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 48. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Inhaled albuterol and bi-level positive airway pressure

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of asthma presents with a cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, and use of accessory muscles after running out of his albuterol inhaler. He has evidence of severe asthma exacerbation and concomitant respiratory acidosis, as evidenced by arterial blood gas results. For patients with severe asthma exacerbations, acute management involves administration of bronchodilator treatment with inhalation of short-acting beta-2-selective adrenergic agonists like albuterol and application of non-invasive ventilation (e.g., bilevel positive airway pressure) and intravenous corticosteroids. If this patient continues to have progressive hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis despite intensive therapy, this can indicate worsening obstruction or respiratory muscle fatigue necessitating intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Respiratory acidosis refers to an increase in partial pressure of carbon dioxide or pCO2, with or without a compensatory increase in bicarbonate resulting in increased hydrogen ion concentration in the blood. This condition is almost always caused by hypoventilation, usually from the central nervous system, obstructive or parenchymal pulmonary, or iatrogenic conditions. Respiratory acidosis is characterized by an arterial pH below 7.35 and a pCO2 above 45 millimeters of mercury.

Many conditions can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and parenchymal pulmonary etiologies; however, the approach remains the same in terms of acute management. For all patients with respiratory acidosis, acute management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation, obtaining IV access, and placing the patient on continuous vital sign monitoring, and providing supplemental oxygen as needed.    

Once the etiology of the acidosis is determined, targeted management should proceed. For example, asthmatic patients should receive inhaled bronchodilator therapy, non-invasive ventilation, and steroids. If a foreign body ingestion/food aspiration is suspected, patients should undergo the Heimlich maneuver, or have the foreign body removed under direct visualization. If acidosis is related to recreational substance overdose, patients should receive the appropriate corrective reversal agent (e.g., naloxone for opiate overdose, or flumazenil for benzodiazepine overdose).  

Option Analysis

✅ Inhaled albuterol and bi-level positive airway pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rapid sequence intubation:
Incorrect: Rapid sequence intubation should be performed as a last resort for patients with respiratory acidosis from severe asthma exacerbation. If this patient continues to have progressive hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis despite intensive therapy, this can indicate worsening obstruction or respiratory muscle fatigue, and intubation and mechanical ventilation should be considered. 
❌ Heimlich maneuver :
Incorrect: This patient can speak clearly, in 5–7-word sentences, making foreign body aspiration as the cause of respiratory distress unlikely. This patient has evidence of a severe asthma exacerbation that should be treated with inhaled Albuterol and bi-level positive airway pressure. 
❌ Naloxone :
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of opiate intoxication or overdose despite his history of opiate use disorder. The patient has equal and reactive pupils on examination and is awake, alert, and oriented. Patients with respiratory distress from opiate intoxication/overdose typically are somnolent with constricted pupils bilaterally. 
❌ Terbutaline:
Incorrect: Terbutaline is a beta-agonist that can be used as a refractory measure to treat patients with severe asthma exacerbations. Intravenous, intramuscular, and subcutaneous beta-agonists like epinephrine and terbutaline are typically avoided in asthma exacerbations because inhaled short-acting selective beta agonists like albuterol have equal or greater efficacy with limited side effects.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of acute shortness of breath and coughing. His partner found him at the dining room table unable to speak and in visible distress after she momentarily left the room to take out the garbage. They were having a meal of chicken wings. She reports that before this event he was in his usual state of health. The patient has a history of intermittent asthma that is well-controlled with an as needed albuterol inhaler. He does not take any other medication. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate 110/min, blood pressure 155/52 mmHg, respiratory rate 24/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation 90% on room air. The patient demonstrates accessory muscle use and is unable to speak in clear, full sentences. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals stridor and wheezing on the left side. The patient is provided with nebulized albuterol without improvement in symptoms. An arterial blood gas is drawn, which demonstrates a pH 7.30 and a pCO<sub>2</sub> 50. A chest x-ray demonstrates air trapping on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of cough, stridor, wheezing, and shortness of breath while eating chicken wings. He is in acute respiratory distress, most likely from foreign body aspiration. Moreover, the patient is found to have a respiratory acidosis pattern on arterial blood gas analysis. 

Respiratory acidosis refers to an increase in partial pressure of carbon dioxide or pCO2, with or without a compensatory increase in bicarbonate resulting in increased hydrogen ion concentration in the blood. This condition is almost always caused by hypoventilation, usually from the central nervous system, obstructive or parenchymal pulmonary, or iatrogenic conditions. Respiratory acidosis is characterized by an arterial pH below 7.35 and a pCO2 above 45 millimeters of mercury. 

Many conditions can cause respiratory acidosis, including central nervous system (CNS), neuromuscular, obstructive, and parenchymal pulmonary etiologies. Patients with wheezing, cough, stridor, or shortness of breath likely have a primary pulmonary process such as asthma, foreign body aspiration, pneumonia, or ARDS, and should undergo an appropriate workup, which will typically include a chest x-ray, administration of bronchodilator therapy, and monitoring for response to treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Foreign body aspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acute respiratory distress syndrome:
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) presents with non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema and bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray following an inciting event (e.g., trauma, sepsis, pancreatitis). This patient has no evidence of this condition. 
❌ Epiglottitis:
Incorrect: Epiglottitis can present with stridor and acute respiratory distress; however, this patient has no clinical findings to suggest an associated infectious process (e.g., fever).  
❌ Pneumonia:
Incorrect: Pneumonia presents with progressively worsening cough, fever, and shortness of breath and infiltrates on chest x-ray. This patient’s sudden presentation of acute respiratory distress and stridor that developed while eating chicken wings is more suggestive of foreign body aspiration. 
❌ Asthma exacerbation:
Incorrect: Asthma exacerbations present with diffuse wheezing and will typically show improvement with bronchodilator therapy. This patient’s sudden presentation of acute respiratory distress and stridor that developed while eating chicken wings and is unresponsive to albuterol is more suggestive of foreign body aspiration.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after she found him difficult to arouse from bed this morning. The partner reports that over the past three days, the patient has become progressively more lethargic and confused. He recently developed progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of yellow sputum. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and chronic lower back pain managed with low-dose oxycodone. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0 °F), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 148/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on 4L/min nasal cannula. The patient is difficult to awaken and disoriented. The patient is using accessory respiratory muscles to breathe. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light.  Cardiopulmonary exam is significant for diffuse wheezes bilaterally. Arterial blood gas analysis is shown below. What is the best next step in management? 

 Parameter      Value     
 pH      7.18     
 PaCO2      82 mmHg     
 PaO2      45 mmHg     
 HCO3-      31 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure as evidenced by mental status changes, elevated CO2 levels, and hypoxemia. The most immediate and necessary intervention is to secure this patient’s airway with endotracheal intubation to ensure adequate ventilation and to prevent further respiratory compromise. Hypoxic hypercapnic respiratory failure can be seen in patients with COPD exacerbations. 

The management of a patient with altered mental status begins with a rapid ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability (Neurological), and Exposure/Environment) assessment. First, ensuring that the airway is secure, and considering endotracheal intubation if necessary. Assessment of respiratory rate and oxygen saturation should guide management, supplemental oxygen or non-invasive ventilatory support should be provided as needed. circulation should be assessed by monitoring heart rate, blood pressure, and perfusion, intravenous access should promptly be obtained. The provider should next perform a quick neurological examination using the Glasgow Coma Scale to assess consciousness and check for focal deficits. The patient should be exposed to identify any physical signs of trauma or other relevant findings.        

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are an important part of management for patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, however, this patient’s acute hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure needs to be addressed first. 
❌ Non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV) :
Incorrect: Although NIPPV is often used to treat patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, this patient with altered mental status needs definitive airway management with intubation and mechanical ventilation.  
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics may be necessary in this case to treat possible pneumonia; however, antibiotics alone would not address the acute need for airway management in this patient. 
✅ Endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: While naloxone can be used to reverse opioid overdose, this patient's presentation is more consistent with acute hypoxic and hypercapnic respiratory failure from COPD and possible pneumonia. The absence of pinpoint pupils and significantly depressed respiratory rate makes opioid overdose less likely in this patient.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of frequent, difficult-to-control nosebleeds over the past two months. He has a history of hypertension, lower gastrointestinal bleeding from angiodysplasia, and aortic stenosis. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. There is a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right intercostal space. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient? 

 Laboratory Test      Result     
 Hemoglobin 9.5 g/dL     
 White blood cell count 7,000 /µL     
 Platelets 200,000 /µL     
 Prothrombin time (PT) 12 seconds     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 34 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent nose bleeds, a history of aortic stenosis, and bleeding from angiodysplasia most likely has Hyde syndrome and acquired von Willebrand syndrome. von Willebrand factor levels should be checked to confirm the diagnosis when acquired von Willebrand syndrome is suspected.

Patients with the association of bleeding from angiodysplasias and aortic stenosis can be diagnosed with Heyde syndrome. Aortic stenosis can lead to decreased von Willebrand factor levels from sheer forces. Patients typically present with bleeding from skin or mucosal sites, along with bleeding from angiodysplasia. In acquired von Willebrand syndrome from aortic stenosis, there is destruction of high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF) due to shear stress across the stenotic aortic valve.        

Option Analysis

✅ von Willebrand factor level :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate for hematologic disorders that can lead to acquired von Willebrand syndrome. However, in this patient with aortic stenosis and angiodysplasia, Hyde syndrome with decreased von Willebrand factor levels is the more likely cause. 
❌ Peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: Peripheral blood smear in patients with Hyde syndrome and acquired von Willebrand syndrome may show fragmented red blood cells, but it would not confirm the diagnosis. Decreased Von Willebrand factor levels would be needed to confirm the diagnosis.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: A colonoscopy can help identify angiodysplasia but would not confirm the cause of bleeding in this patient. The presence of low levels of von Willebrand factor would confirm the diagnosis of acquired von Willebrand syndrome. 
❌ Right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Incorrect: A right upper quadrant ultrasound can evaluate for liver disease that may lead to clotting factor disorders. However, in this patient with bleeding and findings consistent with Heyde syndrome, von Willebrand levels should be checked to confirm that acquired von Willebrand syndrome is the cause of bleeding.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of right shoulder, neck, and arm pain for the past several weeks. The patient reports associated weakness in her right arm, particularly with overhead movements. The patient describes the pain as “burning” and says it shoots down her right arm. She does not recall any history of injury or trauma. The patient has a history of obesity and hypertension for which she takes amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right shoulder shows no evidence of ecchymosis, swelling, erythema, or deformity. The patient has diminished range of motion at the shoulder secondary to pain. Sensation is mildly diminished over the lateral shoulder with noted weakness with shoulder abduction. The patient experiences the pain when the examiner extends and rotates the neck to the right and presses downward on the head. Which of the following is the best next step for diagnosing the underlying cause of shoulder pain in this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right shoulder

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of atraumatic right shoulder pain and neck and right arm pain. This patient's description of the pain is consistent with neuropathic pain, which can present as shooting and burning pain that follows a nerve distribution. Moreover, this patient has associated neurovascular deficits, further supporting a diagnosis of cervical radiculopathy. Therefore, the best next step is to obtain an MRI of the cervical spine to determine if there is cervical radiculopathy.        

Shoulder pain is a common symptom with many potential underlying causes, including conditions affecting the joint, capsule, tendons, or bursa. When performing a history and physical examination for a patient with shoulder pain, the first step is to identify if the patient’s shoulder pain is due to trauma or infection.     

When no history of trauma is present, patients should subsequently be assessed for findings that may suggest infection (e.g. fevers, chills, immunosuppression, warmth, or swelling over the joint). If signs of infection are present, patients should be assessed for septic arthritis or osteomyelitis with blood work, synovial fluid analysis, and MRI.    

When no findings of infection are present, further history can aid in narrowing the diagnosis. Patients with neuropathic shoulder pain often describe pain as burning, lancinating, shooting, or electric in nature and running down the arm. Patients may have findings of neuromuscular/sensory deficits on physical examination, such as decreased sensation and weakness, as seen in this patient. This patient also has a positive Spurling test, indicating cervical radiculopathy. Patients with cervical radiculopathy typically have cervical spinous disease, such as nerve root impingement, as the underlying cause of shoulder pain. In contrast, patients with nociceptive pain will often describe pain that is localized, dull, or sharp. Patients with pain that is nociceptive should undergo further assessment on physical exam for the primary tissue that is damaged (joints, capsules, soft tissues).    

Option Analysis

✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the cervical spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: Synovial fluid analysis is indicated for patients when there is suspicion for septic arthritis. Signs, symptoms, and findings indicating septic arthritis include fevers, chills, and swelling/erythema over the shoulder. This patient's history and physical examination are more consistent with cervical radiculopathy.  
❌ X-ray of the right shoulder:
Incorrect: Given this patient has no history of trauma, an X-ray of the right shoulder is unlikely to provide additional diagnostic utility. An MRI of the cervical spine is more likely to reveal the underlying diagnosis.  
❌ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)/c-reactive protein (CRP):
Incorrect: Inflammatory marker analysis is indicated for patients when there is suspicion of septic arthritis, which typically presents with fevers, chills, and swelling/erythema over the shoulder. This patient's history and physical exam findings are more consistent with cervical radiculopathy. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the right shoulder:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggesting neuropathic pain from cervical radiculopathy. Therefore, primary shoulder pathology that would be seen with MRI is unlikely the cause of the pain.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to several days of worsening shortness of breath. He reports a persistent dry cough for months but no chest pain or palpitations. The patient has severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. Temperature is 36.7 ºC (98.1 ºF), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 142/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued, but he is not in respiratory distress. There are no extra cardiac sounds on auscultation, and breath sounds are distant with scattered wheezes throughout. No digital clubbing is present. Laboratory studies and a chest radiograph are ordered. A bedside transthoracic echocardiogram shows right atrial enlargement and an estimated mean pulmonary artery pressure of 50 mmHg. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 56-year-old man with severe COPD presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and is found to have elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Given the severity of obstructive lung disease and hypoxia, this patient likely has pulmonary hypertension due to chronic lung disease (group III). Since the patient is unstable from a respiratory standpoint, the hypoxia should be addressed with supplemental oxygen via nasal canula before long-term treatment for pulmonary hypertension can be started.   

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) refers to a mean pulmonary artery pressure >20 mmHg and is classified into five groups (I, II, III, IV, and V) based on the underlying etiology. Patients generally present with dyspnea and fatigue, and in more severe cases, may experience chest discomfort or syncope. Physical examination may show signs of right heart strain due to elevated pulmonary pressures, such as right ventricular heave, jugular venous distention, and abnormal cardiac sounds.    

An ABCDE assessment should be performed initially to evaluate for stability. In cases of associated hypoxic respiratory failure, supplemental oxygen should be administered. In severe respiratory failure, especially with concomitant obstructive lung disease, bilevel airway positive pressure (BiPAP) or even endotracheal intubation with mechanical ventilation may be necessary.   

Option Analysis

✅ Supplemental oxygen with nasal canula:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Bilevel positive airway pressure:
Incorrect: Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) is useful in treating patients with poor ventilation or in certain cases of severe oxygenation issues. This patient has not yet had a trial of supplemental oxygen via less invasive means (e.g., nasal cannula) and does not display overt signs of respiratory distress, therefore supplemental oxygen with nasal canula can be tried first. 
❌ Chlorothiazide:
Incorrect: While loop diuretics are frequently used for the acute management of pulmonary hypertension, thiazide diuretics alone are not an effective treatment and this patient's hypoxia should first be managed with supplemental oxygen. 
❌ Sildenafil:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors are used to treat patients with group 1 pulmonary hypertension. This patient likely has group 3 pulmonary hypertension (due to chronic lung disease). Additionally, it is crucial to first manage this patient’s hypoxia. 
❌ Pulmonary rehabilitation:
Incorrect: Pulmonary rehabilitation is helpful for managing many cases of pulmonary hypertension, as it can increase exercise capacity and quality of life. However, it is not appropriate for acute management of hypoxia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the cardiology clinic due to persistent, progressive shortness of breath for the past several months. He wakes up feeling rested and does not have any morning headaches or snoring reported at night. He has poorly controlled hyperthyroidism and end-stage renal disease, which is treated with dialysis three times per week. He has never smoked. Vital signs, including oxygen saturation, are within normal limits. BMI is 21.3 kg/m2. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. There are no extra cardiac sounds, and the lungs are clear to auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. Recent computed tomography imaging of the chest, including angiography, showed no abnormalities, and his ECG is unremarkable. A recent transthoracic echocardiogram estimated the mean pulmonary artery pressure at 35 mmHg, which was confirmed by right heart catheterization. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Pulmonary hypertension group I due to pulmonary arterial hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension group II due to left heart disease
Pulmonary hypertension group III due to chronic lung disease
Pulmonary hypertension group IV due to pulmonary artery obstruction
Pulmonary hypertension group V due to multifactorial mechanisms

questions.solution:
This 65-year-old man presents to the clinic with evidence of pulmonary hypertension (PH), confirmed by right heart catheterization. The patient does not have historical or physical examination findings consistent with a cardiac source (e.g., severe coronary artery disease, heart failure) or a pulmonary source (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary embolism), and he does not have chronic hypoxia (no morning headaches or feelings of poor rest), which might suggest obstructive sleep apnea. He does have a history of hyperthyroidism and renal disease, making group V PH due to unclear or multifactorial mechanisms the most likely diagnosis.    

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) refers to a mean pulmonary artery pressure >20 mmHg and is categorized into five groups (I, II, III, IV, and V) based on the underlying cause. After confirming the diagnosis, the diagnostic workup focuses on determining the underlying etiology. Group I PH (also called pulmonary artery hypertension) tends to occur in younger patients, especially women, and is associated with BMPR2 gene mutations or connective tissue diseases. Group II PH is due to left heart disease causing increased back pressure in the pulmonary circulation. Group III PH is due to chronic lung disease and/or hypoxia, leading to chronically elevated pulmonary pressures. Group IV PH is due to chronic pulmonary artery obstruction, usually chronic thromboembolic disease (i.e., multiple chronic pulmonary emboli). Group V PH is due to multifactorial causes without one clear distinct etiology. Patients should be questioned about symptoms related to each type of underlying cause, and they should have studies performed to determine the type of PH that is present and the underlying etiology.  



Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary hypertension group I due to pulmonary arterial hypertension:
Incorrect: Group I pulmonary hypertension is more common in young women and is frequently associated with BMPR2 gene mutations, connective tissue diseases, or liver disease. This patient’s thyroid and renal disease are not associated with group I pulmonary hypertension. 
❌ Pulmonary hypertension group II due to left heart disease:
Incorrect: Group II pulmonary hypertension is associated with cardiac disease, such as significant coronary artery disease or heart failure. This patient has a normal electrocardiogram, an echocardiogram without mention of left ventricular dysfunction, and there is no evidence of pulmonary edema, making a cardiac cause unlikely. 
❌ Pulmonary hypertension group III due to chronic lung disease:
Incorrect: Group III pulmonary hypertension is associated with chronic lung disease and/or chronic hypoxia. This patient does not have evidence of severe pulmonary disease or untreated obstructive sleep apnea. 
❌ Pulmonary hypertension group IV due to pulmonary artery obstruction:
Incorrect: Group IV pulmonary hypertension is associated with chronic thrombotic disease in the pulmonary vasculature. This patient does not have a history of deep vein thrombosis, and computed tomography imaging of the chest does not show any abnormalities. 
✅ Pulmonary hypertension group V due to multifactorial mechanisms :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of worsening dyspnea on exertion over the past several months. The patient was initially seen by his primary care physician for shortness of breath and was referred to a pulmonologist. Pulmonary function tests revealed findings consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Despite bronchodilator therapy and smoking cessation, the patient has not had relief of symptoms and continues to have dyspnea on exertion, early satiety, and abdominal fullness. Additional past medical history includes hypertension for which he takes amlodipine. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 124/64 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The patient is in no acute distress and is resting comfortably on the examination table. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals a loud P2 but no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Jugular venous distention is present. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen is soft but distended, and 2+ pitting edema is present in the lower extremities bilaterally. An echocardiogram is ordered. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on echocardiogram?

choices.text: Elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure
Right ventricular enlargement and right ventricular dysfunction with preservation of apical contractility

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent dyspnea on exertion with additional signs and symptoms consistent with right heart failure, including abdominal fullness, early satiety, lower extremity edema, and jugular venous distention. A loud P2 on cardiac auscultation and his history of chronic lung disease makes pulmonary hypertension the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms and findings. An elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure would be the most likely finding on echocardiography.        

Right heart failure occurs when the right side of the heart fails to adequately perfuse the pulmonary arterial circulation, resulting in an elevated central venous pressure. In stable patients, this condition often presents with chronic dyspnea, chest discomfort, fatigue, early satiety, or abdominal fullness. Physical examination may reveal jugular venous distention, hepatojugular reflux, bilateral lower extremity edema, and/or ascites. Cardiac exam will typically reveal a right ventricular heave, loud P2 (due to pulmonary hypertension), and right-sided S3. Importantly, there should be no evidence of pulmonary edema, unless concurrent left-sided heart failure is present.        

The cause of right heart failure can typically be identified based on a careful history and assessing for additional physical examination findings. For example, patients with right heart failure secondary to valvular disease will demonstrate a pulmonic valve or tricuspid valve murmur, while those with myocardial disease will have a known history of coronary artery disease or a history of inferior myocardial infarction. Patients with pulmonary artery hypertension will typically have a known risk factor, such as structural lung disease, obstructive sleep apnea, venous thromboembolism, connective tissue disease, or chronic lung disease like COPD (as seen in this patient).   

Option Analysis

✅ Elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve regurgitation:
Incorrect: This patient's history of chronic lung disease and physical examination findings (particularly the loud P2) suggest pulmonary hypertension secondary to chronic lung disease. With tricuspid valve regurgitation, a typical murmur (holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border) would be expected, and this patient has no murmurs. 
❌ Increased right ventricular ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Based on the history and exam findings, this patient likely has right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension from chronic lung disease. Echocardiography would likely show decreased, not increased, right ventricular ejection fraction as a consequence of increased afterload imposed on the right ventricle due to elevated pulmonary artery pressures.  
❌ Right ventricular enlargement and right ventricular dysfunction with preservation of apical contractility:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and not pulmonary artery hypertension, which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. PE is typically associated with acute shortness of breath, while this patient has had progressive dyspnea over months.  
❌ Large pericardial fluid collection:
Incorrect: In order to cause right heart failure with dyspnea, a large pericardial fluid collection would need to result in cardiac tamponade, which would be associated with hemodynamic instability and muffled heart sounds. This patient is hemodynamically stable and has history and examination findings that are more suggestive of pulmonary hypertension from chronic lung disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the cardiologist for evaluation of worsening dyspnea with exertion for three months. She reports a significant increase in lower extremity swelling and abdominal fullness over this time. The patient states that she can only walk to the bathroom in her home before becoming severely short of breath. She has difficulty performing her activities of daily living due to the symptoms. Two months ago, an echocardiogram revealed severe tricuspid valve regurgitation without evidence of elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure. She has been compliant with her prescribed furosemide as well as fluid and salt-restriction. She uses prescribed supplemental oxygen as needed. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease for which she takes carvedilol, metformin, atorvastatin, and a baby aspirin daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 146/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. The patient appears fatigued but is not in respiratory distress. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals a holosystolic murmur, right-sided S3, and jugular venous distention. 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally and abdominal distension are also present. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with right heart failure secondary to tricuspid valve regurgitation. Given that the patient has been on fluid and salt restriction and diuretics without improvement, the best next step in management is cardiothoracic surgery consultation for valvular repair or replacement.         

Patients with right heart failure should receive supplemental oxygen when indicated (e.g. hypoxia at rest or with exertion), loop diuretics, and fluid/salt restriction to assist in optimizing right ventricular preload. Specific treatments will depend on the underlying cause. Patients with valvular dysfunction may require cardiothoracic surgical consultation for valve repair or replacement. Those with pulmonary hypertension or myocardial disease may require ionotropic medications to assist with contractility (e.g. dobutamine), mechanical circulatory support, or heart transplantation. For pulmonary hypertension, vasodilators, inotropic agents, treatment of the underlying cause, and lung or heart transplantation for severe disease may be necessary.    

Option Analysis

✅ Cardiothoracic surgery consultation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Heart transplantation :
Incorrect: A heart transplant should be considered for patients with severe right heart failure secondary to myocardial disease. This patient has clinical findings more suggestive of right heart failure secondary to valvular dysfunction, requiring valve replacement or repair. 
❌ Digoxin :
Incorrect: Digoxin can be considered for treatment of patients with right heart failure secondary to decreased myocardial contractility. It is not used to treat right heart failure secondary to valvular dysfunction.  
❌ Apixaban :
Incorrect: Anticoagulation should be considered for patients with right heart failure secondary to pulmonary embolism. However, this patient’s echocardiographic findings indicate that the right heart failure is more due to tricuspid valvular dysfunction.  
❌ Left-ventricular assist device :
Incorrect: A left ventricular assist device (LVAD) serves as bridging therapy for patients with end-stage left-sided systolic heart failure. It does not serve a role in the treatment of right-sided heart failure.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with four-days of nausea vomiting, diarrhea, and fatigue and new bruising on her arms and legs that is unrelated to trauma. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.9ºC (100.3°F), heart rate is 112/min, blood pressure is 96/42 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears pale and is alert and oriented. Skin examination shows widespread petechiae and several large ecchymoses on the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. No facial rash is present. Abdominal exam shows mild diffuse tenderness but no rebound or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. A peripheral blood smear reveals numerous schistocytes. Which of the following additional features would be most consistent with the likely underlying diagnosis?

 Laboratory value      Result     
 Serum chemistries           
 Hemoglobin      9.4 g/dL     
 Hematocrit      28 %     
 Leukocyte count      12,100 /mm3     
 Platelet count      88,000/mm3     
 Creatinine      2.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL)     
 Lactate dehydrogenase     445 U/L    
 Haptoglobin     Undetectable
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The patient has anemia with schistocytes on peripheral smear, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury associated with a gastrointestinal illness. The most likely diagnosis is hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) caused by Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) from the consumption of undercooked meat. Most cases occur in children, but it can be seen in adults as well.       

Thrombocytopenia can cause petechiae, purpura, and mucocutaneous bleeding. When patients have anemia, thrombocytopenia, and a peripheral blood smear with schistocytes, it suggests microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). MAHA can be due to thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA) (i.e. TTP or HUS) or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). If patients present with thrombotic microangiopathy, thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury, and exhibit neurological symptoms; then thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) should be considered.        
 
Thrombocytopenia can also be seen in patients with chronic conditions like liver disease, systemic lupus erythematous, or bone marrow disorders. Chronic liver disease would be associated with systemic signs and symptoms like jaundice abdominal distension and spider angioma. Patients with SLE can have a malar rash and arthritis, and patients with bone marrow diseases typically present with signs and symptoms related to cytopenia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Exposure to a new pet :
Incorrect: Exposure to animals can be linked to zoonotic infections, but they typically do not cause thrombotic microangiopathy with schistocytes and severe thrombocytopenia as is seen in this case. This patient’s presentation is most likely consistent with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) due to Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli  
✅ Consumption of undercooked meat  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of SLE :
Incorrect: Systemic rheumatic disorders, such as SLE, systemic sclerosis, and antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), can cause microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia. This patient has no prior history or current findings consistent with SLE and, given the recent diarrheal illness, more likely has hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) due to Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli.
❌ Recent travel to Africa :
Incorrect: This may suggest the possibility of malaria or dengue fever, which both can present with fever and thrombocytopenia. However, this patient has evidence of microangiopathy hemolytic anemia and a gastrointestinal illness, suggestive of HUS from eating undercooked meat. 
❌ Recent gardening:
Incorrect: This may suggest exposure to soil-borne pathogens, such as Sporothrix schenckii, leading to sporotrichosis, which can present with nodular skin lesions. This condition is not associated with thrombotic microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man is admitted to the coronary care unit after an acute myocardial infarction and placement of a drug-eluting stent in the left main coronary artery. While in the post-operative suite, the patient begins experiencing palpitations and lightheadedness. His rhythm strip is demonstrated below. He is immediately given a medication that decreases the slope of phase 0 of depolarization. The medication helps terminate the arrhythmia. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication? 


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Selective blockade of fast sodium channels
Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity
Blockade of voltage dependent calcium channels
Increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient presents with ventricular tachycardia after having an acute myocardial infarction. He is given a medication that decreases the slope of phase 0 of depolarization, which leads to termination of the arrhythmia. This mechanism of action is consistent with that of class I antiarrhythmics. These medications work primarily via selective blockade of fast sodium channels.        

Class I antiarrhythmics are divided into three major classes: A, B, and C. However, all of them work via the same mechanism of action. Sodium channel blockade slows the upstroke of the sodium-dependent action potential (phase 0) and prolongs the QRS duration. However, each group has a different affinity for the fast sodium channel, resulting in group 1A prolonging the action potential duration, 1B shortening the actional potential duration, and 1C having no effect on the action potential duration.        

These medications have a predilection to slow conduction in ischemic and depolarized cells. For this reason, class I antiarrhythmics are said to exhibit “state-dependent” action, meaning that they bind to sodium channels when they are open or inactivated and much less readily when they are fully repolarized and resting. This phenomenon means these medications will selectively depress tissue that is frequently depolarized, making them useful in treating reentrant tachycardias and ventricular tachycardias.  



Option Analysis

✅ Selective blockade of fast sodium channels :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers work via selective ꞵ-blockade, decreasing intracellular cAMP, and subsequently decreasing Ca2+ current. This mechanism ultimately decreases the slope of the phase 4 action potential.        
❌ Blockade of potassium rectifier currents :
Incorrect: Class III antiarrhythmic medications inhibit potassium channels responsible for the repolarization of the cardiac membrane. These medications ultimately lead to increased action potential duration, effective refractory period, and QT interval prolongation.  
❌ Blockade of voltage dependent calcium channels :
